[{'id': 49, 'article_title': 'SHERBORO', 'full_section_title': 'SHERBORO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1862#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_12_1862', 'content': "honest dues, if possible. In short, his motto must be, 'Whatsoever things are false, whatsoever things dishonest, whatsoever things are unjust, whatsoever things are impure, whatsoever things are unlovely, whatsoever things are of evil report—if there be any vice, if there be anything that a devil can praise, think on these things.' And yet he must be strictly honest with his employer! Must strip himself of every principle of honesty, truth and justice, in dealing with one class of individuals, and be expected to act from those same lost principles in dealing with another. The thing is morally impossible! He who would take advantage of a countryman would soon learn to take advantage of any other man, and he who would cheat a customer, would surely cheat an employer, if he could get an opportunity. Do those who trade upon such principles make anything in the end? Is there not far more chance for a clerk to cheat his employer than for his employer to cheat him? Would not honesty be far the best policy? Deal honestly with the country people, get honest, upright clerks, and expect to make a good, reasonable profit. They that make haste to be rich fall into a snare. Where is there a man who has made himself rich in trading in the Sherboro? Echo answers, where? Some have been made bankrupt, and ruined, and when they came to reflect upon it, they have the consolation of knowing that they have brought all this evil upon their own heads, by utterly disregarding this command of God."}, {'id': 877, 'article_title': 'SOUTH AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'SOUTH AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1866#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_07_1866', 'content': '"The influx of so many white traders in pursuit of ostrich feathers has exerted a baneful influence on the morals of the natives with whom they have come into contact. The conduct of most of these is a crying disgrace to the name they bear, as well as to the colour of their skin. Some of these have been heard to say that, as they are in a country without law, they can do as they like, and they do do things which make the natives themselves blush. Had we here Burtonians of the Anthropological school, we should like to point them to this and then to that, and ask them when savages are to be civilised under the system they so shamelessly advocate. It goes counter to all that is pure, honest, honourable, lovely, and of good report, ruining both soul and body by swindling, falsehood, and filthiness we will not define, enough to bring down the vengeance of Heaven. There are, however, honourable exceptions to the above, but, alas! they are few" — *Missionary Magazine and Chronicle, July 2, 1866.*'}, {'id': 2968, 'article_title': 'ILLEGAL OPENING OF LETTERS ON THE WEST COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'ILLEGAL OPENING OF LETTERS ON THE WEST COAST.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1875#article-21', 'issue_date': '01_10_1875', 'content': '[We have received the following from a mercantile house in Liverpool, to whom it was addressed.—*Ed. A.T.*]

*Extract from Letter dated Cameroons River, July 17, 1875.*

"I wrote you upon a subject in which you are concerned, and in which you will be deeply interested when you have learnt the facts of the case. Per steamer Bonny you sent to one of your traders a letter containing several documents. Upon the arrival of the steamer's boat to fetch a pilot, I went off to the ship Frances Milly, of London, for letters which the boat had delivered there. When on board Captain — asked me to take what letters there might be for the natives on shore. Among others I brought your letter for Mr. —, from which he learned there was a letter for Mr. —. Inquiry was made of me for it; I said there was not one for him, for I understood that I had brought all the letters ashore that were to come. Upon this he went on board the Frances Milly to make inquiries, and there learned that Captain —, who represents Messrs. —, had taken his letter and gone on board another ship. Upon this he put off to the ship, and there found Captain —, and asked him for the letter. This request was not complied with until Captain — had opened the letter and examined the documents, and made known many items of the contents to those present.

Notwithstanding this offence is so serious in the eyes of the English law, there is here no authority that can interfere in the matter. Natives who have correspondents in England are very angry to find trade jealousies can so influence the white man as to render letters for themselves unsafe while in his hands.'}, {'id': 4404, 'article_title': 'GAMBIA.—LAW COURTS, JURIES, TRADE.', 'full_section_title': 'GAMBIA.—LAW COURTS, JURIES, TRADE.', 'last_edit_date': '02-17-1882', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1882#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_04_1882', 'content': 'Any man who says he takes goods value 600l. for which he knows he can only return 400l., thereby netting a loss of 33½ per cent., publishes his own folly or dishonesty in taking goods at such a rate, well aware he cannot pay for them by a barter trade.

Were the records of the courts here for the past nine years examined, it would then be seen from the number of unsatisfied judgments there, on which heavy costs have been incurred, that a change in the law is imperative.

As to merchants, European or native, or other employers of native traders, being able to remedy the present evils themselves, they certainly can do so by one of two rather objectionable modes: 1st, to cease to entrust any trader with goods to barter in the river; this would lead to extensive ruin and starvation; or, 2nd, to apply the Mandingo law to all traders in the river, by which any man short in his accounts can have his property summarily seized, or failing that, his person seized, or if he is not to be caught, then any member of his family, who can be seized and held as a hostage for the payment of the amount due.

It is rather a sarcasm on the "Native Traders' Association" that one of their leading men should have lately committed a piece of sharp practice, to give it a mild term, which is being investigated at present, and for which in England a man gets some years' imprisonment, and, perhaps, hard labour; and that another case of an also not doubtful nature is to be investigated shortly, which may lead to disagreeable consequences.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

FREDERIC SPEER.

FRENCH AGGRESSION ON THE GAMBIA'}, {'id': 6697, 'article_title': 'THE FUTURE OF THE NEGRO', 'full_section_title': 'THE FUTURE OF THE NEGRO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_02_1896#article-0', 'issue_date': '03_02_1896', 'content': 'to fraudulently fold his piece goods for the African trade so as, while showing the same number of folds, to mulct the Native of a few yards. This state of things has rendered it necessary for the West African Governments to pass an ordinance making it penal to sell fraudulently-folded woven goods. I mention this only to show that persons, before passing judgment on the West African, should first look at home.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': "A Merchant's View of the Gambia River Trade", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A few years ago I have known Mandingoes to make away with 50 to 75 per cent. of the goods entrusted to them, the ordinary amount being 25 to 30 per cent. The Leboos this year have "lost" (?) 25 to 30 per cent. Jolloff traders, natives of Bathurst, seem, many of them, as bad; so that people now say, "Where are we to get good reliable men?"

You may say, "Put the criminal law in force." Yes, if this were England, you could; but not in Gambia. The law is powerless. In the first place, you cannot bring the man up under the Imperial statute for embezzlement, as you cannot give proof of "conversion." No native will come into court and give evidence of such "conversion." Well, to meet this, some years ago, a local ordinance was passed, by which any factor, trader, or agent trading up the river, who, being entrusted with goods, on his return to Bathurst, was deficient in his accounts, and could not satisfactorily answer for the same, was liable to two years' imprisonment. Well, when the conduct of traders became unbearable, three years ago, two test cases were brought before the Judge at the Sessions; and though the cases were clearly proved, and even one of the men confessed to have embezzled goods, the jury in each case refused to convict; and in one case, after much argument, the Foreman clinched the arguments by saying, "We must not convict this man; if we do, none of us are safe." This juror did not understand that the Act only applies to trade in the river, not in Bathurst, and he was a shopkeeper here, and a great church-goer. Thus, you see that the law is made inoperative, and we have no protection whatever against fraud. You can, of course, sue a man in the Civil Court; but, then, as he seldom has in Bathurst more than the clothes he stands in, as soon as the writ is issued he leaves Bathurst; or else, if he defends the case, as soon as judgment is marked; and if he does return again, you can do nothing, as there is nothing to "seize." Natives of Sierra Leone go away to the place; Mandingoes go up the river; Jolloffs do the same; Leboos go to Senegal. The law, as it works, is useless,—only obstructs justice, and protects criminals.

The trade, as I have shown, cannot be carried on without these traders; then, if they will not be honest naturally, the law should be so made and administered as to punish the dishonest.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-07-27', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1881#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letters to the Editor: The C.M.S. Niger Mission—A Warning to Native Merchants', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## A WARNING TO NATIVE MERCHANTS.

### TO THE EDITOR OF "THE AFRICAN TIMES."

Sir,—Will you permit me space in your pages to show some of my brethren on the West Coast how I have been swindled by a firm of professing merchants in London, in the hope that a relation of my experience may be of service to others, and cause them to make all needful inquiries as to the good faith and solvency of those to whom they are thinking of consigning goods for realisation in the London markets, or money for purchase of goods for Africa.

In May last year I received letters from a firm dating from the City, offering to do business with me, whether in the way of realisation or purchase, and professing to have exceptional facilities for the disposal of African produce, and the purchase of European goods in exchange. They made such a plausible tale that I was quite taken with them, and forwarded a box of gold dust, together with samples of goods I wanted in return. This came duly into their hands, and I received an acknowledgment from them with a statement showing that the gold dust had realised £56 10s. 10d., but that the goods I required would cost a good deal more than that. I accordingly obtained and forwarded to them a draft, making in all £97 10s. 2d.; at the same time sending them my gold watch (value £7) for cleaning and repairs in London. This second remittance was also acknowledged in due course—and there the matter ended! Finding weeks go by, and nothing come to hand, I wrote to a firm in London, upon whose integrity I can rely, for them to inquire into the matter, and do the best they could—either in the way of getting back my money or by urging these people to hurry on with the goods, so that I might not entirely lose the market. They accordingly wrote to the firm in question several times, but only to receive vague promises of immediate attention, or still more evasive answers. So I determined myself to come to London to see what could be done. And the upshot of my inquiries is that the firm to whom I had consigned my money and goods have proved utter swindlers: they traded under a fancy name, and when they found things were getting too hot for them they left the country, so as to be beyond the reach of the law.

For myself I must make up my mind to cut my loss; as I understand that even if I could get hold of the swindlers there is no chance of my regaining any portion of what they have had from me. But I hope my experience will be of some use to others who, trading on the West Coast of Africa, are under the necessity of trusting so much to persons or firms in London or the other European capitals.—Yours faithfully,', 'last_edit_date': '1891-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1891#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL DEPRESSION ON THE WEST COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The most unpleasant side of the question to me is that, after these inexperienced European merchants have so imprudently supplied goods to adventurous traders without securities, or worthless securities (and many a time without any reference to the Coast respecting the pecuniary status or reputation of the consignee), they are only too ready to brand all Africans as a race of dishonest robbers. A certain Manchester merchant, in writing to a friend on this subject, lately said, "I have lost £60,000 on the coast of Africa, £30,000 of which I have lost in Lagos." Now, Mr. Editor, the class of men this particular merchant credited is almost beyond belief. One of the effects of this system which have to be deplored is the serious and unwarrantable competition that follows, to the detriment of capitalists. The debtor merchant being sure that he would never possibly pay his creditor in full, for the purpose of giving temporary impetus to the trade, will undersell capitalists and over-top them in buying produce, and with these large shipments or remittances generally baffle their unwary creditors, and secure more confidence and larger credits. They are spoken of as big traders, enterprising men, and such like; it matters not whether the produce shipped has been surreptitiously received and not paid for. The result is that the honest capitalists are threatened with ruin, as they cannot come into open conflict with the fraudulent merchants in their ruinous competitive undertakings, as the latter have nothing to lose. The *Lagos Times*, in its issue of the 10th August, 1881, in inveighing in strong terms against the credit system of Lagos, says: "There is a great facility afforded by it (the credit system) for dishonest and dishonourable transactions. Distance between here and Europe enables one who solicits credit to exaggerate the market value of the property he tenders to a creditor for security, and thus obtains a considerably larger supply than the true value of his property would have warranted; and there are never wanting those who are ready to swear anything, who would solemnly affirm to the alleged estimated value being a fair and just one. They are anxious, perhaps, to help their friend, and this they scruple not to do at the expense of their own better convictions, and of the wholesome advice that we should be just and true to all men alike; and so it has often come to pass that properties are encumbered with debts three times their market value at the time those debts were contracted. . . . Further, the system opens a way for extravagance, and renders it easy for those who are not careful to get into debt. It cannot be denied that men are generally more careful of that which they have earned by their own independent honest industry than of that which is left to them by others, or is given them on credit; and that they would sometimes have dispensed with that which they readily take on credit if they had had to pay for it at once out of their savings. Often upon the receipts of large credits new modes of living are at once adopted; artificial wants rapidly increase; the luxuries, the expensive, and perhaps not innocuous pleasures of European life, and the extravagance of foreign fashions, become at once indispensable; large houses are built and furnished, perhaps in very expensive style. . . . It has sometimes been to us a question whether these persons did ever really intend to repay the loans they so freely squander away when they sought for them."', 'last_edit_date': '1885-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1885#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Yet the Government is not alone to blame. Our merchants have frequently preferred to listen to the wild harangues of men whose exaggeration was patent to all, instead of paying attention to the estimates of those whose accuracy could not be questioned. Some have rushed into the African trade without knowledge or capital, and by ignorance and rashness have not only lost their own money, but have caused serious loss to firms who were working on a sound basis, but in consequence of the competition of mushroom adventurers, had to trade at a rate of exchange which barely paid expenses, and even to retain their connexion with those who took European manufactures in return for raw produce, at an actual loss. These remarks, of course, more especially apply to the trade with West Africa, but over the whole Continent, wherever the British merchant has a footing, he has had to contend with similar difficulties, and to put up with foreign competition carried on in a manner that scarcely savours of fair trade. Foreign competitors, wherever English influence is paramount, have the same privileges as themselves, but directly British protectorate or colony is quitted (except in the Oil Rivers and the Free Trade district of the Congo State) they have to compete with hostile tariffs and duties. In the early days of commerce the West Coast was a happy hunting ground for the merchant who did not much care whether his cargo consisted of gold dust, ivory, or slaves for the plantations in the Western Hemisphere. Many of the ships which visited the coast seemed to consider all that sailed under a foreign flag as fair prize, and even failed to recognize the friendship due to a fellow-countryman. Chartered companies were formed by different nations, which did their best to prevent their unlicensed competitors from encroaching on their privileges; and when war broke out between their respective countries, were quite ready to join in the conflict. These chartered companies made treaties with the natives, and built forts and stations which became emporia of trade. On the Gold Coast these forts succeeded each other in rapid succession. Hollanders, Brandenburghers, Danes, Portuguese, French, and English, all possessed strongholds, some of which are in use at the present day. The solidity of the masonry, the size and design of these fortresses, show the importance which the traders of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries attached to this West African trade. Slavery was rampant, and it is almost certain that without slave labour they would never have been constructed. A large portion of the trade was doubtless in slaves, but still that alone could never have accounted for the prosperity and wealth of the merchants who traded with Western Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. These were strong statements, they would say, and required confirmation. If true, what could possibly have caused this frightful miscarriage of the noblest aspirations of a Christian people? The answer was simply the nature of their commerce with Africa in the past and present. To the slave and gin trades, and that in gunpowder and guns, must he ascribed the frightful evils they had brought upon the negro race, beside which the good they had tried to achieve was hardly discernible.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Alleged Atrocities in the Congo Free State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A recent number of the Sierra Leone *Weekly News* stated that the men from Sierra Leone and others who have ventured into the service of the Congo Free State are suffering terribly at the hands of their employers, who illuse them, break their engagements, intercept their communications with Sierra Leone, and, in a word, use them as slaves. It published the following letter from a correspondent at Stanley Falls, at the upper waters of the Congo: "Your countrymen of Sierra Leone are induced to come hither as workmen, and afterwards are compelled to serve as soldiers; they are contracted with for a salary to be paid in English money, and they are compelled to take their pay in inferior Belgian goods. Their food consists of fish dried many moons ago, and rice only. They are beaten with the 'chikote,' dried hippo hide, for the slightest reason or for no reason; the sick languish in wretched native huts, through which the rain and sun stream, and are denied either blankets or beds by the State. If they complain they are punished, and if they write to their friends or complain to the Governor of Sierra Leone the letters are opened and stopped by the officials. Men whose term of service has expired are kept in distant parts of the river. The natives are cruelly treated, their homes are burned, their property confiscated, and their wives and children reduced to bondage by the State. The State not only allows the slave trade to go on, it is itself engaged in the wholesale and retail traffic in human beings.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-01-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_01_1891#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.636, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In another column we have just briefly noticed the pamphlet dealing with the Liquor traffic of Africa which has been lately issued by the C.M.S. as the outcome of a Committee of Delegates of the British Missionary Societies appointed to consider this subject as it concerns the natives of Africa. This pamphlet throws a strong light upon a matter of which, perhaps, most people, even of those specially interested in the regeneration of Africa, have heard but little. The evidence now brought together goes to prove that in certain parts the wages of native labourers are paid, even in the case of mere boys and girls, in spirits, and that as a result, in some places, after the first hour or so, labour is unprocurable on account of the drunkenness of the people. "The idea of drinking spirits is inseparable from the notion of European life in the ken of the natives. Owing to the relaxing climate of the rivers, there are few factories which cannot tell their tale of hard drinking and certain death as a consequence. But we are repeating an oft-told story, and those who read these pages have probably made themselves acquainted with the state of the West Coast in some degree. ... Competition is relentless; times are very bad; palm oil has fallen to a ruinous rate. But the degradation of the tribes of West Africa has reached a depth which is appalling." Few men are more fitted to testify concerning the extent to which liquor trafficking with the native races of Africa has reached than Mr. Jas. Irvine, of Liverpool; and the following extract from a communication from him speaks volumes: "It is very difficult to give you an account of the ramifications of the drink traffic on the West Coast of Africa—not because there is little to be said, but because it is only a repetition of the oft-told story in every part of the world. The extent of the trade is so prodigious that I think the following estimate of the quantity annually poured into the delta of the Niger relieves me from the necessity of further remark concerning this evil. ... I am sure I do not over-estimate the quantity when I put it down at 60,000 hogsheads of 50 gallons each as the annual consumption in the rivers." We have in the native African one whose natural character is so weak that he easily becomes a victim when a dead set is made at him by those who are able to influence him. One needs go no further than the store-house of the first West African factory to know what is the native's weak point, and the form of the attack made upon it. His propensity to strong drink has been pandered to until things could hardly be worse with him. Mr. Joseph Thomson, the eminent African traveller, recently laid before the members of the Manchester Geographical Society his views upon this subject, and which fully support what has been already said: "In the notorious gin trade lies a greater evil even than slavery. It is indeed a scandal and a shame. ... We talk of civilizing the negro and introducing the blessings of European trade, while at the same time we pour into this unhappy country incredible quantities of gin, rum, gunpowder, and guns. ... The trade in spirits is simply enormous. The appetite for it increases out of all proportion to the desire for better things; and, to our shame be it said, we are ever ready to supply the victims to the utmost, driving them deeper and deeper into the slough of depravity, while at home we talk sanctimoniously as if the introduction of our trade and the elevation of the negro went hand in hand." This is a heavy indictment against the people who would', 'last_edit_date': '1887-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1887#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL COMPANIES FOR AFRICAN TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'But it takes so long to undo evil, and destroy its baneful venom among mankind, that the infamous slave-trade, though scotched, is not yet killed. European Governments, even when sincere, are lax and feeble, fitful and vacillating in their inadequate efforts against it. It can only be thoroughly destroyed in one way. It flourished in an European and Asiatic desire for an accursed gain.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This subject is (says the *Manchester Guardian*, in a series of excellent articles upon the present state of the West Coast of Africa, now under publication) a very wide one, the trade of Africa being carried on under such different conditions, by such different races, and the goods dealt in being so various, that it would seem difficult to bring all under one discussion; but, unfortunately, all the trade of Africa has one great point of similarity, and that is that all is depressed, and much is passing into the hands of foreign competitors. A Royal Commission has been appointed to inquire into the causes of depression in trade. The causes of the depression in African trade are not far to seek, and the remedies must be applied by the Government, and not by the merchants. The apathetic policy which has been pursued, the systematic ignoring of those who have knowledge and experience, and the entrusting of important interests to incompetent hands, have had the effects which were to be expected, and unless some decisive action is taken soon, we may expect our African trade to go from bad to worse, and be all transferred from London, Liverpool, and Bristol to Hamburg, Havre, and Marseilles.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Trading Troubles in Western Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'To a palaver on board his gunboat all the chiefs were recently summoned by the English Consul, who said he regretted deeply to see the state into which the country had fallen, the want of unity that existed amongst the chiefs and people, and the general lawlessness that prevailed. He said he was ready to hear any complaints and suggestions that might be made and invited the various chiefs to speak out their minds fully, frankly, and freely. Possibly, when the Consul did this, he hardly knew what was in store for him, and what a wide field he had opened up, because ever since he has been sitting *de die in diem*. Complaints and mutual recriminations have been rife, allegations have been freely preferred, and often as frankly admitted, of the most horrible crimes, and the proceedings have been a record generally of murder and villainy of every description. However, patience and an enforcement—strictly necessary when one chief brought up a dispute thirty-three years old—of the statute of limitations have at length completed the charges and counter-charges, and the Consul has at length been enabled to give his decision. He certainly showed he was in earnest on the first day of the palaver by fining each of the chiefs half a puncheon of palm oil (equivalent to £5), because their canoes made a row alongside the gunboat. He has now formed a "constitutional government," consisting of the three most powerful chiefs, whom he holds responsible for the administration of the Bonny territory; he has severely fined numerous of the offending chiefs, and has given directions, under a heavy penalty, for the payment of the debts owing by the chiefs to the traders, which in this river amount to some thousands of pounds sterling. It is to be hoped that after this the trade of this river, which has for some time past been yearly retrograding, will show signs of improvement. Formerly Bonny used to be emphatically *the* oil river, but latterly, year by year, its export of that commodity has been diminishing, whilst that of all the other rivers has been increasing. It is an extraordinary fact that, as the price of palm oil has been diminishing month by month, the produce of it has been increasing. This simply arises from the fact that the African is too lazy to work more than is absolutely necessary to obtain what he requires, or thinks he requires. Consequently, as the value obtained in kind for a puncheon of palm oil has diminished, he brings more oil to market to obtain an equivalent supply of gin, gunpowder, clothes, &c., to what he previously received, and so the very proceeding which arises in the first instance from a lowering in the price of the oil at home has a tendency to still further decrease prices by glutting the market.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.637, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the course of some excellent articles which have appeared lately in the *Manchester Guardian*, dealing with the present and future trade prospects of Africa, we have one chapter devoted to the consideration of the drawbacks upon genuine commerce by the enforcement of such quasi-regal rights as those exercised by Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, and the rest of that host of petty kinglings, in the districts of the West Coast. The article in question says:—

One of the ways in which the development of trade must be carried out is by pushing factories up beyond the tribes who now serve as middlemen between the European trader and the native producer. Some difficulty will no doubt be encountered in passing through the unhealthy and malarious districts in which these middlemen live, but the improved knowledge we are obtaining of how to combat climatic diseases will render such an enterprise more easy than it would have been twenty years ago. Indeed, if we contrast the early reports of the Niger with its present exploitation, we may believe that the climate of no tropical country will permanently prevent its being opened up to commerce. This is a ray of hope for our African traders, and it is to be hoped that our Government will enable them to avail themselves of it speedily, and not allow them to be forestalled by the merchants of other nations. As if the inaction of our Government had not been sufficiently disastrous to the trade of the African merchants of Liverpool and Manchester, the home legislation of the last few years has also done much to hamper their enterprise. One industry alone, which, though it may be considered a small one, came in the aggregate to a considerable amount, has been completely driven out of the country. The trade in matches to the West Coast used to be supplied by Manchester. Now, the children who used to be employed in their manufacture are sent to school hungry, while German matches are sent in German ships to those who used to buy the English ones, and the only profit to English people is that of the middleman, and even that is being rapidly taken from them.

The German and French textile manufactures are also running us close, and we have to watch carefully the change of fashions and ideas among the natives. Many cheap articles made in France, with a ready sale on the coast, could easily be made in England. Some of the native manufactures could easily be imitated, such as the Niger cloths and the silk and cotton cloths made by the Santees and Ashantees of unravelled European stuffs. Beyond the Oil rivers to the south we have the French colony of the Gaboon, which has now become one of the largest tracts of Africa controlled by an European nation. In the old portion of the colony trade is not so flourishing as it used to be, English enterprise having been driven away by the action of protection and differential duties.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.636, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The history of British commercial connexion with this part of Africa may be briefly told. More than 100 years ago the ships of one or two Liverpool and Bristol merchants were actively engaged in exchanging cargo for slaves, ivory, and palm oil. Fifty years ago the four or five leading houses in the trade were already strong enough to dispense with the profits of slave traffic and rely on the ordinary channels of commerce. It was not, however, without great sacrifices and outlay of money on their part that the change was made palatable to the great native chiefs of the Bights of Benin and Biafra, who had grown immensely wealthy and powerful by the trade in humanity. To induce a better business in native products, loans and presents of cotton goods, hardware, and other articles were made on an extensive scale, and the palm oil trade thus rapidly developed in importance. Examination of the shipping books of one of the greatest firms of that period (1843) shows about forty-six various assortments of articles shipped in twelve months; and the changes brought about by improving civilisation and persistent commercial effort are evidenced in the 300 or more distinct and separate items of export now found in the invoice books of Oil Rivers merchants. Comparative statistics are not available in any authentic form. The quantity of palm oil imported into Europe has varied very little all along, though the tendency has been slightly to increase. A new trade, however, rivalling in dimensions that in oil, has sprung up through the activity of English merchants, and palm kernels—formerly waste product—are bought up in great quantities for shipment to European crushing mills. Ivory has all but disappeared. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'How Commerce Alone Civilizes', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The trade in palm oil in the Brass river is very considerable. The large Liverpool houses have been trading there in this article for many years, and many English agents' vessels and crews are continually in the river, yet in a letter in the *West African Herald* of May 20, we find the following in a letter dated River Brass. After stating that there are disagreements among the natives, he adds: "Several engagements have taken place, and many prisoners taken. A few days ago, nine or ten of these unfortunate 'Nungums' were taken prisoners, brought down the river, killed and eaten, and within a mile or so of us, the fact becoming known when too late to endeavour (were it possible) to prevent such a barbarous custom." No: there is no civilization for Africa without the light of Christianity.', 'last_edit_date': '1869-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1869#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: Local conflicts and tribal hostilities in 19th-century Africa, particularly between Abeokuta and Lagos, severely disrupted trade and highlighted the economic instability caused by regional tensions and ineffective colonial mediation.
result: The claim that local conflicts and tribal hostilities in 19th-century Africa, particularly between Abeokuta and Lagos, severely disrupted trade and highlighted economic instability due to regional tensions and ineffective colonial mediation is supported by observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles, albeit with differing emphases. The General History of Africa does not specifically mention conflicts between Abeokuta and Lagos, but it discusses broader themes of regional conflicts, trade disruptions, and economic instability across Africa during the 19th century. It highlights the impact of colonial rule on African traders, the decline of traditional trading systems, and the tensions arising from the transition from the slave trade to legitimate trade, as well as the role of European interests in shaping economic dynamics. In contrast, The African Times provides specific details supporting the claim, noting the interruption of trade communications between Lagos and Abeokuta due to a robbery by Abeokuta warriors and the dissatisfaction of merchants despite the resumption of trade. The articles also describe the blockade of roads by the Egbas, Jebus, and Yorubas, which severely impacted trade with Lagos, and highlight the ineffectiveness of colonial mediation, with calls for the return of ex-Governor Glover to resolve the situation. Additionally, the articles mention broader regional tensions, such as the Ashantee war and conflicts involving the Dahomans, contributing to economic instability. Together, these sources illustrate how local conflicts and ineffective colonial intervention disrupted trade and highlighted economic instability in the region.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook does not specifically mention local conflicts or tribal hostilities between Abeokuta and Lagos in the 19th century, nor does it directly address the economic instability caused by such regional tensions or ineffective colonial mediation in that specific context. However, the text does discuss broader themes of regional conflicts, trade disruptions, and economic instability in various parts of Africa during the 19th century. It highlights the impact of colonial rule on African traders, the decline of traditional trading systems, and the tensions arising from the transition from the slave trade to legitimate trade. Additionally, the text mentions the role of European interests in shaping economic dynamics and the challenges faced by African societies in adapting to these changes. While these themes align with the general idea of regional tensions affecting trade and economic stability, the specific claim about Abeokuta and Lagos is not directly addressed in the provided paragraphs, marking a notable difference.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim regarding the disruption of trade due to local conflicts and tribal hostilities in 19th-century Africa, particularly between Abeokuta and Lagos. The articles mention the interruption of trade communications between Lagos and Abeokuta due to a robbery by Abeokuta warriors, and the subsequent dissatisfaction of merchants despite the resumption of trade. Additionally, the articles highlight the blockade of roads by the Egbas, Jebus, and Yorubas, which severely impacted trade with Lagos. The tensions between these tribes and the colonial administration are evident, with the articles noting the ineffectiveness of colonial mediation and the call for the return of ex-Governor Glover to resolve the situation. Furthermore, the articles describe the broader context of regional tensions, such as the Ashantee war and conflicts involving the Dahomans, which contributed to economic instability. These details align with the claim by illustrating how local conflicts and ineffective colonial intervention disrupted trade and highlighted economic instability in the region.
