[{'id': 54, 'article_title': 'LAGOS', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1862#article-8', 'issue_date': '23_12_1862', 'content': 'We are sorry to be obliged to state that the trade communications between this place and Abeokuta have been interrupted during an entire month—viz., from October 7 to November 6. On the former day a considerable robbery with violence was committed on the river. A number of canoes, going up from this place for Abeokuta, laden with valuable produce, were attacked and taken by some of the warriors from the Abeokuta camp. All the efforts and demands made by the merchants to obtain a restitution of their stolen property have been fruitless. The chief authorities have promised that the merchants shall be repaid "after the war;" stating that they are unable to take any effective measures for recovering the property now, as "it would interrupt the progress of the war, and might lead to discord."

The merchants are, with reason, far from being satisfied; but, nevertheless, trade has recommenced.

Her Majesty's ship Investigator struck on the bar when coming in on November 26. Guns were fired at intervals during the day, and it was feared she would have to be abandoned; but she was towed off late in the day by the Advance merchant steamer (Mr. M'Corsky's).

Great complaints are made by the merchants as to the arrangements for vessels crossing the bar.'}, {'id': 70, 'article_title': 'West African Mail', 'full_section_title': 'West African Mail', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1863#article-0', 'issue_date': '23_01_1863', 'content': "The African Royal Mail steamship Ethiope, Captain G. F. Smart, arrived at Liverpool on Monday, 12th inst., bringing nine passengers, two invalided seamen from Her Majesty's ship Investigator, 1,539 oz. gold dust, 72 sovereigns, 1,018 Spanish dollars, and a full cargo of palm oil, ivory, gum, beeswax, &c. Her dates are: Benin, Nov. 24; Fernando Po, 28th; Cameroons, 30th; Old Calabar, Dec. 2; Nun River and Brass River, 4th; Bonny, 7th; Lagos, 10th; Accra, 12th; Cape Coast Castle, 14th; Cape Palmas, 16th; Sierra Leone, 21st; Bathurst, 25th; Teneriffe, Jan. 1; and Madeira, 3rd.

- **Benin.**—Trade fair. River healthy.
- **Fernando Po.**—The island continues healthy. Trade very dull.
- **Cameroons.**—Trade still remains very languid. River healthy.
- **Old Calabar.**—Trade dull; no improvement since the departure of the last mail. Health of the river pretty fair, but sickness prevalent amongst the natives.
- **Brass.**—River healthy. Trade very fair.
- **Bonny.**—Trade very dull. The fever has nearly disappeared from the river. The brig John Brooks, after crossing the bar on the 25th November (inward bound), went on shore the same afternoon on the eastern breakers, and was abandoned the same night by the captain and all the crew. She was picked up next day afloat, about ten miles to seaward, by Mr. Ward, and brought into harbour at considerable personal risk, both on account of the natives and the distance she had drifted to sea. Although being the consignee of the vessel, he claims the privileges of a sailor.
- **Lagos.**—Healthy. Trade fair. Trade at Abeokuta completely closed on account of the war amongst the natives. Commodore Wilmott, Captain Lewis, and the surgeon of the Brisk, had gone on a visit to the King of Dahomey.
- **Accra.**—Trade almost at a stand. The shocks of earthquake still continue.
- **Cape Coast.**—Everything is now quiet here since the mutiny amongst the troops.
- **Sierra Leone.**—Healthy. Trade fair.
- **Bathurst.**—Healthy. Trade dull.

---"}, {'id': 179, 'article_title': 'GENERAL OBSERVATIONS', 'full_section_title': 'GENERAL OBSERVATIONS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1863#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_06_1863', 'content': 'We fear the Ashantee war will be a tedious and expensive one. The difficulty and delay in sending ammunition and supplies into the interior, *in consequence of the total absence of anything like a road,* is disgraceful to Great Britain. The Governor seems to be doing everything in his power; but we feel no confidence in the military command. Unless officers have previously given evidence of great ability, we do not think it ought at all to follow, as a matter of course, that those who may happen to be on the spot whenever and wherever hostilities occur should retain the command in face of the enemy. When the first news of hostilities comes, attended by that of some rapid and able action on their part, giving indication of talent and energy, we should be the last to wish to deprive them of an opportunity of gaining distinction. Otherwise it seems to us to be one of the first duties of the home authorities to send out some superior officer without delay. We think, too, the Governmental staff ought to be complete. The Governor ought to have at his command all necessary assistance. A heavy responsibility rests upon him. And especial care should be taken in such a climate as that of the Gold Coast that he is not left alone. A wise supervision and direction leaves as little as possible to accident. As the rainy season had commenced, we fear we shall hear of great sickness among the officers and West India troops sent up into the bush. Unless for immediate action with the enemy, they ought not to be there. We hope to hear by the next mail that the Fort of Quittah has been reoccupied. If not, not only will military stores reach the Ashantees from that direction, but such of the captives made by the latter in the Protected Territories as are not sacrificed will find their way uninterruptedly to the slave ships at Augwy.

The Mohammedan war of conversion or extermination in the Gambia, under the chief Mabba, continues. The Governor is about to give the refugee Sonnikees lands and seed for planting cotton. It looks as though we should be compelled at last to imitate the French policy in Senegal.

The King of Dahomey is about to hold another Custom. The French have obtained a complete cession of Porto Novo and its territories, including a line of sea coast.

The Liberians claim not the Gallinas, but the Shebar, as their northern frontier limit.

---

The war party in Abeokuta are still in covert hostility with Lagos, and trade in the latter is very bad. In consequence of the stoppage of the roads, only 533 bales of African cotton have reached England from January to June, 1863, against 1,566 bales during the same months last year.'}, {'id': 2240, 'article_title': 'Letters to the Earl of Kimberley on Lagos Affairs', 'full_section_title': 'Letters to the Earl of Kimberley on Lagos Affairs', 'last_edit_date': '05-23-1872', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_06_1872#article-4', 'issue_date': '24_06_1872', 'content': 'My Lord,—There being an outward mail for the West Coast of Africa, I hasten to forward to your lordship copy of a letter received by me this morning from Abeokuta.

I shall not now make any comments on this important communication, by the contents of which your lordship will not fail to perceive that many of my worst fears, formerly expressed, have been realized.—I have the honour to remain, my Lord, your Lordship's obedient servant,

F. FITZGERALD, Editor of the _African Times_. To the Right Honourable Earl Kimberley, K.G.

_Custom House-road, Abeokuta, April 8, 1872._

Sir,—Abeokuta is now surrounded with enemies, who, as I said before, have been supplied with munitions of war to attack us this season; and although news reached us that the Dahomans are on their march for Abeokuta, they are not yet in sight. The Ibadans, as we are informed, are now in arms ready for this place, or may go to the Ijebu territory if the Dahomans fail to come forward. Of course we are not behind in our preparations. Our numerous farmers around are all in, ready to man our walls. Two of our villages, Ishals and Abo, not being aware that the Dahomans would pass by their roads, were suddenly carried off to hopeless slavery; guns and powder not being supplied to them from Abeokuta this year, which still renders these poor creatures a hopeless defence. Rumours say they will be in all about 500 souls—men, women, and children! To say nothing of the dead! Thus you see the evil ordinance, prohibiting and supplying guns, &c., in certain cases.

You would not be surprised to hear of our roads of produce, going down to Lagos, being blockaded on the 18th ult. Apart from the grievance before mentioned, guns and powder have been distributed to our territories below Otta by the Lagos Government; this additional evil has been the cause of the roads being finally closed up, until better understanding for peace can be arrived at between the two Governments.

All your letters for January to the Secretary of State were read to the Egbas; his lordship's reply to your letters not being favourable, and because of the implicit confidence and good faith which we have already planted in the minds of the Egbas towards Her Majesty the Queen and good people in England, the Board of Management has refrained reading that reply to His Supreme Majesty Oyekon, as it will cause grief and loss of confidence in the minds of the Egbas, who are strongly allied with the sister country, Ijebus, for peace or war against their common enemies. The people of Abeokuta have no more faith in Glover's Administration, and so long as England would not believe your letters, although truthfully and justly written for the good of Africa, I am afraid "the roads here, as well as in other places around, will remain perfectly closed, until the death of Glover or his final removal from Lagos." This is the voice of the people.'}, {'id': 2396, 'article_title': 'WHEAT CULTIVATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'WHEAT CULTIVATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': '02-28-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/28_02_1873#article-12', 'issue_date': '28_02_1873', 'content': 'Extract.

"A correspondent sends us the following extract from a private letter just received from Lagos, by the steamer Loanda: 'A proclamation from the Egbas, Jebus, and the Yorubas was received here on January 11, stating that they will not open the roads until the English give up, and all white men leave, Lagos, Leckie, and Palma. So there is not much chance of the roads being re-opened for some years to come. If the roads are to be re-opened at all, it must be by shot, shell, and rockets, or by blockading them. The natives, instead of sending produce, destroy it; whilst vessels here have to leave in ballast. It is a great pity that Governor Glover ever left, as I am sure that, had he been here, he would have opened the roads before this. There is a strong feeling in Lagos in favour of Governor Glover, and even his opponents are beginning to see that they have been de- luded. There is no resource left but force; and the Home Government will be culpable if they neglect to make use of it. Ever since Governor Glover was recalled, both the Lagos Government and its messengers have been treated with contempt, especially by the King of the Je- bus. The British flag has been dishonoured and treated con- temptuously by a few tribes of semi-barbarians, who still hold the power of England at defiance. At first there were only two tribes, the Abeokutans and the Jebus, opposed to the opening of the road, but now the Yorubas have joined; so that, with the exception of Porto Novo, Lagos is completely blockaded for business purposes.' Our correspondent adds that his own con- viction is that a general appeal will be made, both by the Europeans and natives, for the return of ex-Governor Glover, and that the result of Governor Glover's re-appointment will be the opening of the roads into the interior, and the consequent full resumption of trade."'}, {'id': 2756, 'article_title': 'SLAVERY ON THE GOLD COAST', 'full_section_title': 'SLAVERY ON THE GOLD COAST', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_08_1874#article-12', 'issue_date': '29_08_1874', 'content': '### A LITTLE WAR IN PORTO NOVO.

We are sorry to learn, by latest intelligence from Lagos, not only that there is a domestic war at Porto Novo between two sets of Princes there, but that the Egbas have been so ill advised as to side with one of the parties against the other, and send an armed expedition to Porto Novo in aid of one of the contending parties. This, our Lagos correspondent adds, has necessarily interfered a little with the trade of Lagos westward; while the reopening of the Jebu portion of the Eastward trade has not yet been productive of much benefit, in consequence of the palm fruit having been allowed to rot on the trees during the long-continued suspension of trade with Lagos. This little incident shows anew how difficult it is to coerce these native kings to trade with us, through any desire on the part of their people to obtain those European goods which they willingly work for and willingly purchase while trade with Lagos is pursuing its ordinary course; and how indispensable it is to the trading prosperity of Lagos that there should be a man of prudence, conciliatory as well as firm, at the head of Lagos affairs. We regret the absence of Captain Lees from his Government under these circumstances. The produce of all those countries around Lagos is necessary to its trading prosperity; and had Captain Lees been there, we should certainly have expected him to make some endeavour to mediate between the contending parties. We do not know that the acting head of the Executive at Lagos has not done this; but we do not find any mention of it in our letters. We hope the omission has been on the part of our correspondents, and not of that of the Acting Lieutenant-Governor.'}, {'id': 3684, 'article_title': 'West Coast News', 'full_section_title': 'West Coast News', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1879#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_01_1879', 'content': 'Mr. William Robinson, writing from Whydah on October 27th, says: "Quittah has been in a state of siege. Business operations had been entirely suspended, and the factories were being turned into fortresses. Kroomen were armed and provided with ammunition, gangs told off nightly to patrol the streets, whilst the Government were preparing redoubts and taking every precautionary measure against an impending attack. The effects of the sad affair, in which Captain Ellis and his companion have plunged the town, cannot yet be realized. It will be, undoubtedly, a costly job for Government and an awkward matter to settle, for the same law as in olden times prevails, 'blood for blood.' Even if war is averted, which is very desirable, and an amicable settlement come to, it will take some time to efface it from the memories of the country people, and bring them round to the same state of tranquillity as heretofore. In fact, great dissatisfaction is everywhere expressed against the Government, and every market day there are complaints against Houssas stealing firewood, turkeys, etc. This all tends to affect the trade of the port. Merchants suffer and agents' lives are endangered by the foolhardiness of a young inexperienced Commandant. A very uneasy feeling prevails amongst Europeans at Whydah to know what steps the Government are likely to take in order to enforce the balance of the fine the King has not paid and still persists in not paying. The country is very tranquil and trade good, and we think if Consul Hopkins was sent up he would be able to persuade his Highness to pay without resorting to extreme measures, thereby endangering lives. Lagos trade was extremely dull, owing to the interior war. Merchants were loud in their protests against the Governor not taking any steps to put an immediate end to the war, nor using his influence to bring about a reconciliation between the two conflicting tribes. In order still to make matters worse, the King of Porto Novo has shut the roads against provisions and fresh meat going into Lagos. After the recent epidemic which the inhabitants have passed through, it is really too bad that they should be prohibited fresh provisions, so needful to the preservation of health."

We learn by the "Senegal" that Mr. Consul Hopkins has arranged temporarily certain difficulties which had arisen between King George of Bonny and his chiefs. King George had, we fear, been badly inspired by some of his new friends in England, who were totally ignorant of Bonny customs, prejudices, and powers; but we hope all will soon be satisfactorily arranged between him and his chiefs.'}, {'id': 4990, 'article_title': 'LAGOS NEWS', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS NEWS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1885#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_01_1885', 'content': 'The selling price of agidy, or corn pudding, has been reduced from one to half string—i.e., from 40 to 20 cowries. The Porto Novians have been prohibited from buying farina or garry, rice, provision from Lagos. The King of Porto Novo has since prohibited his subjects from bringing bullocks, poultry, and all kinds of provision to Lagos.

A grand ball was given by Dr. McCarthy, the Colonial Surgeon, on Nov. 7th. The hall was splendidly decorated, and the guests included the chief inhabitants of Lagos, native and foreign.

There is a good deal of bitter feeling in Lagos still on account of the disputes between Ajassah, the ex-Apina, and Tiwo, and the action of Captain Barrow, the Deputy-Governor, in reference to this matter. Latest advices are to the effect that the Governor-in-Chief has requested to be supplied with more information regarding the alleged conspiracy affecting the security of the Government, for which Ajassah and others were exiled to Elmina without process of law—an act that the Governor-in-Chief and the Legislative Council at Accra found it needful to legalize by Ordinance No. 9 of 1884; and has ordered a careful search to be made for the arms and ammunition which they were charged with having secured in their premises preparatory to a general rising. The order was passed, and the Superintendent of Police, with a strong body of the constabulary and Houssas, made a raid on their premises some weeks ago, surprising the families of the deported men with the purport of their message, and commencing to search every nook and corner of the dwelling-places of the men in the different parts of Lagos; doors having keys were opened with them, and those without were burst open, till the small hours of the morning, when this expedition was rewarded with a big "find" of nothing, which was reported accordingly; messengers sped to and from persons who had preferred the charges, to hasten to Government House to substantiate them, and when they went there it was merely a repetition of what one told another.

The Lagos races took place on the 4th and 5th of November, with the usual success.

A meeting assembled at Banner Brothers and Co.'s establishment, Marina, on the 15th of November, when the subject of the separation of the settlement from the Gold Coast was reconsidered, and a deputation was named to wait on his Excellency the Governor-in-Chief, W. A. G. Young, on his arrival from Accra, on the subject. G. W. Neville, Esq., was chairman of the meeting.

A bazaar was opened in the lower rooms of the Wesleyan Girls' High School, on Tuesday, the 25th of November. The proceeds of the sale were given towards the Girls' High School.

The Melodramatic Society is to be transformed into the Lagos Isthmæan Club, to be composed of members ordinary and honorary. The aim of the club is to develop the physical as well as the mental resources of its members. A conversazione took place on the 5th ult. at the Phoenix Hall, given by the members of this society.'}, {'id': 5167, 'article_title': 'Memorial of the Inhabitants of Lagos to the Colonial Secretary', 'full_section_title': 'Memorial of the Inhabitants of Lagos to the Colonial Secretary', 'last_edit_date': '05-23-1885', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': "7. We further respectfully beg to point out to your Lordship that the revenue of Lagos has had a steady increase for the past few years, and this notwithstanding the serious drawbacks to commerce on account of the protracted warfare in the interior; and that this justifies and strengthens our request for a separation. The revenue of 1882 was £45,000, that of 1883 £50,000, and that of 1884 £58,000. Furthermore, Lagos had a reserved fund of £20,000, in the hands of Crown Agents, before the amalgamation scheme was set on foot. A sum of £10,000 should have been reserved at the end of 1883, and a further sum of £10,000 before the close of 1884, making £40,000, which is expected to be in the hands of Crown Agents in favour of Lagos. If this is absorbed into the revenue of the Gold Coast according to the present arrangement, we hesitate not to say that Lagos would derive no benefit from the revenue it raises, and to the full advantage of which it is entitled.

8. We may mention as one proof of the impracticability of the amalgamation scheme, the fact that the laws governing the tariff of both places are not identical, it being found, no doubt, by our rulers extremely difficult to make them so; for whilst the duty on spirits in Lagos is 6d. per gallon, that on the Gold Coast is 2s. 6d. per gallon; and whilst the cost of license to retail spirits in Lagos is £25 annually, that on the Gold Coast is £2; and whilst an auctioneer's license in Lagos costs from £25 to £26 10s., on the Gold Coast it is only £10.

9. We are not unmindful, however, of the unsteady and unreliable condition of the trade and revenue of Lagos through frequent misunderstanding with and among the surrounding tribes, some of them sometimes very serious; but such unsteadiness and unreliableness are common with other places on the Coast. We, however, believe that the warfare in the interior, which has been a serious injury and drawback to Lagos, and lost the interior countries on which Lagos absolutely depends for its commerce, since itself produces nothing, very many of their inhabitants might have been composed long ago if our Government had been more or less independent and the policy of non-intervention less rigid.

10. We beg leave, in connexion with the question of separation, to point out, to and urge upon your Lordship the desirability of a Council Board at Lagos, on which the people would be properly represented, for dealing with matters affect-
**TABULAR STATEMENT.—A.**

**STATEMENT** showing offices requiring alterations in their original annual estimated expenditure as per Lagos Estimates for 1883. Increase thereunto under the proposed new arrangement for a separate Government, with additional Offices and costs; against the £2,905 annually contributed to salaries of Officials, Gold Coast."}, {'id': 5381, 'article_title': 'LAGOS NEWS', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS NEWS', 'last_edit_date': '02-26-1886', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1886#article-13', 'issue_date': '01_05_1886', 'content': "On Friday, February 26th, there was a large gathering at the Customs Warehouse for the purpose of presenting an address to the Governor. The Warehouse was densely crowded, but very few of the audience could hear the address presented to Governor Moloney, which was read by Mr. W. E. Cole. The new King of Ijebu (one of the largest palm districts in the interior of Lagos) recently sent a message to Governor Moloney, ex-King Oyekan, the heir and successor to the late King Docemo of Lagos, and to the well-known Chief Daniel C. Taiwo, a successor to the King of Isheri (an oil river near Lagos). On March 1st, a very large number of persons arrived with a present of eight sheep to the Governor, four to ex-King Oyekan, and two to Chief Taiwo. The King sent the messengers to inform the Governor and others that he reigns as King, and that he wishes always to be on friendly terms with Her Majesty's Government, and that he also wishes that Governor Moloney, ex-King Oyekan, and Chief Taiwo to see that all the long-standing disputes be settled in Lagos; and as for himself, on that part of the country, he should use his influence to settle all the long-pending wars amongst the different tribes, so that there should be a good trade all over the interior, which would be to the interest of Lagos, its Government, and merchants. No doubt the Governor will consider this matter, and settle those disputes which cause so many unpleasantnesses among the community. Perhaps Chief Taiwo, if things had been left entirely with him since Sir Samuel Rowe and Governor Barrow were here last, would have settled the whole matter long since."}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The war was now brought into the more immediate neighbourhood of the settlements, and the result was, caravans of traders from Lagos were robbed, and carriers murdered in passing through the seat of war; representations made to the Governor resulted in appeals from him for redress to the Abbeokutan chiefs, who did not deny such excesses had occurred, but pleaded the disordered state of the country, and promised to make compensation when in their power. The Governor, not feeling satisfied with their reply, and believing that the war was being carried on by a retrograde minority of the people, threatened to bring the Egbas to reason by closing the road to Abbeokuta and preventing all trade between that place and Lagos. Further robberies on traders, and the prospect of an attack by the Dahomians on Abbeokuta, led the Governor to issue a proclamation recommending the Europeans residing there to leave the place, and eventually to carry out his threat of proclaiming a blockade of Abbeokuta; these proceedings were very displeasing to some of the inhabitants of Lagos, and were made the subject of complaint by the Church Missionary Society in England, who addressed a memorial on the subject to the Secretary of State for the Colonies, in which they urged that immediate measures should be taken for checking the policy of the Governor.

Now, without denying that exception might perhaps be taken to the language and style of the Governor's proclamations and communications to the native chiefs, and admitting that his policy may have been injurious to the Abbeokutan cause, it does not, therefore, follow that it was either improper or injudicious. In an interview with the acting Governor in 1863, the head chief of the Abbeokutans not only admitted that robbery and destruction of property were the natural results of war, but stated that it was their custom, under such circumstances, to destroy trade and property in order to recruit the army, and to drive the people to war, and that if they allowed trading there would be no soldiers. The statement goes far to support the opinion expressed by the Governor that the war was carried on for the satisfaction of a minority, and to justify him in believing that the best way to bring the chiefs to reason would be to stop their supplies from Lagos.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADING IN THE COLONY OF LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Liverpool Chamber of Commerce has received from the Colonial Secretary the following reply to a memorial to the African trade section, in reference to the trade in the Protectorate:—

Colonial Office, April 3, 1891.

Sir,—I am directed by Lord Knutsford to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th ult., forwarding a memorial of your Chamber on the subject of the condition of affairs in the Colony and Protectorate of Lagos. In reply, I am to inform you that the communications between Sir A. Moloney and the Lagos Chamber of Commerce, to which the memorial of your Chamber refers, have been transmitted to Lord Knutsford and have received his serious attention. They have also been communicated to Mr. Carter, the newly-appointed Governor of Lagos, and the suggestions will receive the earliest consideration as soon as possible after his arrival in the Colony. Lord Knutsford is fully alive to, and much regrets, the serious interruption of trade which is caused by the exactions of certain native chiefs and by the internecine warfare which is constantly carried on among the interior tribes. He is anxious that all expedient and possible means should be adopted to remedy the inconveniences complained of, but the situation is one of much delicacy and difficulty, and will require very careful and patient handling.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,', 'last_edit_date': '1891-04-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.654, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS, ABEOKUTA, AND IBADAN.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There is perhaps no other part of Africa in which a greater disposition exists to cultivate the soil for the purpose of exchanging the produce against foreign commodities than in the Yoruba countries, lying between the Lagos Lagoons and the river Niger. Before the annexation of Lagos to the British Crown, Abeokuta had become remarkable among the African countries for the great and rapid increase of its production and trade. Abeokuta was immeasurably the largest exporter of cotton in native Africa; her palm oil trade with Lagos was considerable, and other commerce prospered. With the annexation of Lagos to Great Britain, we looked naturally for a still greater increase of production and trade; and we have no doubt that such results would have been obtained but for the native wars, which have so interfered with agricultural pursuits, and the differences with Lagos on the part of the Egbas, which had their origin principally in those wars. In the comments we have from time to time made upon those wars and differences, we have regarded the former as in a great degree arising from

[DECEMBER 23, 1865.

---', 'last_edit_date': '1865-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MANUFACTURERS IN AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Mr. Alvan Millson, Assistant Colonial Secretary, Colony of Lagos, delivered an address in the Manchester Chamber of Commerce rooms on June 5th, on the Commerce and Industries of the Yoruba country. Mr. F. Zimmern, honorary secretary of the Manchester Geographical Society, presided, the lecture being under the society's auspices.

Mr. Millson said that although the enterprise of European merchants in the Niger had rectified the evil in so far as Ilorin and the interior were concerned, it was still the case that the powerful nation of Yoruba, with its 400,000 families of industrial cultivators of the soil, was hopelessly cut off in every direction from all but the most insignificant driblets of European trade. During the past fifteen years its northern frontier had been constantly harassed by the inroads of the Mohammedans, who had made Ilorin their centre of operations towards the south, and by that renewed pressure from the north the inhabitants of Yoruba had not only been cut off from their former sources of supplies in that direction, but had also been forced to submit to the exactions and commercial blockade of their weaker kinsmen who inhabit the neighbourhood of the Gulf lagoons. These tribes, with true African blindness to consequences, harassed in every way the Yorubas in their efforts to drive back the Fulah conquerers, curtailed their supply of guns and powder, upon which their safety depended, demanded exorbitant prices for such articles as they condescended to allow them to purchase, and to the best of their ability revenged themselves for former oppressions at their hands. Not only did they by this means endanger the safety of their own land, and diminish a trade which should be a source of prosperity to all, but they disregarded all former promises and friendly relations with the English, and inflicted a serious injury to our trade, by cutting us off from commercial intercourse with the most important market of West Africa. The continual wars led to slave catching, and the result was that the trade routes to the interior were, with few exceptions, closed to traffic, and it was more difficult for a trader to penetrate beyond the coast line than for a Mohammedan to traverse the desert of Sahara. The general insecurity of property on the borders of", 'last_edit_date': '1891-07-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_07_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Political Troubles on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British and African steamer Opobo, with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa, arrived at Liverpool a short time since. Health on the coast was still unsatisfactory, and trade dull. At Bonny and Opobo there had been no further hostility since the British Consul had held a "palaver," and both peoples were settling down to trade. At Salt Pond trade was at a standstill, owing to fighting going on a few miles from the coast. The trouble was between the tribes in the interior, those on the sea-coast, and the natives known as the "middlemen." Both parties were desirous of direct intercourse, which the "middlemen" natives were doing all they could to prevent. The effect was that business was stopped, and several encounters had taken place. The war in the Ashantee country showed no signs of abatement.

Affairs in the Cameroons are in a very unsatisfactory state. It is said that the natives have boycotted all the whites, and refused to trade with them or supply them with food. No white man can buy a fowl or a bullock, and the natives have barred the way to the fresh water, so that the whites have to depend upon rain for all the water they require. Large numbers of the factories up the river are closed, and the traders are sending their working staffs home. The natives are determined that the German Government shall derive no advantages from the port. They are paying up all the debts they owe to the white traders, but are doing no fresh business. The people on both sides of the river have joined together, and made common cause against the Government. They do not threaten, nor will they fight, but they will not work. Their houses as well as their plantations were all destroyed when the Germans bombarded the town, so that they have nothing to lose. The English traders have had an interview with the Vice-Consul and the German Governor, and unless some compromise is effected, it will only be a question of how long the traders will keep their factories open, as they are losing money daily.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1886#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Messrs. J. Irvine & Co.'s Palm Oil Report for November", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. The average prices in Europe of the more important native products have stood even lower than during the previous twelve months, while the prolonged continuance of low prices in Africa has apparently disheartened the native producer, and tended to diminish the quantity as well as the value of his out-turn. In Europe and America an improvement has, it is true, occurred in the prices of a few leading articles of commerce, but no sign of such revival extending to the products of West Africa has yet been vouchsafed; and, while it is not forbidden to hope for better things in 1888, it would be imprudent of our readers to base their calculations on any material rise in prices, or, indeed, not to make the necessary provisions for a possible—though, let us hope, improbable—further fall. While this condition of business is doubtless felt more or less even by the wealthy European merchants trading to West Africa, the most deplorable results of the depression occur in the colonial centres, such as Sierra Leone and Lagos. Great numbers of clerks and artisans, anxious for engagements as heretofore at various parts of the coast, are unable to obtain employment, or only at reduced rates of wages.

To these communities 1888 will probably bring good tidings. It has been stated, on apparently good authority, that early in the new year the so-called "oil rivers"—now under intermittent Consular jurisdiction—will be formed into a Colony. The experiences of Lagos and the Gold Coast enable us to predict, with tolerable certainty, the results which will follow from this policy. These valuable regions will be rapidly settled and opened up to trade. Hitherto, owing to the prevalence of the barter system, the unsettled condition of the tribes, and the absence of order and justice, only wealthy European houses have been able to make the necessary provisions.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Yet the Government is not alone to blame. Our merchants have frequently preferred to listen to the wild harangues of men whose exaggeration was patent to all, instead of paying attention to the estimates of those whose accuracy could not be questioned. Some have rushed into the African trade without knowledge or capital, and by ignorance and rashness have not only lost their own money, but have caused serious loss to firms who were working on a sound basis, but in consequence of the competition of mushroom adventurers, had to trade at a rate of exchange which barely paid expenses, and even to retain their connexion with those who took European manufactures in return for raw produce, at an actual loss. These remarks, of course, more especially apply to the trade with West Africa, but over the whole Continent, wherever the British merchant has a footing, he has had to contend with similar difficulties, and to put up with foreign competition carried on in a manner that scarcely savours of fair trade. Foreign competitors, wherever English influence is paramount, have the same privileges as themselves, but directly British protectorate or colony is quitted (except in the Oil Rivers and the Free Trade district of the Congo State) they have to compete with hostile tariffs and duties. In the early days of commerce the West Coast was a happy hunting ground for the merchant who did not much care whether his cargo consisted of gold dust, ivory, or slaves for the plantations in the Western Hemisphere. Many of the ships which visited the coast seemed to consider all that sailed under a foreign flag as fair prize, and even failed to recognize the friendship due to a fellow-countryman. Chartered companies were formed by different nations, which did their best to prevent their unlicensed competitors from encroaching on their privileges; and when war broke out between their respective countries, were quite ready to join in the conflict. These chartered companies made treaties with the natives, and built forts and stations which became emporia of trade. On the Gold Coast these forts succeeded each other in rapid succession. Hollanders, Brandenburghers, Danes, Portuguese, French, and English, all possessed strongholds, some of which are in use at the present day. The solidity of the masonry, the size and design of these fortresses, show the importance which the traders of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries attached to this West African trade. Slavery was rampant, and it is almost certain that without slave labour they would never have been constructed. A large portion of the trade was doubtless in slaves, but still that alone could never have accounted for the prosperity and wealth of the merchants who traded with Western Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.65, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL INTERESTS IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "commerce if carried by steamers. The demand for kola nuts was reported to be at all times considerable in Brazil, but in view of the slowness of the passage and the difficulty of keeping them in marketable condition, the value has at no time during the past six years exceeded £3,563, while in 1877 it sank as low as £304. Shea butter also, though exported to the value of £161 in 1883, sank in 1887 to £29. Among the imports from Brazil, the most important seem to be rum, cigars, and tobacco. The depressed state of trade in 1887 affected the branches of commerce upon which the colony depended; indeed, irregularity of communication has in the past given this trade a peculiarly unstable character. Placed on a firm basis, however, there would seem to be excellent prospects of a rapid development in the imports above mentioned, especially when it is considered that the market for imports from Brazil is already established in the colony of Lagos. These facts showed that it was worth while to consider the advisability of embarking upon this enterprise, and he took advantage of this opportunity to publish the facts he had put before them, which bore upon the subject, sincerely trusting that so important an opening for British trade would not be neglected. Another inducement for the establishment of steam communication between Brazil and West Africa was that the value of our possessions, in their work of development, must depend on their trade, which meant an open and settled interior. Cut them off from the interior, and they were cramped as regarded progress, and were occupied in struggling to meet the bare cost of administration; connect them with the interior and their future would be great and far-reaching. It had been questioned why West Africa had not made more progress in the march of civilisation. In the words of Sir Thomas Fowell Buxton it was slavery that debarred them from acquiring industries; it was slavery which prevented them from exercising the virtues of foresight and prudence; it was slavery which left them nothing to care for; it was slavery that took away from them all the incentives to industrious labour, and debarred them from all the ties of social intercourse. When we remember the small percentage of people that represents owners, we had to acknowledge that these causes still opposed development. Time alone would rehabilitate the negro in his manliness. Obstacles that blocked progress were the altered relationship between owner and former slave, the independence of the latter when compared with his former grovelling position, doubt of result or use of independence secured with abolition, doubt in minds of native authorities of consequence of any action they might initiate, non-existence of free labour markets, and inter-tribal differences, jealousies and feuds. The removal of such blocks had been and was the aim of the Government, and they were gradually disappearing. In primitive countries such as within and adjoining our West African colonies, it was the duty of the Government to initiate the capabilities of the country represented by its products. The people were industrious in their own fashion, and were ready to follow examples set, and to develop industries once they learn to appreciate their value. We wanted new staples of trade and larger areas of demand for our wares. Agricultural products must long continue the most important part of the exports from tropical Africa, and the future development of Africa's commerce would depend upon the improvement in the quantity and quality of existing agricultural staples, and on the introduction of new products, which should serve as materials for manufacture and for use in industrial arts.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Royal Mail steamer Axim, which arrived in the Mersey on Sept. 11, having left Accra on August 28, reported trade as in a very bad state, practically little or no produce coming down from the interior. This, it was stated, was owing to the district being raided by hostile tribes. There was a great deal of poverty in the interior in consequence of the unsettled state of the country, and some places were threatened with famine. Three hundred Hausa troops had left Accra for Elmina just before the Axim sailed, to be sent into the disturbed districts. The Princes John and Albert Ansah were at Cape Coast when the Axim passed. It was reported that they intended soon to visit England for the purpose of bringing their case before the British Parliament, and submitting a claim for wrongful arrest. The French hulk stationed at the port of Badagry is reported to have sunk in deep water, but all on board escaped to the shore. Within the last six years the Church Missionary Society had sent out to West Africa and the Niger about sixty missionaries, all of whom, in one way or another, have suffered severely from the climate: of these twelve had died and fourteen returned to England and would not be reckoned on again for service in Africa, for which only thirty-six were now available.

M. de Belarbre, writing from Sierra Leone to the Paris Débats, gives a startling account of the secret cannibal society, styled "The Human Leopards," which in the last 20 years has made hundreds of victims. The society was formed among the Imperi in the Isle of Sherbro, part of the colony of Sierra Leone. It originated in a desire for vengeance for the death of a troop of warriors, who while on an expedition were slaughtered by the Imperi. A sorcerer who was consulted devised a fetish called boffima, the owner of which would have all his wishes gratified. It is a tuber, the size of an ostrich's egg, which is hollowed out, filled with some secret mixture, and enveloped in leopard's hide. To retain its virtue it had to be occasionally greased with human fat. Every candidate for admission to the society undertook to inveigle some relative, slave, or neighbour, to a gathering, at which this stranger was murdered by a member wearing a leopard's hide, and the body was eaten. A few years ago the chiefs of the district formed a rival society for exterminating those cannibals, but innocent persons having been murdered through false denunciations, the English authorities put it down. As, however, the outrages then revived, a spy was induced to give information which led to the arrest of six "human leopards." One died in prison and the other five have been tried and hanged. The last cry of one of them was—"The leopards still exist."', 'last_edit_date': '1896-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This subject is (says the *Manchester Guardian*, in a series of excellent articles upon the present state of the West Coast of Africa, now under publication) a very wide one, the trade of Africa being carried on under such different conditions, by such different races, and the goods dealt in being so various, that it would seem difficult to bring all under one discussion; but, unfortunately, all the trade of Africa has one great point of similarity, and that is that all is depressed, and much is passing into the hands of foreign competitors. A Royal Commission has been appointed to inquire into the causes of depression in trade. The causes of the depression in African trade are not far to seek, and the remedies must be applied by the Government, and not by the merchants. The apathetic policy which has been pursued, the systematic ignoring of those who have knowledge and experience, and the entrusting of important interests to incompetent hands, have had the effects which were to be expected, and unless some decisive action is taken soon, we may expect our African trade to go from bad to worse, and be all transferred from London, Liverpool, and Bristol to Hamburg, Havre, and Marseilles.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'How Commerce Alone Civilizes', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The trade in palm oil in the Brass river is very considerable. The large Liverpool houses have been trading there in this article for many years, and many English agents' vessels and crews are continually in the river, yet in a letter in the *West African Herald* of May 20, we find the following in a letter dated River Brass. After stating that there are disagreements among the natives, he adds: "Several engagements have taken place, and many prisoners taken. A few days ago, nine or ten of these unfortunate 'Nungums' were taken prisoners, brought down the river, killed and eaten, and within a mile or so of us, the fact becoming known when too late to endeavour (were it possible) to prevent such a barbarous custom." No: there is no civilization for Africa without the light of Christianity.', 'last_edit_date': '1869-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1869#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. The average prices in Europe of the more important native products have stood even lower than during the previous twelve months, while the prolonged continuance of low prices in Africa has apparently disheartened the native producer, and tended to diminish the quantity as well as the value of his out-turn. In Europe and America an improvement has, it is true, occurred in the prices of a few leading articles of commerce, but no sign of such revival extending to the products of West Africa has yet been vouchsafed; and, while it is not forbidden to hope for better things in 1888, it would be imprudent of our readers to base their calculations on any material rise in prices, or, indeed, not to make the necessary provisions for a possible—though, let us hope, improbable—further fall. While this condition of business is doubtless felt more or less even by the wealthy European merchants trading to West Africa, the most deplorable results of the depression occur in the colonial centres, such as Sierra Leone and Lagos. Great numbers of clerks and artisans, anxious for engagements as heretofore at various parts of the coast, are unable to obtain employment, or only at reduced rates of wages.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Latest from Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. The average prices in Europe of the more important native products have stood even lower than during the previous twelve months, while the prolonged continuance of low prices in Africa has apparently disheartened the native producer, and tended to diminish the quantity as well as the value of his out-turn. In Europe and America an improvement has, it is true, occurred in the prices of a few leading articles of commerce, but no sign of such revival extending to the products of West Africa has yet been vouchsafed; and, while it is not forbidden to hope for better things in 1888, it would be imprudent of our readers to base their calculations on any material rise in prices, or, indeed, not to make the necessary provisions for a possible—though, let us hope, improbable—further fall. While this condition of business is doubtless felt more or less even by the wealthy European merchants trading to West Africa, the most deplorable results of the depression occur in the colonial centres, such as Sierra Leone and Lagos. Great numbers of clerks and artisans, anxious for engagements as heretofore at various parts of the coast, are unable to obtain employment, or only at reduced rates of wages.

To these communities 1888 will probably bring good tidings. It has been stated, on apparently good authority, that early in the new year the so-called "oil rivers"—now under intermittent Consular jurisdiction—will be formed into a Colony. The experiences of Lagos and the Gold Coast enable us to predict, with tolerable certainty, the results which will follow from this policy. These valuable regions will be rapidly settled and opened up to trade. Hitherto, owing to the prevalence of the barter system, the unsettled condition of the tribes, and the absence of order and justice, only wealthy European houses have been able to make the necessary provisions.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Arabs on Lake Nyassa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The serious part of the intelligence is the evidence which is afforded of the increasing audacity and violence of the Arab traders throughout Central Africa. The increase of Arab power in Central Africa, and enormous growth of slave-hunting and the slave traffic in consequence, are notorious. The German traveller, Lieut. Wissmann, found extensive districts depopulated and burned by the Arabs in the Kassai and Sankaru regions. Then there has been the attack on the Stanley Falls Station. The wave of reviving Arab power which has been spreading westward from the Zanzibar coast is now, it appears, spreading southward also. The first impulse to this extension is said to date from the end of 1883, when for a time our policy of armed intervention on the coast was changed. Every Arab on the coast appears to have regarded this change as an indication that our opposition to the trade had been abandoned. The recent agreement between Germany and Portugal for the division of the country as far as Nyassa, and the limitation of the Sultan of Zanzibar's influence to a coast-zone ten miles wide, have probably also stimulated the Sultan to endeavour to extend his influence to the west beyond the regions claimed by Germany. Arab camps are being placed at commanding points on the slave-routes, and Arabs visit and settle in the villages of the more powerful of the native chiefs. In short, there appears to be evidence that the disturbances on the Tanganyika and Nyassa, and it may be at Stanley Falls, are not due merely to the turbulence of isolated Arab ivory and slave hunters, but are parts of something like a concerted movement. The suggestion certainly seems to throw a new light on the action or inaction of Tippoo Tib at Stanley Falls, and on the appearance of Arabs west of the Aruwimi on the Welle-Makua.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1888#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial trade in Africa was fraught with tensions, misunderstandings, and legal disputes due to conflicting economic interests, complex regulations, and inefficient practices.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively provide a comprehensive view that supports the claim that colonial trade in Africa was fraught with tensions, misunderstandings, and legal disputes due to conflicting economic interests, complex regulations, and inefficient practices. The textbook details how Europeans manipulated trade agreements to weaken African economies and rulers, imposed one-sided debt collection agreements, and established international debt commissions in Egypt and Tunisia. It also highlights collective actions by African producers, such as the cocoa hold-ups in the Gold Coast, in response to the monopoly control of expatriate firms and marketing inefficiencies. The exploitation of African producers by monopolistic merchant firms, the unequal exchange between the colonial economy and the metropolises, and the neglect of industrialization and local crafts further illustrate the economic conflicts and regulatory complexities. Additionally, the commercialization of land and the imposition of colonial economic relations led to legal and social tensions. Complementing these observations, The African Times articles report on trade disruptions and legal conflicts, such as the interruption of trade between Lagos and Abeokuta due to robbery and the seizure of gin by customs authorities in Lagos, which merchants deemed unjustifiable. Legal disputes like Harris v. Isaac, involving allegations of malicious arrest related to business transactions, and dissatisfaction with the Royal Niger Company's monopoly, highlight the challenges faced by traders. The articles also discuss the inefficiencies in customs practices that damaged goods and the tensions between native traders and European merchants, exacerbated by colonial policies affecting trade routes and local economies. Together, these sources illustrate the multifaceted challenges and disputes that characterized trade in colonial Africa.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that support the claim that colonial trade in Africa was fraught with tensions, misunderstandings, and legal disputes due to conflicting economic interests, complex regulations, and inefficient practices. The text highlights the manipulation of trade agreements by Europeans to weaken African economies and rulers, the imposition of one-sided debt collection agreements, and the forced establishment of international debt commissions in Egypt and Tunisia. It also describes collective actions by African producers, such as the cocoa hold-ups in the Gold Coast, which were responses to the monopoly control of expatriate firms and the inefficiencies in the marketing system. The text further discusses the exploitation of African producers by monopolistic merchant firms and intermediaries, the unequal exchange between the colonial economy and the metropolises, and the neglect of industrialization and local crafts. Additionally, it mentions the legal and social tensions arising from the commercialization of land and the imposition of colonial economic relations. These details align with the claim by illustrating the economic conflicts, regulatory complexities, and inefficiencies that characterized colonial trade in Africa.
tat: The African Times news articles provide numerous details that support the claim that colonial trade in Africa was fraught with tensions, misunderstandings, and legal disputes due to conflicting economic interests, complex regulations, and inefficient practices. The articles highlight several instances of trade disruptions and legal conflicts, such as the interruption of trade between Lagos and Abeokuta due to robbery and the seizure of gin by customs authorities in Lagos, which was deemed unjustifiable by the merchants. There are also accounts of legal disputes, such as the case of Harris v. Isaac, which involved allegations of malicious arrest related to business transactions on the West Coast of Africa. Additionally, the articles discuss the dissatisfaction of merchants with the Royal Niger Company's monopoly, the challenges faced by British traders due to foreign competition, and the inefficiencies in customs practices that damaged goods. The tensions between native traders and European merchants, as well as the impact of colonial policies on trade routes and local economies, further illustrate the complexities and conflicts inherent in colonial trade. These examples align with the claim by demonstrating the multifaceted challenges and disputes that characterized trade in colonial Africa.
