[{'id': 54, 'article_title': 'LAGOS', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1862#article-8', 'issue_date': '23_12_1862', 'content': 'We are sorry to be obliged to state that the trade communications between this place and Abeokuta have been interrupted during an entire month—viz., from October 7 to November 6. On the former day a considerable robbery with violence was committed on the river. A number of canoes, going up from this place for Abeokuta, laden with valuable produce, were attacked and taken by some of the warriors from the Abeokuta camp. All the efforts and demands made by the merchants to obtain a restitution of their stolen property have been fruitless. The chief authorities have promised that the merchants shall be repaid "after the war;" stating that they are unable to take any effective measures for recovering the property now, as "it would interrupt the progress of the war, and might lead to discord."

The merchants are, with reason, far from being satisfied; but, nevertheless, trade has recommenced.

Her Majesty's ship Investigator struck on the bar when coming in on November 26. Guns were fired at intervals during the day, and it was feared she would have to be abandoned; but she was towed off late in the day by the Advance merchant steamer (Mr. M'Corsky's).

Great complaints are made by the merchants as to the arrangements for vessels crossing the bar.'}, {'id': 1429, 'article_title': 'The Great Gin Seizure in Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'The Great Gin Seizure in Lagos', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1868#article-13', 'issue_date': '23_10_1868', 'content': "At the beginning of July 1867, the Custom authorities at Lagos, seized 3,752 cases of gin on board the French ship Conception, at Lagos, for an alleged infraction of the Customs laws of that port.

We have now been informed that, by command of Her Majesty's Government, the produce of the sale of the said gin, which was sold by auction, has been paid to the owners—viz., 1,033l. We have not time at present to enter upon the particulars of this seizure, which seems to us to have been totally unjustifiable, and which has inflicted a loss of at least 700l. on the owners; but we hope to be able to do so in our next number."}, {'id': 1498, 'article_title': 'COURT OF COMMON PLEAS.—Dec. 5.', 'full_section_title': 'COURT OF COMMON PLEAS.—Dec. 5.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1868#article-25', 'issue_date': '23_12_1868', 'content': "Sittings at Nisi Prius in Middlesex.—(Before Lord Chief Justice Bovill and a Special Jury.)

**HARRIS v. ISAAC AND ANOTHER.**

The plaintiff has been for many years engaged in trade upon the West Coast of Africa, and for the last seven years he has had business transactions with the defendants, Messrs. Isaac, Campbell, and Co. In September, 1867, he came to England, and two months afterwards he was arrested upon a *ca. sa.*, at the suit of the defendants, for £6,885. The affidavit upon which the judge issued the capias stated that there was reason to believe that the plaintiff was about to return to Africa. The present action was to recover damages upon the ground that the defendants had maliciously caused the plaintiff to be arrested, the plaintiff's case being that he had no present intention of returning to Africa.

Mr. D. Keane, Q.C., and Mr. H. James appeared for the plaintiff, and Mr. Hawkins, Q.C., and Mr. Cohen for the defendants.

In the course of the case it appeared that there were proceedings in the Court of Chancery, in which the accounts between the parties were to be investigated, and, further, that the present case must depend to a great extent upon the result of the accounts.

Under these circumstances his lordship interposed, and it was agreed that the whole of the matters in difference should be referred to the arbitration of Mr. J. J. Powell, Q.C."}, {'id': 1509, 'article_title': 'ACCRA—PAINFUL AND DISTRESSING SUICIDE.', 'full_section_title': 'ACCRA—PAINFUL AND DISTRESSING SUICIDE.', 'last_edit_date': '02-06-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1869#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_03_1869', 'content': 'It may appear strange and almost incredible that men engaged in mercantile pursuits for a number of years, as our native traders here, could be induced to affix their signatures to documents the purport of which they are but imperfectly acquainted with, but I declare unhesitatingly that such is the fact, and with your permission I shall furnish you with a glaring instance in support of this statement in another letter.

I enclose you the summons which was served upon the poor young man for your information.

If there are any misstatements in this letter, I alone am responsible for them; and if any person whose name is mentioned here deems it worth his while to seek for an explanation of anything herein written, he can do so from your obedient servant,'}, {'id': 1604, 'article_title': 'SIERRA LEONE', 'full_section_title': 'SIERRA LEONE', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1869#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_08_1869', 'content': "We have received complaints of rough usage to goods landed from England, on the part of the Customs' examiners, so that goods are often greatly damaged by them; and we feel sure that it is only necessary to call the attention of the superior authorities to this abuse of power to ensure its discontinuance.

Sirius, 6, screw sloop, recently commissioned at Portsmouth by Captain D. Miller for the West Coast of Africa and the Cape of Good Hope, went out of the harbour and anchored at Spithead on Monday, August 2, and was tried at the measured mile on Friday, the 6th, and had her six hours trial at sea the following week. The Sirius was built at Portsmouth Dockyard, and was launched on the 24th of April, 1868."}, {'id': 1605, 'article_title': 'Equities of Cape Coast Government', 'full_section_title': 'Equities of Cape Coast Government', 'last_edit_date': '08-23-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1869#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_08_1869', 'content': "Customs-office, Cape Coast, April 26, 1869.

Sir,—I have the honour to inform you that two packages bearing your address, and landed by you on the 25th instant ex S.S. Congo, have been seized for a breach of the Gold Coast Customs Ordinance, No. 3, 1867.—I have, &c.,  
THOMAS JONES, Dy. Collector of Customs.

To Mr. W. C. Finlayson.

Customs-office, Cape Coast, 27th April, 1869.

Sir,—Referring to my letter of yesterday, and the conversation I had with you, I have to intimate to you that on inquiry there appears a great discrepancy between your statement and that of the chief landing waiter, who asserts that he gave you no permission to land any packages in the Government canoe.

I have, therefore, the honour to inform you that the two packages are still seized by this department, and that in due course I shall prosecute you for a breach of the Gold Coast Customs Ordinance.

If you have any statement or explanation to make, you will please do so in writing, and it shall have my best consideration.  
—I have, &c.,  
THOMAS JONES.

Mr. W. C. Finlayson.

Hamilton House, Cape Coast, 27th April, 1869.

Sir,—I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of this day's date, and in reply I beg respectfully to state that I have not committed a breach of the Customs regulations.

The two boxes seized by you are not my property, I know nothing about them, and when I saw Mr. Hagan, the landing waiter, on board the steamship Congo, I asked him to take possession of them in the Colonial boat.

On my arrival some time after, I notified to the second landing waiter that I was not aware what was in the boxes, or who was the owner, and requested him to keep them until the real owner turned up. I did this to rid myself of all responsibility, and that the Customs regulations should not be invaded.

I am sure you will see at once that I had nothing to do with the boxes, and the very fact of my handing them over to the landing waiter on board is more than a sufficient proof that I acted in the only way that I could under the peculiar circumstances of the case.

Trusting that this explanation will be satisfactory, and that you will be pleased to hold the boxes until the owner is known,  
I have, &c.,  
WM. CHAS. FINLAYSON.

Thomas Jones, Esq., Dep. Collector of Customs.

Cape Coast, 5th May, 1869.

Sir,—I have the honour respectfully to lay before your Excellency the following statement relative to the seizure of two boxes by the Deputy Collector of Customs on the 25th ult."}, {'id': 4371, 'article_title': 'COMMENTS ON A MEMORIAL TO EARL KIMBERLEY BY "BATHURST MERCHANTS."', 'full_section_title': 'COMMENTS ON A MEMORIAL TO EARL KIMBERLEY BY "BATHURST MERCHANTS."', 'last_edit_date': '01-10-1882', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1882#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_02_1882', 'content': 'Sir,—A very remarkable document, in the shape of a memorial, emanating from merchants at Bathurst, was forwarded by the last mail steamer to Sierra Leone for transmission to the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for the Colonies, on the matter of the imprisonment of impecunious debtors. This document, copy of which we forward you herewith, contains sixteen signatures, only three of which are those of representatives of English houses. The rest represent French firms, inclusive of two European gentlemen about town of no well-defined status in the community, and three native traders, whose names are tagged to the tail of the memorial, we suppose, as a make-weight. There is not a shadow of reasoning in the entire document that would convince the most shallow mind of its necessity. Bathurst merchants in general are not remarkable for liberal and philanthropic ideas, but one would suppose that when they formed an iniquitous compact to compromise the social interests of the native traders they had a fair show of convincing argument based upon sound principles to offer in proof of their point, instead of a conglomeration of ill-digested statements, such as are contained in the memorial before us.

The memorial opens with a prayer for protection from fraudulent debtors, and the very humane wish that Earl Kimberley would sanction the opening of the gaol gates once more, in order that "debtors of an unfortunate class" might find a home. Perhaps the engrossing pursuits of trade do not leave much leisure to the memorialists to make themselves conversant with the local laws.
**15**

by which they are governed. They may perhaps be surprised to know that the "Criminal Amendment Ordinance, 1852" which is still in force in the settlement, offers them the very protection they seek against fraudulent debtors. It is therein enacted that a "trader who shall conceal, detain, or otherwise fraudulently dispose of the property of his employer entrusted to him for the purposes of his trade, or who shall neglect and refuse to account to his employer for such property, or any part thereof, or for its equivalent in value, such trader shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be liable to imprisonment for any period not exceeding two years at the discretion of the Court." If the memorialists were not blinded by an excess of zeal worthy of a better cause, they would have spared themselves the humiliation of subscribing to a memorial so discreditable to their heads and hearts by simply referring to the laws of the country.'}, {'id': 4506, 'article_title': 'MR. T. F. J. QUIN'S REPLY TO "LYNX."', 'full_section_title': 'MR. T. F. J. QUIN'S REPLY TO "LYNX."', 'last_edit_date': '10-07-1882', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_11_1882', 'content': '

supplied by Maurel Frères and his own capital, which capital he had raised in the Senegal by selling a large cutter he had owned there in order to enter into the Gambia trade. As for the unlimited abuse of the whole Bathurst jury I shall simply say his abuse, like the banning of the Archbishop of Rheims, will not make anybody one penny the worse. The next part of his letter is a groan over the sinner, as Sam Weller's "Shepherd" would say; but this only proves that he adds hypocrisy to the best of his perfections, for if he felt any kindly feelings at all for Owens why judge him before his trial? He goes on to say "the particular acts of theft charged against him were undoubtedly proved." I want to know how this can be when the judge clearly said in his charge to us jurymen, that one of the two charges—namely, the second—could not legally be maintained, and that we must try him only on the first charge, which was for the theft or embezzlement of 8 tons 8 cwt. of nuts. Mr. Owens was not ably defended. Mr. Morris his lawyer has, I believe, only lately been admitted as an attorney on the Coast, and is therefore no match for Mr. Walcott, barrister-at-law of Grays Inn; and a clever lawyer who was present at the whole trial, told me that he would have had no difficulty in clearing Mr. Owens if he had been retained, and probably this will be shown when the case comes on again for trial before an English judge and clever lawyers. "Lynx" does not understand why I took it upon myself to ask questions in reply. It was my duty to ask the judge to put questions which my fellow jurors wanted to have put, and most of the questions I did ask I was directed to do by them. The questions I asked on my own account were asked to make clear in my brains the chief points from which I drew my conclusions and which Mr. Walcott tried in a masterly way to muddle and slur over, Mr. Morris's great deficiency, as cross-examining counsel, making this doubly necessary. This was my right, and if I had not done it I should have gone out of the box with no clear conception of the case. As regards the fiction he indulges in about my fellow jurymen remonstrating with me, I reply it is a gratuitous invention; and as for the extraordinary speech he alleges I made, I give you my word of honour not one syllable of it came out of my lips. The judge summed up dead against Mr. Owens, but only on the first charge; and in summing up the facts that led to his conclusion on that charge he quite forgot a material fact which, I have heard asserted, would have made the whole case no longer legally tenable. My procedure as foreman of the jury next gives "Lynx" trouble, but it was quite different to his idea of it. After we were seated I called on the jurors, as is the rule, by name, beginning with the youngest, to give his verdict, which I recorded as given; and then, when I saw we disagreed, I proceeded calmly to open the debate by stating my reasons for believing Mr. Owens to be innocent. A clamour then began and continued, which prevented further argument.'}, {'id': 4506, 'article_title': 'MR. T. F. J. QUIN'S REPLY TO "LYNX."', 'full_section_title': 'MR. T. F. J. QUIN'S REPLY TO "LYNX."', 'last_edit_date': '10-07-1882', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_11_1882', 'content': '

The same night my illegitimate half-brother, Michael Quin, came to my house, and, in the presence of Mr. John Fenden, fully agreed with me that Owens was innocent. How he came to change his opinion is no affair of mine. As regards the bit of bombast "Lynx" adds, if anyone had the cheek to threaten me with such a penalty for acting according to my conscience I should have laughed at him. "He was told if he acted so and perjured himself no respectable man would speak to him or have any intercourse with him." Since this trial, instead of no respectable man speaking to me, His Excellency has been pleased to appoint me Sanitary Commissioner, a complimentary office only conferred on respectable men. The leading native gentlemen have recommended His Excellency the Governor to appoint me the mayor for the town—a kind of official medium between them and the Government; and so with the respect and friendly regard of His Excellency, the Administrator, and of the good men of the town, I will try to bear the hardship of "Lynx" not speaking to me, or having any intercourse with me. But as "Lynx" has accused me of all kinds of bad motives for acquitting Mr. Owens, measuring me I presume by his own bushel, I will give my reasons. The two charges against Mr. Owens were: first, for stealing 8 tons 8 cwt. of nuts, or embezzling the same; second, for stealing 15 tons of nuts or embezzling the same. The second charge was dealt with by the judge who told us it was legally untenable, because agreed value at M'Carthy rates was given for the nuts, and delivery of the nuts was made to Mamadoo in the river; besides, the nuts were never Verminck's property. Mamadoo proving the nuts to be bought from property put in the hands of Verminck's trader to sell, in order to give him the appearance of doing business while he collected Verminck's debts, and that the nuts received did not fully pay this property by $120, and S. F. Owens did not directly or indirectly benefit by Mamadoo's business. In this view I fully coincide. But on the first charge we disagreed, the judge being of opinion that Mr. Owens was guilty. The issue was—Did Owens really borrow the 8 tons 8 cwt. of nuts for account of his brother, or was it a plea put in after to cover his crime, and had he the right to lend people Verminck's nuts? It came out in evidence, if he were agent he would have the right by custom to borrow and lend nuts to respectable persons to keep up cordial relations when it was convenient and safe. It came out also that the agent at Bathurst made Mr. Owens believe he was agent in order to do his work well, and wrote him to that effect. So for my part, judging for the truth only, with no man's fear or favour in view, I felt convinced Owens really thought and was led to believe that he was agent, and believed he had power to lend nuts and borrow nuts if needs be, provided he ran no risks; and from the evidence I gathered that he did bona fide lend the nuts to accommodate his half-brother's business, which at that particular time he was managing in the absence of his half-brother; that the intention was evidently to accommodate the half-brother's business, but as he made no gain or benefit to himself in helping his half-brother, no loss to Verminck, and returned them within fourteen days in a better quality of nuts and before anyone knew or asked him about them. I must say I do not believe he ever had the intention of stealing them, which is the whole sum of the charge. The only point against Mr. Owens was, why he did not charge the loan in the books. The answer to this is, he charged his stock with the nuts, and thus charged himself with them in the books, for he was responsible for the stock. Why he did not pass the transaction through the books he explains by saying, "I did do so in my private memo. book and diary, but did not extend it into the house-books, because I only intended the loan to be for a short time, and did not want a lot of queries about it from my chief at Bathurst, who was quarrelsome." Now, I believe this explanation, and it would require some good grounds for me to think that a man who has lived half his life in this colony in good credit and repute, who has married and got children, and is the centre of a large circle of relatives and friends, and who is worth property, would suddenly change his nature and steal for another 8 tons 8 cwt. of nuts, a value of about 33l. In my mind the whole charge comes to a cashier lending cash to a customer to whom he is permitted to lend it, and only making a private entry, because it will be only for a few hours. Such an act in my mind is not criminal. Others may think differently from me, as, for instance, "Lynx;" but if all that think differently from me are of the "Lynx" turn of mind, I will be contented to think differently from them all my life.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant, THOMAS F. J. QUIN.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'The Niger Trouble', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At a recent meeting of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, the following resolution was carried: "That the members of the African Trade Section are of opinion that the charter granted to the Royal Niger Company, Limited, constitutes a virtual monopoly of the trade of the Niger district, thereby affecting prejudicially British interests in the adjoining rivers. The charter was obtained on the statement that all other European interests in that district had been bought up, which is not the case, and the members of the section are therefore of opinion that the charter should be revoked." It was further resolved that the Council of the Chamber should be asked to adopt the resolution and forward copies of it to certain members of the Government, members of Parliament, and Chambers of Commerce.

A letter from the Colonial Office relating to the administration of the Gold Coast was read. In it Sir H. Holland stated that the Government had consented that the Sefwhi country should on certain conditions be included in the British Protectorate, and he trusted that this action, together with the appointment of Captain Lonsdale as a Commissioner to visit the native tribes, will conduce to a reopening of the roads and an improvement and development of trade.

The *Liverpool Courier* has published the correspondence between Mr. W. F. Lawrence, M.P. for the Abercornby Division, and the Foreign Office on this burning subject.

In a subsequent issue of the *Courier*, a correspondent, signing himself "African Merchant," points out that "one passage in the Foreign Office letter of 27th January last is deserving of special attention—viz., a return to the old system is 'impracticable, even if it were desirable.' Such a declaration is astounding, and an outrage upon common sense. What are the facts? A company not long in existence has been granted sovereign rights and taxing powers over the imports and exports of from five to eight millions of people, and no company trading for its own benefit can exercise such powers in an impartial manner. Powers such as these can only be properly used by an independently-organized body, altogether unconnected with trade. Probably the Government having negotiated treaties with countries up the Niger, were glad to transfer their responsibility to the first who asked for it. Nominally there was to be no monopoly, but practically the greater number of traders are entirely debarred from doing business, and instead of there being free trade, open to all comers, the trade is absolutely shut up. Civilization is not promoted, but thrown back for an indefinite period of time.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1887#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE WITH THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. J. F. Hutton said that for years past the Manchester Chamber of Commerce had been in correspondence with the Colonial Office in reference to the West Coast of Africa, and had constantly called attention to the neglect of the authorities to attend to the interests of our trade, and to the responsibilities that ought to be undertaken in connexion with it. This trade especially concerned Manchester and the district around, because the bulk of the goods that went to the West Coast were cotton goods. For that reason, the Manchester Chamber of Commerce felt greatly interested in this question, and they asked the Government to consider whether they could not accept a greater amount of responsibility, not only as regarded the merchants, but also as regarded the natives in the interior. This country held possession of a mere fringe of the coast; but the goods that passed up the river were taxed, and merchants got no protection for their trade in return. The policy of the Colonial Office deterred merchants from going into the interior, and disheartened them. They had been urged, and in fact warned, not to go into the interior. The result was that our trade had fallen off considerably. He considered that the cause of this decline was, in a great measure, the absence of that order and responsibility that ought to exist on the coast of Africa. Complaints had been made of internal wars. These wars were continually arising among the tribes, and in some cases merchants had been ruined. A substantial duty was levied on goods passing along the Gambia, and the protection accorded in return was most inadequate. The case of Gambia was, perhaps, the worst of the class. It had been troubled by wars and robberies to such an extent that trade was almost ruined, and there was scarcely a merchant left of any position. The trade of the district was gradually passing into the hands of the French, from the want of activity and determination on the part of the British authorities. The British traders were being taxed without getting any adequate protection in return. The merchants had no representative on the Council. It was true there were...', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Yet the Government is not alone to blame. Our merchants have frequently preferred to listen to the wild harangues of men whose exaggeration was patent to all, instead of paying attention to the estimates of those whose accuracy could not be questioned. Some have rushed into the African trade without knowledge or capital, and by ignorance and rashness have not only lost their own money, but have caused serious loss to firms who were working on a sound basis, but in consequence of the competition of mushroom adventurers, had to trade at a rate of exchange which barely paid expenses, and even to retain their connexion with those who took European manufactures in return for raw produce, at an actual loss. These remarks, of course, more especially apply to the trade with West Africa, but over the whole Continent, wherever the British merchant has a footing, he has had to contend with similar difficulties, and to put up with foreign competition carried on in a manner that scarcely savours of fair trade. Foreign competitors, wherever English influence is paramount, have the same privileges as themselves, but directly British protectorate or colony is quitted (except in the Oil Rivers and the Free Trade district of the Congo State) they have to compete with hostile tariffs and duties. In the early days of commerce the West Coast was a happy hunting ground for the merchant who did not much care whether his cargo consisted of gold dust, ivory, or slaves for the plantations in the Western Hemisphere. Many of the ships which visited the coast seemed to consider all that sailed under a foreign flag as fair prize, and even failed to recognize the friendship due to a fellow-countryman. Chartered companies were formed by different nations, which did their best to prevent their unlicensed competitors from encroaching on their privileges; and when war broke out between their respective countries, were quite ready to join in the conflict. These chartered companies made treaties with the natives, and built forts and stations which became emporia of trade. On the Gold Coast these forts succeeded each other in rapid succession. Hollanders, Brandenburghers, Danes, Portuguese, French, and English, all possessed strongholds, some of which are in use at the present day. The solidity of the masonry, the size and design of these fortresses, show the importance which the traders of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries attached to this West African trade. Slavery was rampant, and it is almost certain that without slave labour they would never have been constructed. A large portion of the trade was doubtless in slaves, but still that alone could never have accounted for the prosperity and wealth of the merchants who traded with Western Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Some Minor Trading Stations on the West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We may now take up the consideration of another portion of Africa, one which till lately was considered as being peculiarly under British influence, and as places where British trade need fear no competition—the Oil Rivers. Unfortunately, the traders and merchants considered that the independence of the chiefs was more for their benefit than the establishment of British rule; that the influence of the British Consul, backed up by an occasional gunboat, was sufficient to prevent any serious difficulties; and that the treaties with the chiefs secured trade on profitable and equitable terms.

Under the old régime large fortunes were made, but competition has now much reduced the profits, while German and French annexations have closed some districts to Englishmen and seriously injured their interests in others. In the days that were gone, the courts of equity, formed of the principal merchants, used, with the assistance of the British Consul or the captain of a man-of-war, to smooth all local disputes, settle prices, and generally make regulations for the conduct of trade. Whilst all the merchants were English this system acted very well, although no doubt at times considerable difficulties arose.

Foreign competition has sprung up now to a very considerable extent, most of it being in the hands of Germans, and the way that the trade has passed into their hands is not creditable to the foresight or patriotism of English merchants. Even when trade was conducted at more remunerative rates than at present, the scale of pay to clerks and subordinates was not sufficiently high to induce men of education and standing to face the risks of the African climate, and separate themselves from their families and the comforts of civilization for lengthened periods; and in consequence, among those who went to the coast, there were some men whose ideas of commercial morality were at a very low ebb.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letters to the Editor: The Arrest of King Ja Ja', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'SIR,—I note in some of the daily newspapers an announcement of the arrest of King Ja Ja, of Opobo, West Africa, by the British Consul, on account of his disregard of certain trade obligations. As matters have come to such a crisis, perhaps you will allow me to lay before your readers some details of the whole matter in dispute, by which they may be better able to judge whether such arrest was really justified by the facts.

After the famous Berlin Conference of 1884, it was arranged by the British authorities that some one should be sent out to the Oil Rivers to proclaim a Protectorate on behalf of Great Britain over the whole district; and accordingly a gentleman was sent out as Consul, who was empowered to sign a treaty with the native kings and chiefs of the various places, of which Opobo, where Ja Ja is King, was one. One of the conditions of the treaty which Ja Ja signed (Article 6) expressly prohibited strangers going to the interior markets; this condition being further substantiated by a letter from the Consul to Ja Ja; the effect and intention of this being to secure that the European agents should only obtain their goods from the interior through Ja Ja and his chiefs.

About two years ago, owing to the depression in the oil trade, some of these agents agreed among themselves that the price of the oil and other native productions should be reduced; and Ja Ja accordingly was communicated with upon the subject, and he expressed his readiness to accept their terms; but that the "topside" (a general term among the traders there, meaning commission) should be allowed to him and his chiefs, as before. This the agents would not agree to; they were willing to continue the usual topside to Ja Ja himself, but not to his chiefs. Ja Ja remonstrated with them, and pointed out that Opobo was made by himself and his chiefs. Immediately a white flag was hoisted in five of the factories, which meant that they stop all further business with the natives. One of the firms concerned refused to agree to this suspension, and continued to trade as before.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1887#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.69, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Deputation to Lord Knutsford', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"As regards the colony of Gambia, it was but natural that British traders would object to give their colony and trade to France for what the French possessed between Pongas river and the Gaboon, as the French had only the Assinie and Porto Novo territory, both of little value. Besides, they expected our own people would keep the hinterland of the Gambia and not let the French hem them in. Again, if the exchange had been made, it would not have prevented the French getting behind us at Sierra Leone, the inland territory not being between the places named.

"Then there is the Tabou territory on the Kroo coast. The real ruler of this place is an Englishman who has lived there for twenty years, and holds deeds of ownership of the land. This gentleman called at the Colonial Office years ago with the documents in question, and besought the authorities to take over the country. They refused, and when the matter was again brought up by the recent deputation they were told that the territory had been taken over by France.

"Something of the same kind took place as regards the island of Matacong. At present it is owned by an Englishman, leased by an Englishman, and the owner was told the other day by Lord Knutsford that it was French territory.

"You cite Liberia in your article as a place where a profitable trade may yet be done. Well, this is a poor solace. It is not creditable to a Government that its subjects should have to give up trading in its settlements and go into the colony of a neighbouring Government to make a living.

"There is also the question of the Gold Coast settlement. We have not the assurance that the hinterland there has been secured to us. On the contrary, what may we not fear from the mission of M. Binger? Look what France is doing in West Africa. Railways at Konakry and St. Louis, spending £250,000 on a pier at Kotonu, near Lagos; all this apart from her numerous expeditions.

"After all, the sum total of the whole question is this. We have a coast colony, and to feed that colony we should have the inland trade. The territory whence emanates this trade is suddenly taken away from our influence by a country whose interest is to divert it to its own colonies. We cannot get the inland territory under our own influence again, and our coast colony may become a seaport without a trade. What steps can we take to nullify the effect of the change and bring back the trade to the colony? Hitherto the Government has been looked up to for guidance, protection, and direction, but, in view of the interests which have been recently sacrificed, the African trade is determined to speak out unmistakably for itself in future, whatever Government may be in power.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-01-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Trading Troubles in Western Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'To a palaver on board his gunboat all the chiefs were recently summoned by the English Consul, who said he regretted deeply to see the state into which the country had fallen, the want of unity that existed amongst the chiefs and people, and the general lawlessness that prevailed. He said he was ready to hear any complaints and suggestions that might be made and invited the various chiefs to speak out their minds fully, frankly, and freely. Possibly, when the Consul did this, he hardly knew what was in store for him, and what a wide field he had opened up, because ever since he has been sitting *de die in diem*. Complaints and mutual recriminations have been rife, allegations have been freely preferred, and often as frankly admitted, of the most horrible crimes, and the proceedings have been a record generally of murder and villainy of every description. However, patience and an enforcement—strictly necessary when one chief brought up a dispute thirty-three years old—of the statute of limitations have at length completed the charges and counter-charges, and the Consul has at length been enabled to give his decision. He certainly showed he was in earnest on the first day of the palaver by fining each of the chiefs half a puncheon of palm oil (equivalent to £5), because their canoes made a row alongside the gunboat. He has now formed a "constitutional government," consisting of the three most powerful chiefs, whom he holds responsible for the administration of the Bonny territory; he has severely fined numerous of the offending chiefs, and has given directions, under a heavy penalty, for the payment of the debts owing by the chiefs to the traders, which in this river amount to some thousands of pounds sterling. It is to be hoped that after this the trade of this river, which has for some time past been yearly retrograding, will show signs of improvement. Formerly Bonny used to be emphatically *the* oil river, but latterly, year by year, its export of that commodity has been diminishing, whilst that of all the other rivers has been increasing. It is an extraordinary fact that, as the price of palm oil has been diminishing month by month, the produce of it has been increasing. This simply arises from the fact that the African is too lazy to work more than is absolutely necessary to obtain what he requires, or thinks he requires. Consequently, as the value obtained in kind for a puncheon of palm oil has diminished, he brings more oil to market to obtain an equivalent supply of gin, gunpowder, clothes, &c., to what he previously received, and so the very proceeding which arises in the first instance from a lowering in the price of the oil at home has a tendency to still further decrease prices by glutting the market.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.685, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the course of some excellent articles which have appeared lately in the *Manchester Guardian*, dealing with the present and future trade prospects of Africa, we have one chapter devoted to the consideration of the drawbacks upon genuine commerce by the enforcement of such quasi-regal rights as those exercised by Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, and the rest of that host of petty kinglings, in the districts of the West Coast. The article in question says:—

One of the ways in which the development of trade must be carried out is by pushing factories up beyond the tribes who now serve as middlemen between the European trader and the native producer. Some difficulty will no doubt be encountered in passing through the unhealthy and malarious districts in which these middlemen live, but the improved knowledge we are obtaining of how to combat climatic diseases will render such an enterprise more easy than it would have been twenty years ago. Indeed, if we contrast the early reports of the Niger with its present exploitation, we may believe that the climate of no tropical country will permanently prevent its being opened up to commerce. This is a ray of hope for our African traders, and it is to be hoped that our Government will enable them to avail themselves of it speedily, and not allow them to be forestalled by the merchants of other nations. As if the inaction of our Government had not been sufficiently disastrous to the trade of the African merchants of Liverpool and Manchester, the home legislation of the last few years has also done much to hamper their enterprise. One industry alone, which, though it may be considered a small one, came in the aggregate to a considerable amount, has been completely driven out of the country. The trade in matches to the West Coast used to be supplied by Manchester. Now, the children who used to be employed in their manufacture are sent to school hungry, while German matches are sent in German ships to those who used to buy the English ones, and the only profit to English people is that of the middleman, and even that is being rapidly taken from them.

The German and French textile manufactures are also running us close, and we have to watch carefully the change of fashions and ideas among the natives. Many cheap articles made in France, with a ready sale on the coast, could easily be made in England. Some of the native manufactures could easily be imitated, such as the Niger cloths and the silk and cotton cloths made by the Santees and Ashantees of unravelled European stuffs. Beyond the Oil rivers to the south we have the French colony of the Gaboon, which has now become one of the largest tracts of Africa controlled by an European nation. In the old portion of the colony trade is not so flourishing as it used to be, English enterprise having been driven away by the action of protection and differential duties.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The question of the drink traffic and King Ja Ja's troubles, which have been subjects of discussion in the House of Commons lately, ought to attract increased attention to the trade of West Africa.

Our oldest settlement there is at the mouth of the Gambia river; but though the oldest, the total import and export trade amounts to only £380,000 a year. With the exception of the Senegal, the river is the finest on this part of the coast, but it is almost useless for trade purposes, because the country is in so disturbed a condition. Wax, hides, and ground nuts are the principal exports. The ground nuts are sent to Marseilles, where a substitute for olive oil is pressed from them. Rice, cotton, maize, and a kind of millet are also produced, but not in sufficient quantities for export. The charge on ordinary merchandise is 2 per cent. _ad valorem_.

Sierra Leone, with a coast line 200 miles long, has a trade of a different character, the produce of the palm, nuts and oil, hides, gum copal, ground nuts, ginger, and kola nuts being exported. The gum copal and the palm oil are for the most part shipped to Great Britain, and the hides to the United States.

The most promising place of all in this part of the world is Lagos, where the natives are eager to trade. The exports are palm oil and various oil seeds; but although the chances of business are excellent, British rule has failed to develop trade to anything like the extent that was anticipated. The reason is the isolation of the settlements, which were originally slave settlements. Fifty years ago slavery was abolished, and then, instead of making a radical change in the methods of government which the altered conditions required, no action was taken, and the machinery of government was merely adapted to the circumstances. The British Administration has made practically no effort to conciliate the tribes in the interior, or to remove the suspicions which the early history of the colonies had implanted in the minds of the natives. Custom-houses were set up, and, as the natives derive no benefit from the expenditure of the taxes in the colonies, they naturally did not like the new institutions. Then, again, the natives on the coast hate those in the interior, and British administrators invariably sided with the former. The three Ashantee wars were due to this cause. If efforts were made to conciliate the Mandingoes, the Foulahs, and other large tribes in the interior, the trade of these settlements would certainly not consist, as it does at the present time, almost exclusively of the produce of the fringe of land adjoining the sea. The Americans and Germans, particularly the latter, are looking after this trade. As usual, the Germans are picking up the language and the customs of the natives, and it is time our Government bestirred itself to conciliate people who might be valuable customers.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1888#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The rivers are connected by a network of cross creeks, being indeed one delta; so from the Opobo Ja Ja's people found their way to the interior oil markets, and the oil trade of Opobo was established. The trade flourished, and Ja Ja was respected for his fair dealing and his great ability to govern his own people. Meanwhile, treaties of friendship had been made, courts of equity had been established in the various stations; regulations for trade, customs, and other subjects of interest were decided, the British Consul inspecting the proceedings from time to time. Of late years there has been a growing inclination on the part of the traders to establish themselves up the rivers at the interior oil markets, so dispensing with the services of the coast tribes. In Opobo this movement was resisted by Ja Ja, for the reason that the welfare of his people depended upon their employment as middlemen, and as no customs would be paid on the produce bought by the Europeans. He was last year accused of obstructing the Europeans from proceeding to the interior, at the time that his son was in England complaining that the Europeans were invading his markets. Ja Ja was made prisoner by Consul Johnstone, and carried off to Accra. An inquiry was held at Accra upon the charges brought against Ja Ja, and the Admiral holds that they are mainly proved; and Ja Ja is deposed, and will not be allowed to return to the Opobo river. He will, however, be allowed an annual pension of £800 for life.

The principle having been laid down that Europeans may trade in the interior, it becomes imperative to assume definite authority over the district. The "customs" have been abolished, a uniform export duty of 2s. 6d. per ton being levied instead. As things stand, we make no pretence to the sovereignty of the country; we only constitute ourselves the final authority in matters of dispute between the natives and traders of whatever nationality, and debar our continental neighbours from proclaiming themselves masters of the country. Whether things will remain as they now are is the doubtful point; pretexts for occupation are so easily found when wanted that it would be rash to answer. Some tribe is reached who cannot understand dual control; they insist on customs, perhaps; are "chastised" by the Consul; they retaliate, and finally an occupation is proclaimed. This is the danger to which we are exposed, for the destruction of the natives means loss to the traders and the abandonment of commerce. Let this be borne in mind, and we may escape the slough into which other nations have fallen.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Currency and Other Grievances of African Traders', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Chairman of the African Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce has received a memorial, signed by traders and residents at Bathurst, protesting against the transference of the Gambia mail service from British to French vessels, detailing grievances in regard to the currency of the settlement, and asking the co-operation of the Chamber of Commerce in enlisting public sympathy.

We learn with much regret that the Secretary of State for the Colonies has been pleased to direct that the subsidy at present paid for the monthly mail service between Liverpool and this settlement should be discontinued, as he is informed that the general feeling in the settlement was against its continuance. We cannot suppress our feelings of surprise at the above statement, and at such a seeming disregard respecting a matter which so much concerns our interests, as represented in the memorial, addressed in May last to the Colonial Office, on behalf of the West African settlements, protesting against the measure from the outset. In the face of the facts set forth in this memorial, it is impossible to doubt that the discontinuance of the mail service, hitherto carried on by the British and African Steam Navigation Company, will seriously affect our commercial relationship with the merchants and manufacturers interested in the trade of the Gambia. The establishment of our trading connexion direct with Great Britain is due entirely to the maintenance of the monthly mail communication by the steamers running between Liverpool and the settlement, and but for which it might have been impossible.

We, therefore, regard with serious apprehension the ruin which threatens an enterprise which many of us have embarked in in the earliest days of our lives, and which will cut off from us the fruits which it has been our desire to enjoy in old days. Not only will such a measure cut off our source of supplies, but oblige us to be at the mercy of the French merchants, who already command the trade; and we shall be deprived of the facilities which hitherto have enabled us to maintain competition with our French neighbours in the trade, and will cause tastes and preferences by the natives in the interior of the district, and the wish of the natives for British manufactures will be checked.

The discontinuance of the mail service will also affect the export trade in ground nuts, which has been only recently created, and the results of which have led us to hope that a fair field of competition would be opened against the French market, where the great bulk of this produce has hitherto been consigned. By the service of the mail steamers, cheap food and provisions are within the reach of all classes in the community, and, in the event of this service being discontinued, a state of things altogether unpleasant will be brought about by those in whose hands the advantage lies.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This subject is (says the *Manchester Guardian*, in a series of excellent articles upon the present state of the West Coast of Africa, now under publication) a very wide one, the trade of Africa being carried on under such different conditions, by such different races, and the goods dealt in being so various, that it would seem difficult to bring all under one discussion; but, unfortunately, all the trade of Africa has one great point of similarity, and that is that all is depressed, and much is passing into the hands of foreign competitors. A Royal Commission has been appointed to inquire into the causes of depression in trade. The causes of the depression in African trade are not far to seek, and the remedies must be applied by the Government, and not by the merchants. The apathetic policy which has been pursued, the systematic ignoring of those who have knowledge and experience, and the entrusting of important interests to incompetent hands, have had the effects which were to be expected, and unless some decisive action is taken soon, we may expect our African trade to go from bad to worse, and be all transferred from London, Liverpool, and Bristol to Hamburg, Havre, and Marseilles.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MANUFACTURERS IN AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Mr. Alvan Millson, Assistant Colonial Secretary, Colony of Lagos, delivered an address in the Manchester Chamber of Commerce rooms on June 5th, on the Commerce and Industries of the Yoruba country. Mr. F. Zimmern, honorary secretary of the Manchester Geographical Society, presided, the lecture being under the society's auspices.

Mr. Millson said that although the enterprise of European merchants in the Niger had rectified the evil in so far as Ilorin and the interior were concerned, it was still the case that the powerful nation of Yoruba, with its 400,000 families of industrial cultivators of the soil, was hopelessly cut off in every direction from all but the most insignificant driblets of European trade. During the past fifteen years its northern frontier had been constantly harassed by the inroads of the Mohammedans, who had made Ilorin their centre of operations towards the south, and by that renewed pressure from the north the inhabitants of Yoruba had not only been cut off from their former sources of supplies in that direction, but had also been forced to submit to the exactions and commercial blockade of their weaker kinsmen who inhabit the neighbourhood of the Gulf lagoons. These tribes, with true African blindness to consequences, harassed in every way the Yorubas in their efforts to drive back the Fulah conquerers, curtailed their supply of guns and powder, upon which their safety depended, demanded exorbitant prices for such articles as they condescended to allow them to purchase, and to the best of their ability revenged themselves for former oppressions at their hands. Not only did they by this means endanger the safety of their own land, and diminish a trade which should be a source of prosperity to all, but they disregarded all former promises and friendly relations with the English, and inflicted a serious injury to our trade, by cutting us off from commercial intercourse with the most important market of West Africa. The continual wars led to slave catching, and the result was that the trade routes to the interior were, with few exceptions, closed to traffic, and it was more difficult for a trader to penetrate beyond the coast line than for a Mohammedan to traverse the desert of Sahara. The general insecurity of property on the borders of", 'last_edit_date': '1891-07-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_07_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Great Britain and Portugal in East Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'all traffic with them forbidden, as in the case of the populous towns of Onitsha, Idah, &c., as in them there would have been competition of other merchants." This is a mistake. It is impossible to say what towns he includes under "&c.," but not only has the Niger Government never closed Idah to trade, but that place has actually been a port of entry for vessels ever since the issue of the charter. As a matter of fact, Onitsha, the most turbulent place in the territories, and the scene of constant trouble prior to the charter, is the only town that has ever been closed to trade. The prohibition, of course, extended as fully to the trade of the Company as to that of other foreigners. As the Company at that time (1886) was the only European trader in the territories, and had large commercial establishments at Onitsha, it cannot be seriously contended that the closing was in order to prevent competition. Moreover, in another part of his report, the German Consul says that "competition with the powerful and admirably organised Company is as good as impossible in the same locality," which, whether true or not, is plainly inconsistent with his previous and absolutely unfounded imputation of motives for closing "Onitsha, Idah, &c."', 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: The British colonial government strategically mediated local conflicts to maintain control over trade routes and resources, prioritizing economic and political interests over humanitarian concerns.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that the British colonial government strategically mediated local conflicts to maintain control over trade routes and resources, prioritizing economic and political interests over humanitarian concerns. The General History of Africa highlights the British tactic of 'divide and conquer,' exploiting African rivalries and weaknesses to their advantage, and their intervention in local politics through treaties and the use of gunboats to enforce agreements, all of which align with the claim of strategic mediation for control. The emphasis on maintaining 'law and order' to facilitate resource exploitation and the implementation of economic policies, such as tariffs and quotas, further underscores the prioritization of British interests over local welfare, with little mention of humanitarian concerns. Similarly, The African Times articles detail instances where British officials, like Sir Samuel Rowe and Mr. Carter, intervened in local conflicts to stabilize regions critical for trade, emphasizing the protection of trade routes and the revival of commerce in areas like the Gambia and Sierra Leone. The reluctance of the British government to engage in conflicts unless they directly impacted trade further illustrates a strategic approach focused on economic stability rather than humanitarian issues. However, the articles also note efforts to abolish slavery and promote peace through treaties, indicating some level of humanitarian concern, albeit secondary to economic objectives. Together, these sources corroborate the claim by illustrating the British focus on economic and political control through strategic mediation and exploitation of local conflicts, with humanitarian efforts being a nuanced and secondary consideration.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that support the claim that the British colonial government strategically mediated local conflicts to maintain control over trade routes and resources, prioritizing economic and political interests over humanitarian concerns. The text highlights the British tactic of 'divide and conquer,' exploiting African rivalries and weaknesses to their advantage, which aligns with the claim of strategic mediation for control. Additionally, the British intervention in local politics through treaties and the use of gunboats to enforce agreements further supports the notion of prioritizing economic and political interests. The emphasis on maintaining 'law and order' to facilitate the exploitation of resources and the use of economic policies, such as tariffs and quotas, to benefit British interests over local welfare, also aligns with the claim. However, the text does not explicitly mention humanitarian concerns, suggesting that these were not a priority for the British colonial government. Overall, the textbook content corroborates the claim by illustrating the British focus on economic and political control through strategic mediation and exploitation of local conflicts.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that align with the claim that the British colonial government strategically mediated local conflicts to maintain control over trade routes and resources, prioritizing economic and political interests over humanitarian concerns. The articles highlight instances where British officials, such as Sir Samuel Rowe and Mr. Carter, intervened in local conflicts, like those involving Saide Mattie and Beram Ceasey, with the aim of stabilizing regions critical for trade. The emphasis on protecting trade routes and reviving commerce, as seen in the discussions about the Gambia and Sierra Leone, supports the notion that economic interests were a priority. Additionally, the articles mention the reluctance of the British government to engage in conflicts unless they directly impacted trade, as seen in the refusal to join the French in stopping wars outside British settlements. This suggests a strategic approach to intervention, focused on maintaining economic stability rather than addressing humanitarian issues. However, the articles also note the British government's efforts to abolish slavery and promote peace through treaties, indicating some level of humanitarian concern, albeit secondary to economic objectives. Overall, the articles largely support the claim, with a few nuances that suggest a complex interplay between economic interests and humanitarian efforts.
