[{'document_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"The above statement will, I am sure, be most gratifying to all who are interested either in trade or the extension of civilization in this part of Africa, and the more so as war has been put an end to by peaceful means, although it has been necessary to interfere to some extent with native affairs outside the colony. It may be proper where British settlements are surrounded by powerful and fierce nations, like those of Ashantee and Dahomey, for our Government to forbid interference in their affairs lest we should be drawn into conflict with them. But the case is entirely different in the neighbourhood of Sierra Leone. There the people are divided into a large number of very small tribes, and, although their petty wars are sufficient to fill their country with bloodshed, and frequently to stop our trade, they have never shown either inclination or capacity to unite under one chief or to form anything like a nation. Their wars are all between themselves, and mutual friends and foes all alike are inclined to welcome our interference as arbitrators in their disputes. To deny to our local Governors the right to do so is not only cruel to these people, but downright destructive to the trade and prosperity of the colony. And yet the late Governor, Sir Arthur Havelock, under instructions doubtless from home, actually refused to join an agent of the French Governor of Senegal in the employment even of moral force to stop a war between the Susoos and Timmanees, on the ground that they were outside the settlement of Sierra Leone. In my last letter I also showed that the long-continued native wars, in which multitudes of people near my own part of the country had been killed, whole districts reduced to starvation, trade entirely stopped, and no revenue obtainable from the coast, we had recently annexed for the sake of revenue, might have been stopped by a little judicious action on the part of our Governor, which he was prevented from taking by orders from Downing-street. I now desire to state that these wars have been stopped, and trade so far revived, with a consequent probability of public revenue, without war, violence, or danger of them, on our part, and even without expenditure to any great amount, simply through the energy of a Governor who knows the native character and has adapted his measures accordingly."
[AUG. 1, 1885.

trade of the colony, and a great hindrance to their civilization. One can only hope that the successful result of Sir Samuel Rowe's late proceedings will convince our Colonial Secretary of the uselessness of attempting to govern such a colony by hard-and-fast rules drawn up in London without that intimate knowledge of local peculiarities which is absolutely essential to its welfare. —I am, Sir, your obedient servant,  
"A WEST AFRICAN MERCHANT."  
"London."', 'last_edit_date': '1885-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have numerous treaties with the natives, beginning from 1826; they relate, in some instances, to cessions of territory, and always contain engagements for the protection of trade, the abolition of slavery, and the preservation of peace. They are not entered into by the natives without great consideration, and as they are rarely, if ever, broken, they are decidedly beneficial to the colony. Moreover, they afford us the plea for proffering our intervention when they show a disposition to quarrel amongst themselves, and in some recent instances our interference has been attended with very good results. The practice which has been long and successfully followed at Sierra Leone, of paying the chiefs small stipends to encourage them in observing these engagements, might advantageously be introduced at the Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.627, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Some months since the *Times* inserted a letter directing attention to the policy of the Government in the countries which adjoin the territories between British Sherbro and the Republic of Liberia on the West Coast of Africa. The letter called attention to the native wars which had desolated the whole region surrounding the colony of Sierra Leone and put an entire stop to British trade on the newly-annexed coast; to the powerlessness of the Government of Sierra Leone to stop these wars in consequence of the instructions sent out from Downing-street; and the necessity of allowing to Sir Samuel Rowe, who had just then been reappointed Governor of Sierra Leone, more power and discretion than had been allowed to his predecessors. This line of policy has, at least to some extent, since been acted upon, with the results of stopping the native wars, the revival of trade, and the advancement of the interests of the colony generally. These results are largely due to Sir Samuel Rowe's tact and ability, and his knowledge, obtained by previous experience, of the peculiar wants of the district and native character; and also in no small measure to the non-observance of the instructions from the Colonial Office, which left former Governors without discretion to act as they from experience knew to be necessary.

The colony of Sierra Leone was established and maintained for the purpose of becoming an emporium of commerce and a means of civilizing the whole of that part of Africa through the extension of its communications with the interior. Unhappily, the colony is surrounded by a number of small tribes, continually at war with each other, thereby preventing traffic to the more peaceable inhabitants and the markets of the interior. The trade of Sierra Leone and its dependencies is essentially a transport trade. The amount of goods produced or consumed in the colony itself is quite insignificant, as nearly everything that enters or leaves it is intended for the interior. The question of peace or war among the neighbouring tribes is thus a most serious matter to the prosperity of the colony. And yet the late Governor, doubtless under instructions, refused to join an agent of the French Governor of Senegal in order to stop a war between the Susoos and Timmannees, on the ground that they were outside the Settlement. Yet these wars have now been stopped, and trade revived, at least partially, without war on our part, even without great expenditure, through the energy of a Governor who knows the native character and has adopted means accordingly.

Immediately after Sir Samuel Rowe's return to Sierra Leone, he made an excursion into the Timmannee country, where he...", 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following letter has such an important bearing upon the present state of Sierra Leone that we print it in its entirety from the *Times*:

"**Sir**—You were good enough on the 8th of January last to insert a letter of mine in relation to the policy of our Government in the countries which adjoin our newly-acquired territories between British Sherbro and the Republic of Liberia on the West Coast of Africa. The object of that letter was to call attention to the horrible native wars which had for a long time desolated the whole region surrounding the colony of Sierra Leone and put an entire stop to British trade on the newly-annexed coast; to the powerlessness of the Government of Sierra Leone to stop these wars in consequence of the absurd instructions sent out from Downing-street; and the necessity of allowing to Sir Samuel Rowe, who had then just been reappointed Governor of Sierra Leone, more power and discretion than had been allowed to his predecessors.

"I am glad to state that the line of policy I then advocated has since been acted upon, and so far with the results of stopping the native wars, the revival of trade, and the advancement of the interests of the colony of Sierra Leone generally. These satisfactory results are, no doubt, largely due to Sir Samuel Rowe's personal tact and ability, and his special knowledge of the peculiar wants of the district and native character, obtained by previous experience. But they are also due in no small measure to the non-observance of the mischievous instructions from the Colonial Office, which left former Governors without any discretion to act in the only manner which men of local experience knew to be necessary.

"It may suit the political theories of people at home, who have no practical acquaintance with the West African Coast, to forbid our representative there to step a yard outside British territory. But it should be remembered that the colony of Sierra Leone was established and for many years maintained at great expense for the express purpose that it might become an emporium of commerce and a means of civilizing the whole of that part of Africa through the extension of its communications with the interior. Unhappily, however, the colony is surrounded by a number of small tribes, who are continually at war with each other, and who thereby prevent traffic across their belt of country to the more peaceable inhabitants and the rich markets of the interior. The trade of Sierra Leone and its dependencies, it must never be forgotten, is essentially a carrying trade. The amount of goods produced or consumed in the colony itself is quite insignificant. Nearly everything that enters or leaves it is intended to reach the interior, many miles distant from British jurisdiction.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'As most of our readers are aware, there has been formed in Sierra Leone an association to promote the development of the country, which includes natives of all ranks, with resident Europeans. This association has forwarded to the Colonial Office a memorial to the effect, among other things, that the great need of their colony is that the Governor should have sufficient power to go outside their borders and compel the chiefs already under treaty obligations not to engage in war with each other, to observe those obligations. This association has also suggested the appointment of native agents in all the treaty districts, whose business it should be to keep the Governor informed of all native movements tending towards war. This would enable him to take effectual action for their suppression, and he should be authorised to use the powers lodged in him for that purpose. Were a plan like this carried out, and not left to the variable notions of successive Governors, many a smouldering fire would be extinguished before it burst into the flames of war. A little force might be occasionally necessary, but the amount would be wonderfully small, the roads to the interior would be kept permanently open, and in course of time those tribes who now interrupt the trade would find it more advantageous to live in peace.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This statement must be most gratifying to all who are interested in trade and the extension of civilization in this part of Africa, the more so as war has been stopped by peaceful means, though it has been necessary to interfere to some extent with native affairs outside the colony. It may be proper, where settlements are surrounded by powerful and fierce nations, for the Home Government to forbid interference in their affairs, lest we should be drawn into conflict with them. But the case is different in the neighbourhood of Sierra Leone. There the people are divided into a number of very small tribes, and though their wars are sufficient to fill their country with bloodshed and frequently to stop trade, they have never shown inclination or capacity to form anything like a nation. Their wars are all between themselves, and friends and foes are inclined to welcome our interference as arbitrators in their disputes. One must hope that the result so far of Sir Samuel Rowe's proceedings will convince those concerned of the uselessness of attempting to govern such a colony by hard-and-fast rules drawn up in London without that intimate knowledge of local peculiarities which is absolutely essential to its welfare.

The above facts are gleaned from a long and interesting letter, signed "A West African Merchant," which appeared in the _Times_ of July 27th, and which gave rise to further correspondence upon this subject, the salient points of which will be found appended.

Though very true that Sir Samuel Rowe has induced the chiefs to agree to a mutual peace, it seems that so soon as pressure was removed they fell back into their old ways; and when the Governor had departed from Kambia, that place was plundered and burnt; and even now war is raging at Mosaipeh, Mammyah, Masabole, and Bendoom.

Sir Samuel Rowe went out to Sierra Leone with no more power to punish the offending natives than had his predecessor, and the native chiefs knew this well enough. All they fear or respect is force; the lavish expenditure of money, gin, tobacco, cloth, &c., by the English Government is looked upon by the native as a sign of weakness on the part of the donor. The general opinion appears to be that we cannot look for permanent peace until it is known by the natives that the Governor has unlimited powers to use such force as he may think fit to punish.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.626, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letter of Merchants and Traders to Governor Rowe', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Your Excellency having already been informed by the chiefs and traders of the Boom River that war has recently broken out there, it is needless for us to again enter into particulars concerning the same. We have, therefore, only to corroborate all they have written to you on the subject; but in justice to ourselves, we must inform your Excellency that the correspondence above referred to was not shown to the majority of us until Monday last.

We regret very much to learn from your Excellency's reply to the chiefs and traders that you have thought fit to decline to interfere between the belligerents, or to in any way punish the murderers of the two British subjects—the war men who first burnt and afterwards plundered every factory between Mobungo and Wymah.

From a previous knowledge of your Excellency's prompt and effective demonstration against the natives of the Jong and Bagroo Rivers, we are induced to believe that you will take such steps as you may deem necessary to re-establish peace in the country and vindicate the honour of the Government you represent.

We earnestly request your Excellency's immediate interference, in order that the war now raging in the Boom may not extend to the Kittam and other rivers.

We must remind your Excellency that we are entirely dependent on these two named rivers for the largest portion of the produce we collect. In the event of both being closed against commerce, we should have no alternative but to at once reduce our establishments until such time as peace shall be re-established throughout the country.

From your Excellency's letter to the chiefs of the Boom, we very much regret to learn that you so strongly advised them to seek redress by force of arms; although your predecessor, Mr. Kortwright (about two years ago), thought it advisable for British interests to enter into a treaty with the chiefs of Boom River, binding them to raze their war-fences to the ground; and also, in the event of any of the neighbouring tribes bringing war on them, that they should, before taking any active steps, submit the matter to the Commandant, and in the event of his not being able to settle the "palaver," they were then to lay the matter before the Governor-in-Chief for the time being. They further bound themselves to protect the lives and property of British subjects: and we are pleased to be enabled to say that they have carried out their part of the treaty in a manner little to be expected from an uncivilized tribe, though how far we have performed our obligations your Excellency knows better than we do.

Should your Excellency still decide not to interfere, the consequences will be most disastrous to us all, as the natives in the adjacent rivers will know then that they can plunder and murder British subjects with impunity. Trade will, in consequence, be stopped, and the prestige of the British Government entirely forgotten.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-03-15', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1878#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GOVERNMENT OF THE OIL RIVERS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We are not unmindful of the plea put forward in favour of administration by a chartered company, that the work of government in a newly acquired territory can be performed more economically by it than by the machinery of a Crown colony; but we would remind your Lordship that in the Oil Rivers District even now there are sources of revenue which should amply suffice for the expenses of a well-organised Crown colony. The trade of this district already greatly exceeds that of Lagos, and, under statesmanlike rule, is certain to advance from year to year. Moderate and equitable fiscal arrangements would yield all the revenue needed for administration, and would be welcomed as a great boon by the people if they replaced the arbitrary system of fines and bribes at present in force. The appointment and collection of that revenue should, however, we are of opinion, be assigned to duly qualified officers of the Crown, and not be entrusted to the traders who have hitherto, seeking only immediate gain, recklessly pursued tactics debasing and oppressive to the natives. To assign to those traders far greater powers than they now possess—and abuse—would, we venture to say, be a most impolitic and disastrous surrender by her Majesty's Government of its duties towards native races brought within the sphere of British influence.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.627, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE WITH THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. J. F. Hutton said that for years past the Manchester Chamber of Commerce had been in correspondence with the Colonial Office in reference to the West Coast of Africa, and had constantly called attention to the neglect of the authorities to attend to the interests of our trade, and to the responsibilities that ought to be undertaken in connexion with it. This trade especially concerned Manchester and the district around, because the bulk of the goods that went to the West Coast were cotton goods. For that reason, the Manchester Chamber of Commerce felt greatly interested in this question, and they asked the Government to consider whether they could not accept a greater amount of responsibility, not only as regarded the merchants, but also as regarded the natives in the interior. This country held possession of a mere fringe of the coast; but the goods that passed up the river were taxed, and merchants got no protection for their trade in return. The policy of the Colonial Office deterred merchants from going into the interior, and disheartened them. They had been urged, and in fact warned, not to go into the interior. The result was that our trade had fallen off considerably. He considered that the cause of this decline was, in a great measure, the absence of that order and responsibility that ought to exist on the coast of Africa. Complaints had been made of internal wars. These wars were continually arising among the tribes, and in some cases merchants had been ruined. A substantial duty was levied on goods passing along the Gambia, and the protection accorded in return was most inadequate. The case of Gambia was, perhaps, the worst of the class. It had been troubled by wars and robberies to such an extent that trade was almost ruined, and there was scarcely a merchant left of any position. The trade of the district was gradually passing into the hands of the French, from the want of activity and determination on the part of the British authorities. The British traders were being taxed without getting any adequate protection in return. The merchants had no representative on the Council. It was true there were...', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Trade in the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We have been requested to publish the following correspondence:—

(Copy.)

Chamber of Commerce, Manchester, Oct. 13th, 1885.  
To the Right Hon. Colonel Stanley, M.P., &c., &c., Colonial Office, London.

Sir,—On the 9th September last I had the honour to enclose you a copy of a letter which had been addressed to this Chamber relative to the disastrous condition of affairs in the Gambia—caused, in a great measure, by the robberies of native chiefs upon British property, on a river which, for the past 70 years, has been subject to the sovereignty of Great Britain.

To my communication of the foregoing date, I have not as yet been favoured with any reply.

Gambia merchants tell this board that the losses incurred by them during the last two or three years amount to over 25 per cent. on the capital which they have invested in that trade.

They further state that the season has now arrived when they ought to commence the shipments of supplies of goods suitable for the next year's Gambia trade. But they plead that in the present neglected state of the colony it would not be judicious to make the requisite preparatory arrangements—thus not only inflicting injury on the colony, but also, reflectively, of course, upon the industries of the mother country.

It has been authoritatively asserted that Her Majesty's Government cannot employ force for the establishment of peace or putting down outrages in countries beyond the jurisdiction of the Crown.

But inasmuch as the British Government not only claims, but exercises jurisdiction over the waters of the Gambia, by levying taxes on goods ascending and descending that river, it would seem only a matter of right that Her Majesty's subjects, recollecting that in England taxation and protection go together, should either receive, in this instance, protection from the colonial authorities, or that they should celebrate the demise of their authority and power by the removal of all duties and all official impediments and restrictions on the river.

Appealed to by its members on this question, the Chamber can only in its turn make representations to the Colonial Office. I would, therefore, respectfully call the serious attention of Her Majesty's Government to these complaints, and urge that these grave disabilities, amounting even to wrongs upon British commerce, may without delay be redressed.—I have, &c.,

(Signed) **James F. Hutton, President.**

---

(Copy.)

Downing Street, October 21st, 1885.  
To J. F. Hutton, Esq., President, Manchester Chamber of Commerce.

Sir,—I am directed by Secretary Colonel Stanley to state that he has had under his consideration your letters of the 9th ult. and the 13th inst., on the subject of the injury to British subjects and property, and the loss of trade occasioned by the native wars in the districts bordering on the River Gambia.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It will be considered presently whether larger reductions cannot be effected in the cost for military establishments without endangering the security of the settlements, and with increased efficiency to their administration.

Admitting that there may have been errors in the administration of these settlements, that their finances may not have been always carefully managed, and that differences or collisions with the natives have occurred which greater forethought or judgment might perhaps have in some instances prevented, it cannot be denied that, from their circumstances and position, they are exposed to risks and embarrassments from which most other colonies are free, and that whenever settlements are brought into contact with warlike and lawless savages, such complications as have occurred on the West Coast are by no means unfrequent, and are generally productive of financial and other difficulties.

The possibility of introducing improvements into their administration will, however, presently form a subject of consideration.

The suggestion that the benefits accruing from the settlements would be as readily obtained were they abolished, or, at least, made trading posts with a consul, is supposed to be supported by the fact that the oil rivers, as the district is termed in which the Benin, Nun, Calabar, and Bonny Rivers are situated, have a trade in palm oil exceeding that of the settlements, and yet that it is sustained without any aid or interference from Government.

This statement is perfectly correct, except as regards the non-interference of the Government, the Commodore being compelled at times to exercise all the authority which the power of the squadron gives him to maintain order in these rivers, which are said to be occasionally the scene of great irregularities.

It must, however, be borne in mind that the district in question is most prolific in palm-oil trees, and that ready access is obtainable to it through its numerous rivers; thus favourably situated, Europeans had every opportunity of making the natives aware of the value of the produce that lay around them, and of inducing them to turn their attention to its collection, whilst the facilities which were afforded the trade were such as are not to be found in any other part of Africa.

Urged by these considerations, the chiefs were soon led to see that it was more advantageous to employ their slaves in the manufacture of palm oil than to sell them; and it is easy to understand how, under these circumstances, no Government aid should have been required to create the large trade that now exists, and by its agency has abolished the former traffic in slaves.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Perils and Dangers to British Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On the Gold Coast nothing is done by the Government to open up the country to commerce; nothing done at Lagos; nothing at Sierra Leone; nothing at Gambia. Though this last has a deep water highway 350 miles into the interior, protection is not afforded, and Englishmen will not be allowed to protect their trade themselves. The merchants cannot push forward, and as not being protected, and not being allowed to arm their people and protect themselves, they complain that official meddling and interference of the men sent out to manage our colonies—whose sole idea of administration is to raise taxes and spend them principally in salaries, allowances, or theoretical experiments—is utterly obstructive and ruinous to successful trade, the source from which all revenue is derived.

This dog-in-the-manger policy will end in killing the goose...

i.e., trade—that lays the golden egg—i.e., revenue, and depriving England of what ought to be her best markets.—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1879-09-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EXTRACTS FROM A LECTURE BY THE UNDER-SECRETARY FOR THE COLONIES ON COLONIAL GOVERNMENT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Deal, October 23.—Mr. E. H. K. Karskoth-Hugessen, M.P., Under-Secretary for the Colonies, delivered a lecture on 23rd October, to the members of the Deal and Walmer Institute, on "The Colonies, and their Government by the Mother Country." First, he desired to say how entirely he agreed with the opinion implied in the question, "What would Great Britain be without her colonies?" There had been from time to time statesmen who had let fall words from which it had been inferred that they regarded colonial possessions at a low value. They had talked of the evils contingent upon such possessions, the vulnerable point for assault which they afford to an enemy in time of war, of the difficulty and delicacy of the relations between a mother country and a dependency; daily increasing in wealth and population; and they maintained that our trade and commerce would be equal in magnitude and extent if each great colony were an independent country. For his part, he differed entirely from such views as these. He thought—nay, he maintained, as an undoubted and incontrovertible fact—that our colonies had been, and still are, of immense service to us; that by their means, the name, the credit, and the prestige of England had been heralded throughout the world; that trade had followed the flag; that by means of them commerce, free of labour for our surplus population, for whatever small force our active spirits had, been, had been opened to us through our colonies; and that it was the duty of every patriotic Englishman to cherish the colonial connection, and to do his utmost to strengthen the tie which bound and united together the mother country and the colonies, to their great and mutual advantage. (Cheers.) He might go even further. There could only be one colonial policy by which any government in this country could stand or fall. Any government which rightly interpreted, and desired duly to represent, the feelings and wishes of the people, must be anxious to cherish and encourage the party at home, and it was little less than a crime for speakers or writers to insinuate that any government desired to alienate the colonies. Such insinuations were only made to serve the object of political partisans, and they might depend upon it that whatever occasional difference there might be in the management of details, any and every British government, from whatever political party it might be chosen, had only one and the same general colonial policy to pursue. (Hear, hear.) Having spoken of the number and position of the British colonies, the manner in which they came into the possession of Great Britain, and the different forms of government which they enjoyed, the honourable gentleman, when dealing with the West Coast of Africa, referred to the somewhat curious fact that while those settlements were originally founded principally for the purposes of the slave trade, they were now, under a wiser and more human policy, made use of for precisely a contrary object—viz., a station from which our efforts might be directed towards the suppression of that cruel and nefarious traffic. These efforts had been attended with very great success. Moreover, these were African settlements which had been centres from which good and brave men had gone forth into the interior of the continent of Africa, and they by their energy and zeal had been created, often at the cost of no means a secondary order of importance, the blessings of Christianity and civilization, and reached those nations who, but for the British settlements, would have still remained in dark and heathen ignorance. (Cheer.) The good work, however, was not yet half done, and there were many obstacles in the way. The missionaries and the civilizing traders had much to contend against, besides the natural difficulty of overcoming native ignorance and prejudice. A committee of the House of Commons sat in 1865 "to consider the state of the British establishments on the Western Coast of Africa." After a long and careful inquiry, the committee reported that "it is impossible to withdraw the British Government wholly or immediately from any settlements or engagements on the West African Coast." But it went on to say that if further extension of territory or assumption of government, or new treaties offering any protection to native tribes, would be inexpedient, and that the object of our policy should be to encourage in the natives the exercise of those qualities which may render it possible for us more and more to transfer to them the administration of all the governments, with a view to our ultimate withdrawal from all, except, probably, Sierra Leone." The main object of that committee, which was doubtless actuated by the best possible motives, was to save this country the expense of these settlements, and the complications with native tribes which had occasionally taken place. For his part, however, he could not look forward to any such contingency. He hoped that, in spite of this report of the House of Commons Committee, settlements which had already effected so much good, and through whose agency so much more might still be done, would never be abandoned by Great Britain; and he believed, moreover, that eventually an increasing and developing trade would make their continued occupation more and more desirable on commercial grounds, while there was good reason to hope that before long they might become entirely self-supporting. (Cheers.) . . . Having given a description of the institution of the Colonial-office in London, and remarking that on all the departments able and experienced men were employed, Mr. Hugessen went on to deal with the duties of the Parliamentary Under-Secretary, and, replying to questions, he mentioned that during three weeks last session, when members of the Government had to stay up in the House of Commons until one, two, or three in the morning four days out of the seven, the average number of despatches that passed through his hands was 84 a week, or 14 a working day. . . . The Colonial-office, however, was not the only channel through which communications were interchanged between the mother country and the colonies. There were two very important gentlemen called the Crown agents, whose office was in Spring-gardens. They were appointed by the Secretary of State at fixed salaries, and the numerical strength and cost of their clerical staff was fixed by the Treasury. Their office was, in fact, a branch of the Colonial-office, and was most valuable to the colonies. They made no personal profit whatever from their agency, as other agents did, but received either a small fixed annual sum, calculated on the average percentage on business transacted. The duties performed by this branch of the office were of a most important and varied character. . . . In his concluding remarks, Mr. Hugessen said that he had heard how colonial matters were treated in Downing-street, and he was glad to say that he believed such matters were regarded by the public with greater interest than was formerly the case. (Hear, hear.) He earnestly desired to encourage the interests of the colonies, and thus to foster and stimulate political union.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_12_1872#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ENGLAND AND HER WEST AFRICAN COLONIES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Turning to the question of the political administration of the Colonies at the present time, he enumerated the different systems of government prevailing in the various British Colonies in Africa, and said that the great benefits derived by the Colonies from their annexation to England, whose constitutional monarchy was the most stable system of representative government to be found in the whole world, were conspicuous and great. England had extended to her West African dependencies the privileges of British legitimate trade and commerce, which was a powerful vehicle for the advancement of civilisation.

Bringing forward the commercial advancement of the West African Colonies, he said the question had often been asked, "Do the Colonies pay?" He could answer with an emphatic affirmative. In 1837 the total external trade of England with all the Colonies was £28,341,471; it was now nearly £300,000,000, thus showing an increase of about ten times. The British shipping in connexion with the Colonies in 1837 was 3,677,975 tons; in 1885 it was 56,611,075 tons. The English Customs returns reckoned the exports to the Colonies in 1837 at £11,283,363; and this had since risen to £54,545,553. Her Majesty's Colonies, he said, furnished more than a quarter of the whole world's annual supply of gold. He then referred to the commercial geography of the British African Colonies, gave the value of their exports and imports, and reviewed the trade generally. The construction of a railway to the interior of Africa from Lagos was a recent proposition and a new feature in the history of the West African Colonies. It was obvious that Africa was, or would be, the only continent open for the future expansion of British manufacture; in such a case the interior would play an important part. He maintained, with eminent authorities on the subject, that by native agency alone, under foreign supervision necessarily, could tropical Africa be gradually and definitely developed on any permanent basis, and that the negro should be educated industrially and otherwise with the generous help of Europe and America. Whatever was accomplished by native agency, England certainly should carry the credit of effecting such accomplishment in the civilisation of Africa. It was beyond doubt that the English were acknowledged the best colonisers; and the marked consideration invariably shown by them to the people whom they undertook to govern, the extreme liberty and entire privileges of a British subject extended to every native, and the judicious caution characteristic of the policy of the British Government had altogether won for England this success and the preference to all other civilised nations. From the past and present history they might reasonably hope for the dawning of still better, brighter, and happier days upon the future of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE EFFECT', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'THE EFFECT of the lately popular laissez-faire policy of the Government with regard to the British colonies and settlements in West Africa is beginning to make itself most unpleasantly realised. For months past it has been pointed out that the French and other European nations were gradually bearing in upon the irregularly defined boundaries of our authority towards the interior; and now the constriction of the annexation band which the recent settlements of the French have completed around the eastern and northern limits of the British sphere in West Africa is beginning to be most painfully felt upon our trade and intercourse with the interior. From Sierra Leone we have complaints that by the appropriation of the hinterlands British authority is confined to a narrow strip of coast; that French authority compels tribes outside our control to boycott our markets and to favour those of France. One effect is that natives are moving inside the British lines. The aggression assumes a most active form on the borders of our old colony on the Gambia. The Governor has investigated the circumstances attending the hauling-down of the Union Jack at two stations in the interior. In one case it was found that the district was distinctly under British protection; the other was about "forty yards outside the British limit." Doubtless, this is a near thing; but the rule the French, with the rest of our rivals, are in the habit of applying is, that ground which cannot be proved to belong to us must belong to them. Since the downfall of the Spanish Colonial Empire in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, Great Britain has been...

till lately, the only European Power of the first rank which has devoted its energies to the construction of an Empire outside the geographical limits of its own home. In the absence of rivals, the course has been comparatively clear; and it seems difficult for Governments to realise that all this has been changed during the last two decades. If we would maintain the Empire which has been handed down to us by the enterprise and enthusiasm of the last nine generations, it can only be done by a ready recognition of the fact that other nations around us are only too eager to circumvent our plans, and to take advantage of every slip and inaction on our part.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1893#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Political instability and conflict in West Africa led to economic disruptions, shifting trade patterns, and declining commodity values in ports like Lagos, Abeokuta, and Old Calabar.
result: The observations from the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that political instability and conflict in West Africa led to economic disruptions, shifting trade patterns, and declining commodity values in ports like Lagos, Abeokuta, and Old Calabar. The General History of Africa describes the nineteenth-century wars in Yorubaland, which resulted in the destruction of settlements and the movement of populations, leading to the creation of new towns like Ibadan and Abeokuta, thereby disrupting traditional trade routes and economic activities. It also highlights the challenge to the Benin kingdom's trading privileges by European traders and African middlemen, indicating a shift in trade dynamics, although it does not specifically mention declining commodity values in the specified ports. Instead, it notes a transition from the slave trade to legitimate trade, such as palm oil, suggesting a shift rather than a decline in economic activities. In contrast, The African Times articles provide more direct evidence of economic challenges, mentioning the blockade of trade routes in Lagos due to conflicts involving the Jebu and Egba tribes, leading to trade stagnation. The war with Ibadan and the demoralization of people in Abeokuta are noted as factors contributing to the decline in trade. The articles also highlight dull trade in Old Calabar and Bonny, with disruptions caused by disputes among native tribes and the impact of treaties, and they specifically mention declining values of commodities such as oils, indicating economic challenges. However, they do not provide specific details about the impact on commodity values in Abeokuta. Together, these sources illustrate how political instability and conflict affected trade and economic conditions in these regions, with the textbook emphasizing shifts in trade patterns and the articles highlighting declining commodity values.

The text describes the nineteenth-century wars in Yorubaland, which resulted in the destruction of settlements and the movement of populations, leading to the creation of new towns like Ibadan and Abeokuta. This suggests a disruption in traditional trade routes and economic activities. The decline of the Benin port of Ughoton further supports the claim of economic disruptions. However, the text does not specifically mention declining commodity values in ports like Lagos, Abeokuta, and Old Calabar, which is a notable difference from the claim. Instead, it highlights the transition from the slave trade to legitimate trade, such as palm oil, which suggests a shift rather than a decline in economic activities. Overall, while the text supports the notion of economic disruptions and shifting trade patterns due to political instability, it does not explicitly address declining commodity values in the specified ports.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that political instability and conflict in West Africa led to economic disruptions, shifting trade patterns, and declining commodity values in ports like Lagos, Abeokuta, and Old Calabar. The articles mention the blockade of trade routes in Lagos due to conflicts involving the Jebu and Egba tribes, which resulted in a stagnation of trade. Additionally, the war with Ibadan and the demoralization of people in Abeokuta are noted as factors contributing to the decline in trade. The articles also highlight the dull trade in Old Calabar and Bonny, with disruptions caused by disputes among native tribes and the impact of treaties. Furthermore, the declining values of commodities such as oils and the overall depression in trade are mentioned, indicating economic challenges. These observations align with the claim, as they illustrate how political instability and conflict affected trade and economic conditions in these regions. However, the articles do not provide specific details about the impact on commodity values in Abeokuta, which is a notable difference from the claim.
