Two years later a similar work stoppage occurred at the Kakontwe mines. 53 The Depression created new economic uncertainties. Jobs disappeared, wages dropped and working conditions deteriorated, as mining interests sought to minimize costs. Despite threats to workers that they would be dismissed, however, work stoppages and labour 'riots' erupted at the Union MiniŁre mines of Kipushi, Ruashi and Mswenu Ditu in 1931, temporarily paralysing operations.$^{54}$ In the same year workers organized a boycott in Elizabethville to protest against the high prices charged for basic com› modities by the Union MiniŁre company stores and independent European merchants. Before it ended, the boycott spread to surrounding regions and gained the support of construction workers, carpenters, and bricklayers - suggesting a growing labour consciousness.$^{55}$ The district commissioner of", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.601, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}]
tat_orig:
[{'id': 171, 'article_title': 'SIERRA LEONE.', 'full_section_title': 'SIERRA LEONE.', 'last_edit_date': '05-20-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1863#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_06_1863', 'content': 'We are glad to learn that his Excellency Governor Blackall has lately sent a messenger up the Sierra Leone river, on a mission to the various chiefs, and to examine into the state of those war-afflicted districts. The latter is miserable enough: there is scarcely a town anywhere remaining. Mr. Lawson, the gentleman despatched on that mission, reports that all the towns have been destroyed by fire, and are at this moment heaps of ruins, presenting a lamentable sight for any one who has previously known them. Quite depopulated, with the exception of here and there a few huts, occupied by starving people, the dense and solitary forest is rapidly enveloping them. This sad state is the result of continual wars among the chiefs since 1858.

It is said that, having destroyed and almost depopulated their country, they are now tired of war and bloodshed, and desire influential mediation among them. Can nothing be done for the permanent tranquillity of these districts? The scattered people are selling the members of their families and their dependents in order to obtain food and supplies of articles which they need. Surely it would be in the interests of humanity to obtain the voluntary consent of all the chiefs to an acknowledgment of a supreme authority, whose counsels and commands should maintain peace and order among them. If, as the Sierra Leone journals assert, there are large supplies of palm-oil, beniseed, camwood, African teak timber, &c., to be procured in those parts of the river, notwithstanding the melancholy state to which the country is reduced, it is evident that, with assured peace and order, and the increase of population which would accompany these, wealth and happiness might soon abound in those districts. The trade of Sierra Leone would increase by measures being taken to make those people prosperous. Civilization ought to be pushed forward up the river from Sierra Leone. It is evident that something more than the mere occupation of the mouth of the river and the immediately contiguous territory is indispensable to order and progress.

Sierra Leone, like the Gambia, has been almost stripped of troops, in order to furnish what, after all, is the miserably insufficient regular force now available at the Gold Coast for the Ashantee war.

The colony is in a very healthy state.

We are glad to see by the journals that the Rev. J. W. Davison, who was lecturing for some time about London and in other parts of this country, had arrived out. It is said that he has been offered the superintendence of the Baptist connexion in the colony, and has accepted it. We always understood his proposed destination to be the Gold Coast, on the ground that his wife is the sister of an influential chief there. We are sorry to find that Mr. Davison, his wife and child, were all suffering under the acclimatising process.'}, {'id': 1506, 'article_title': 'SIERRA LEONE.', 'full_section_title': 'SIERRA LEONE.', 'last_edit_date': '02-08-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1869#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_03_1869', 'content': 'Dear Mr. Editor,—A new year is a season for serious reflection, for a review of past events, and a consideration of things that may possibly happen during its course.

We in this part of the world congratulate ourselves, in a political point of view, on the events which have for the last twelve months marked the history of these settlements, and that we are thus able to look with pleasing countenance to a bright future. The government of our country by an officer whose administration, we are confident, is identified with the true and real policy of benevolent Britain towards Africa—Sir Arthur Edward Kennedy—has done much to bring about the many happy results that have graced the history of Western Africa in 1868, and patriotic Africans cannot fail to revere, love, and respect him; in fact, so much has he secured the confidence of the public here, that it is not long since a reverend gentleman in a public meeting called him "Arthur the Good."

The year which has just expired witnessed a fine and once prosperous country, situate on the north of Sierra Leone, harassed and desolated by a civil war, by which Sierra Leone was famished, because her chief produce for export and home consumption was derived from the surrounding countries. The new Governor-in-Chief saw at once the very damaging effect of native raids and massacres dignified by the name of "War." He proffered his good offices; and within the very short space of two months of his arrival here, Sir Arthur Kennedy succeeded in effecting a peace between the belligerent natives. The Moriah land, which had been desolated for three years, is now enjoying peace and likely to recover her former prosperity; and the colony of Sierra Leone, also, has regained, in a great measure, her usual activity and vigour, although we are under some apprehension that the encroachment of the French nation in that country may prove a heavy and serious loss to this colony.

The political historian of Western Africa, Mr. Editor, would not do justice to this country if he were to pass over in silence events which have lately taken place at the River Volta. The ascent of this noble river by steamer has been reserved for the enterprising Governor Kennedy, who crossed the bar in the colonial steamer Eyo, ably commanded by the Lieut.-Governor of Lagos, Captain Glover, R.N., and ascended in November last as far as Bartoh, distant between sixty and seventy miles from the bar. It is not surprising that the primitive tribes on the banks of the river were seen trying, by their hands and gestures, to imitate the "smoke ship," which they for the first time saw in their river; and some of them were actually racing on foot with the steamer.

The moral effect produced on the natives by the "smoke ship" is said to be very great, and we hope will conduce to permanent peace in those wealthy eastern districts of the Gold Coast.'}, {'id': 3598, 'article_title': 'Important Memorial from Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'Important Memorial from Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': '06-12-1878', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1878#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_07_1878', 'content': '11. Your memorialists, together with all other sections of this community, look with the greatest gravity on a speech of this character emanating from the head of the Government, and are deeply sorry that whilst his Excellency took occasion, which he seems always to endeavour to create, for expressing his contempt for the descendants of the liberated Africans of Western Africa, and his want of genuine sympathy for their material improvement, he has, by his unfortunate speech, created in the minds of the surrounding countries incentive to, and given license for lawlessness, disorder, and, it may be, much bloodshed, for which it is known there is much aptitude in the aboriginal audience of his Excellency.

12. Your memorialists will advert to the great depression to which the commerce of Sierra Leone has for the past eight years been subject, and that, amongst other causes of that depression, is the existence of native feuds and wars around us; that the policy of preceding administrations had been to extend into, and protect in, the interior countries the trade of this settlement, which provides not only means of livelihood for the majority of the people, but also the funds by which the local government is upheld. The position and extent of Sierra Leone, its geographical relations to surrounding countries, the natural aptitude of the inhabitants, perhaps developed by the example of the early as well as later European colonists, render it a strictly commercial community, and it seems to your memorialists that any Governor who aims to destroy instead of cultivating this commercial tendency will struggle long with disappointment of his views, unless his object be also to ruin the settlement.

13. Your memorialists do not charge his Excellency with such an object, but what they do contend is that to have made his above-cited speech to a people through whose country a large portion of the trade with the interior is carried on, and who, without the influence of this settlement, would interfere with and divert the trade by vexatious quarrels and absurd imposts, is to render our social, commercial, and political relations with the interior tribes insecure, to expose to great danger the lives and property of British subjects who go amongst them to seek honest employment, and, by infusing contempt in the minds of the aborigines towards the Africans under British rule, to undermine all the good results of British philanthropy, and awaken in the native mind a mistrust of the moral and civilizing influences of the British people, and a consequent disposition to withdraw from the operation of those influences.'}, {'id': 5176, 'article_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'last_edit_date': '08-01-1885', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': 'The following letter has such an important bearing upon the present state of Sierra Leone that we print it in its entirety from the *Times*:

"**Sir**—You were good enough on the 8th of January last to insert a letter of mine in relation to the policy of our Government in the countries which adjoin our newly-acquired territories between British Sherbro and the Republic of Liberia on the West Coast of Africa. The object of that letter was to call attention to the horrible native wars which had for a long time desolated the whole region surrounding the colony of Sierra Leone and put an entire stop to British trade on the newly-annexed coast; to the powerlessness of the Government of Sierra Leone to stop these wars in consequence of the absurd instructions sent out from Downing-street; and the necessity of allowing to Sir Samuel Rowe, who had then just been reappointed Governor of Sierra Leone, more power and discretion than had been allowed to his predecessors.

"I am glad to state that the line of policy I then advocated has since been acted upon, and so far with the results of stopping the native wars, the revival of trade, and the advancement of the interests of the colony of Sierra Leone generally. These satisfactory results are, no doubt, largely due to Sir Samuel Rowe's personal tact and ability, and his special knowledge of the peculiar wants of the district and native character, obtained by previous experience. But they are also due in no small measure to the non-observance of the mischievous instructions from the Colonial Office, which left former Governors without any discretion to act in the only manner which men of local experience knew to be necessary.

"It may suit the political theories of people at home, who have no practical acquaintance with the West African Coast, to forbid our representative there to step a yard outside British territory. But it should be remembered that the colony of Sierra Leone was established and for many years maintained at great expense for the express purpose that it might become an emporium of commerce and a means of civilizing the whole of that part of Africa through the extension of its communications with the interior. Unhappily, however, the colony is surrounded by a number of small tribes, who are continually at war with each other, and who thereby prevent traffic across their belt of country to the more peaceable inhabitants and the rich markets of the interior. The trade of Sierra Leone and its dependencies, it must never be forgotten, is essentially a carrying trade. The amount of goods produced or consumed in the colony itself is quite insignificant. Nearly everything that enters or leaves it is intended to reach the interior, many miles distant from British jurisdiction.'}, {'id': 5176, 'article_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'last_edit_date': '08-01-1885', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': '"The question of peace or war among the neighbouring tribes thus becomes a matter of life or death to the trade and prosperity of the colony. And yet the late Governor, Sir Arthur Havelock, under instructions doubtless from home, actually refused to join an agent of the French Governor of Senegal in the employment even of moral force to stop a war between the Susoos and Timmanees, on the ground that they were outside the settlement of Sierra Leone. In my last letter I also showed that the long-continued native wars, in which multitudes of people near my own part of the country had been killed, whole districts reduced to starvation, trade entirely stopped, and no revenue obtainable from the coast, we had recently annexed for the sake of revenue, might have been stopped by a little judicious action on the part of our Governor, which he was prevented from taking by orders from Downing-street. I now desire to state that these wars have been stopped, and trade so far revived, with a consequent probability of public revenue, without war, violence, or danger of them, on our part, and even without expenditure to any great amount, simply through the energy of a Governor who knows the native character and has adapted his measures accordingly.'}, {'id': 5176, 'article_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Our Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'last_edit_date': '08-01-1885', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': '"The above statement will, I am sure, be most gratifying to all who are interested either in trade or the extension of civilization in this part of Africa, and the more so as war has been put an end to by peaceful means, although it has been necessary to interfere to some extent with native affairs outside the colony. It may be proper where British settlements are surrounded by powerful and fierce nations, like those of Ashantee and Dahomey, for our Government to forbid interference in their affairs lest we should be drawn into conflict with them. But the case is entirely different in the neighbourhood of Sierra Leone. There the people are divided into a large number of very small tribes, and, although their petty wars are sufficient to fill their country with bloodshed, and frequently to stop our trade, they have never shown either inclination or capacity to unite under one chief or to form anything like a nation. Their wars are all between themselves, and mutual friends and foes all alike are inclined to welcome our interference as arbitrators in their disputes. To deny to our local Governors the right to do so is not only cruel to these people, but downright destructive to the trade and prosperity of the colony. And yet the late Governor, Sir Arthur Havelock, under instructions doubtless from home, actually refused to join an agent of the French Governor of Senegal in the employment even of moral force to stop a war between the Susoos and Timmanees, on the ground that they were outside the settlement of Sierra Leone. In my last letter I also showed that the long-continued native wars, in which multitudes of people near my own part of the country had been killed, whole districts reduced to starvation, trade entirely stopped, and no revenue obtainable from the coast, we had recently annexed for the sake of revenue, might have been stopped by a little judicious action on the part of our Governor, which he was prevented from taking by orders from Downing-street. I now desire to state that these wars have been stopped, and trade so far revived, with a consequent probability of public revenue, without war, violence, or danger of them, on our part, and even without expenditure to any great amount, simply through the energy of a Governor who knows the native character and has adapted his measures accordingly."
[AUG. 1, 1885.

trade of the colony, and a great hindrance to their civilization. One can only hope that the successful result of Sir Samuel Rowe's late proceedings will convince our Colonial Secretary of the uselessness of attempting to govern such a colony by hard-and-fast rules drawn up in London without that intimate knowledge of local peculiarities which is absolutely essential to its welfare. —I am, Sir, your obedient servant,  
"A WEST AFRICAN MERCHANT."  
"London."'}, {'id': 6368, 'article_title': 'The Natural Products of Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'The Natural Products of Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_09_1893#article-2', 'issue_date': '04_09_1893', 'content': 'Much interesting and useful information may be gleaned from the Colonial Office report lately issued with reference to Sierra Leone. It has been compiled by Mr. G. F. Scott-Elliott and Miss Catherine A. Raisin, and deals exhaustively with the botany and geology of that Colony. One or two of the matters with which it deals may be noted. Sugar-cane is cultivated, and seems suited to the climate, and the £3,500 worth of sugar imported by the Colony in 1890 may—the authors of the report state—be easily produced on the spot. Arrowroot grows exceedingly well; indeed, that of Sierra Leone is claimed to be the best in the world. But unfortunately the market has been spoilt because the Natives adulterated the flour with cassada and would not clean it properly. African flax or bow-string hemp is extremely common in the district. Its excellent character is well known, but so far the difficulty of preparing it for the market has not been overcome, and it is suggested that the processes of cleaning might be improved by first passing the leaves lengthwise through two horizontal rollers placed close together. Banana fibre is also referred to. As fibre, it can, perhaps, scarcely compete with other substances, but has scarcely yet had a fair practical trial. Usually the old stems are cut into four, lengthwise, the soft heart is taken out, and the pieces, after being left lying two or three days, are passed lengthwise through two horizontal rollers and washed. A tree yields about 4 lbs. of fibre, which is worth from £12 to £20 a ton. Waste stems might be profitably utilised in this way, though a plantation for fibre purposes could scarcely pay. There should be a large export trade in bananas, which sell at about 8d. a bunch. The authors think that with good roads, the supply of rubber from the Colony may be doubled or even quadrupled in amount, while the demand for this most useful article is capable of almost endless expansion. The obstacles to the trade are the constant Native wars prevailing in the interior.'}, {'id': 6403, 'article_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN MAHDI', 'full_section_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN MAHDI', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_12_1893#article-6', 'issue_date': '04_12_1893', 'content': "Samadu first came in contact with the French in 1882, in which year his career of conquest to the north brought him to Keniera, an important market beyond the Niger, to which he laid siege. The chief of Keniera applied to the French for assistance, and a small column under Colonel Desbordes marched to his aid. It arrived too late to save Keniera, but Samadu's entrenched camps were stormed and his army, numbering about 5,000 men, dispersed in every direction. The war thus commenced was continued through the years 1882 and 1883, with uniform success on the part of the French against overwhelming odds, and the Sofas were gradually driven southwards. The repeated defeats he had experienced now made Samadu chary of coming into further collision with the French, for it is only by success that an adventurer such as he can keep together his heterogeneous following; and finding that the heathen tribes to the north were effectually protected by the French, he, in 1884, carried his raids southward into Sulimania and districts which are now placed within the sphere of British influence. In 1884 he captured and destroyed Falaba, the capital of Sulimania, and the great emporium for the trans-Niger trade, and devastated a vast tract of country. Thousands of natives were slain, thousands more were sold into slavery, and the country was so depopulated that trade came to a standstill, and the colony of Sierra Leone was reduced to the verge of bankruptcy. These conquests brought a fresh accession of strength to Samadu, and in 1885 he again commenced operating against the French provinces, but sustained in that year a severe defeat near Siguiri, and in the year following a still more severe defeat at Malinkamori, the result of which was that, in February 1887, he signed a treaty of peace with the French, in which he recognised that the River Niger was the boundary between his territory and that of the French."}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Intestine wars had broken out amongst the natives in the Mellicourie country, near Sierra Leone, and several European factories had been destroyed and plundered. The authorities at Sierra Leone were adopting measures to punish the marauders and obtain reparation for the losses sustained by British subjects during the disturbance. Trade was very inactive, and in consequence of heavy rains sickness was rather prevalent amongst Europeans. The ships Advance, Day Spring, and Ellerslie were in port.

At Bathurst the health was very good, but the trade was dull. The barque Le Grace, of Marseilles, was in port.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.668, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Prince Manna is doing great harm at the Boom River. As I wrote last month, there is no real and permanent remedy but to extend the boundaries of Sierra Leone to the frontiers of Liberia. The old slave-trade populations of the Coast, and their chiefs, must be under the strong hand, or they will perpetually kill and destroy. The traders of this colony and the poor labouring people of the invaded districts are the victims. To make slaves is the great object in view in all these petty barbarous wars.—Yours,', 'last_edit_date': '1863-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1863#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There is very little news by this mail. We regret to learn that the pacification of the Quia country had not yet been effected. Some fighting had occurred since our last Sierra Leone advices. Only one soldier of the Government forces was killed, and that by accident; but many of the rebels are said to have perished. Nearly all the stockades had been destroyed, and it was believed that the country would soon be quiet again.', 'last_edit_date': '1862-02-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_02_1862#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RAILWAY SCHEMES FOR SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'When there is a promise of a settled and peaceful state of affairs it is disappointing that it should not result in a greater flow of trade. There are various causes assigned for the depression in Sierra Leone. I may mention some of these. Stoppage of the slave traffic: A few years ago it was the practice of traders, called Banjuls, from Bathurst, to betake themselves to the riverine towns of the Protectorate, and purchase slaves brought from up-country, and take them back to Bathurst; and the money brought for this purpose was usually spent in Freetown. Again, traders from the Susu country and Futa Yallon used to drive cattle to Freetown, barter them there for trade guns, powder, and Manchester goods, proceed up country—preferably to those parts where slave raiding and tribal wars were going on—purchase the captives taken, and return with them to their own country. All this trade is now stopped, and I do not suppose any right-minded person can regret it when he considers the iniquities of the slave traffic. During my tour last year in the interior I released several parties of slaves consisting of men, women, and children, either shackled with chains or led along tied to one another with halters round their necks. Another cause of the depression has been attributed to the attitude assumed by the domestic slaves, who are not so subservient as formerly to their masters, who find it difficult to get them to gather the produce and send it to the markets. However, I have found that those masters who treat their slaves kindly do not lose them. Hundreds of slaves come every week to Freetown with trade canoes across from Bullom and the adjacent shores, and I have heard no complaints of their deserting their masters. A third cause assigned is the influx of Natives from the interior and the emigration of labourers. It is estimated that 6,000 labourers have proceeded to the Congo since the commencement of the year. This emigration may affect the producing power, but numbers of these labourers return with their wages, which they spend in the Colony; and those who come to Freetown and obtain work there convert their earnings into goods and return with them to their masters. The cessation of the raids and wars which supplied the slave traders, and the entire prohibition of the traffic, must revolutionise the system of trade, and probably accounts for some of the depression that has prevailed, which has been even more felt in French Guinea, as I am informed, than in the Colony of Sierra Leone.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1895#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Recent Disturbances in the Native Territories adjacent to Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': "A Blue-book has just been issued containing the correspondence between Sir S. Rowe, the Governor of Sierra Leone, and the Secretary of State for the Colonies with regard to the recent disturbances in the adjacent native territories. The correspondence commences with a letter dated October 7, 1885, from the Governor, stating that robberies had been frequent in Freetown, committed in many cases, it was alleged, by strangers, who carried away their booty up the river. In order to stop these practices, Sir S. Rowe entered into communications with representatives of the Timmannee States, with the result that certain persons were nominated by the chiefs to assist the local police in the detection of the offenders. Matters in the colony were considerably embarrassed by raids conducted by the turbulent Yonnie tribe upon their neighbours in British territory. In one of the despatches the Governor reported that in view of the critical state of the negotiations with the Yonnies, he had detained H.M.S. Tyne, with the relief of the head-quarters of the 2nd West India Regiment on board; and in the next he reported that the track from Maffuai had been cleared, and he hoped shortly to be able to visit the place. In a despatch dated January 30, he expresses his hope that the display of the electric mast-head light of Her Majesty's ship Racer, together with his words to them, would produce a beneficial result among the marauders. Pacific means, however, for some time seemed likely to fail, until, at a meeting on February 11, the Yonnie chiefs expressed their regret to Major Festing, the Commissioner, and asked pardon. In a despatch of the 9th of April, the Governor reports his reception on the previous day of the Yonnie chiefs, when they had formally expressed their regret for the raid on Songo-town. Considerable difficulty seems to have arisen from the smuggling engaged in by the natives, especially in connexion with the liquor traffic, which resulted in the withholding from one of the chiefs of his stipend until he could give satisfactory explanations. In a despatch dated May 12, Sir Samuel Rowe enclosed the copy of an agreement between the Chiefs of the Yonnie and Quiah clans of Timmannees, and the Bompeh Sherbros, whose quarrel had been the direct cause of the recent raid on Songo Town.

The Blue-book also contains three maps, in illustration of the correspondence. The first is a map of the Settlement of Sierra Leone, and the other two are rough sketches of the Lower Bompey and Shengay districts, and of the Cockboro river.", 'last_edit_date': '1886-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1886#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Outlook on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sierra Leone is one of the greatest possible examples of wasted opportunities. The attention of philanthropists was drawn to the beauty of the place and the excellence of the harbour and water supply, and here first in Africa was founded a home for the liberated slave.

Every experiment almost has been tried, and the effect has been to cause the people to consider the pursuit of agriculture as lowering, and to turn themselves to petty commerce and clerkships to obtain the means of livelihood, while the fertile soil scarcely produces enough for the support of its inhabitants. Some attempts have been made to form plantations and improve and increase the valuable natural products, and introduce plants suitable to the soil and climate, but the difficulties arising from the lack of suitable labour, from the apathy and indifference of those who should have fostered and nurtured the attempts, and a variety of other reasons, have caused most of these attempts to result in total or partial failure, and nearly all those who have embarked in the undertaking have had to abandon their hopes of success—and this not on account of the place being unfitted for the attempts, but because of the faults of the men employed.

Under happier auspices, and the home of an industrious and persevering race, the peninsula of Sierra Leone might be rendered a very garden, and the slopes of her mountains support a prosperous peasantry who would require the manufactures of our looms and mills, and be able to pay a remunerative price for them in produce obtained by pleasant toil from a fertile and smiling land.

But Sierra Leone is not only fitted for an agricultural colony; she is, or should be, the emporium of a large portion of Africa: she commands the nearest route to the head waters of the Niger, and the peoples who live on that route are traders, every one, and their countries produce many articles of value which they are only too glad to change for calicoes and other manufactured goods. The people at Sierra Leone are traders; surely, then,
**147**

Here we have a prosperous commerce; shame upon us, we have to confess that the most successful and enterprising house in Sierra Leone, Verminck et Cie. is a French one, and that they have almost monopolized the trade of Porto Lokko and the Rokelle.

The conduct of our Government at Sierra Leone at the present time requires careful handling, and at any moment we may be brought face to face with an incident compared with which the proprietorship of Matacong was a mere trifle, and which may cause a very unpleasant state of tension between this country and France.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FINANCIAL CONDITION OF THE COLONY OF SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is quite impossible for us to dismiss the very important subject of a deficiency of public revenue at Sierra Leone with the brief notice taken of it in our last. The interesting communications that we have lately inserted, made by persons but too deeply concerned in the Educational department of the colony, on which, with that of religious teaching—the Native Pastorate—the earliest discomforts of the position seem to have fallen, in strict accordance with the old official principles of government in the colony, appeal too strongly to our well-known sympathies and convictions to allow of our doing so. We have received so many letters during the last few months, in which the writers give most saddening pictures of the moral state and condition of the colony, which our personal experience of a too prevalent dishonesty only too fully confirms, that we look upon the curtailment of education and of public religious teaching with the most serious alarm for the future of the colony and for the reputation of Sierra Leoneans everywhere down the Coast. We are quite aware that the old enemies of the African people will point to those conditions of individual mind and practice which our correspondents stigmatize, and of which we complain, and say, "Education and religious teaching, forsooth! behold the fruits of them; we have had too much of them already. Some of the greatest cheats are men who have more than any other a redundancy of Scripture phrases at the tip of their tongue." But they are grossly mistaken. Bad as such men are, they would without doubt have been much worse under the semi-civilizing rule introduced by the British Government, had not the Church and Wesleyan Missionary Societies laboured assiduously to counteract by education and religious teaching the demoralizing effects of example, which has had in time past all the weight of authority and of European intelligence to commend it to African imitation. It is not difficult to account for the prevalent dishonesty without making education and familiarity with Scripture texts responsible for its origin. Not to allude further to example, as already mentioned, the presence of Europeans and the influence of European government have created a wide array of new wants, without providing any other means for obtaining the money necessary to their gratification than Government employment and the pursuits of trade. Handicraftsmen and mechanics there are. The necessities of an advancing civilization have induced these. But where is the organized or individual agricultural enterprise, which would confer wealth on the colony, and give wide-spread, ennobling, and remunerative employment? The production of staples for commerce is still, as in the olden time, a pursuit followed only by the uneducated aborigines in the interior. The result has been the creation of a trading class altogether out of proportion with the demand for European products in the interior, and the quantity of produce offering there for sale, and on which the entire commercial movement of the colony necessarily depends. We have long hoped to see some remedy found for this state of things, without which the healthful moral development, as well as the industrial development, of the colony is impossible. These hopes have been disappointed; and this is perhaps not a time to enter fully into a consideration of the causes that have led to that disappointment. We may say this, however, that sooner or later agricultural and other industrial pursuits connected with the soil must be made honourable in the eyes of the community, and the prevailing stigma of degradation (a curse originating in slave employment in the West India Islands, the United States, the Brazils, Cuba, and other countries into which the victims of an atrocious slave-trade were imported) be removed from it. Already we see the dawn of this happy day in Liberia, which has to depend entirely on its own resources; and we sincerely hope that Sierra Leone will follow suit. With this view we earnestly and emphatically deprecate all money grants by Great Britain to Sierra Leone. Sierra Leone must be made to depend entirely on its own revenues. If those revenues be insufficient for the public service of the colony as at present organized, the work of retrenchment must be at once commenced. A revenue of 80,000l. to 90,000l. a-year, or even a much smaller revenue, ought to suffice for all the legitimate wants of a settlement the population of which is about 40,000, as well as for those of the Sherbro'. There cannot be any valid reason for patching up a rotten state of things by grants from the Imperial Treasury. As old and tried friends of West Africa and its people, we protest against any contributions from the Exchequer of Great Britain to bolster up abuses in Sierra Leone, and thus prolong the existence of a state of things which is working the moral and industrial ruin of the settlement and its people. But that retrenchment, on which we feel thus bound to insist, ought never to have touched the School Department or the Native Pastorate. This is indeed beginning at the wrong end. Educate the people, endeavour to make Christians true and consistent Christians, of the people. This is first need; next after the necessary one of providing a', 'last_edit_date': '1876-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1876#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "MR. SIBTHORPE'S LETTER", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Although we had no previous knowledge of Mr. Sibthorpe or his labours, which, as now reported by him, entitle him to the warmest praise, we have without hesitation inserted his letter in full, bearing as it does upon a subject that has long seriously and painfully occupied our mind. The necessity of some great development of Sierra Leone mercantile resources has long been evident. The encroachments of the French in the neighbouring rivers greatly hinder that development; and it cannot be thought probable that the aids to Sierra Leone revenue now given by the Sherbro' countries will permanently continue. In Sherbro' everything seems to have been sacrificed to secure a large surplus revenue to augment the income of Sierra Leone. In many admirable communications from Sherbro' we have long since exposed the injustice with which that dependency has been treated. It is a country of great resources, but those resources are crippled by the disadvantages under which merchants and traders have there laboured, owing to the meagre and ill-paid official staff, the want of adequate protection, and the neglect of those improvements for which the duties levied on its trade would provide, and to which it is therefore justly entitled. It is self-evident that in the near future a much larger proportion of the amount annually derived from those duties must be spent in Sherbro'; that the much-needed improvements cannot be longer delayed; that there must be a largely-increased and better-paid staff; more expenditure for sanitary measures and for the supply of adequate public buildings; or that the Sherbro' must have a separate administration, as in the Gambia, when the whole of the revenue levied will have to be expended in the Sherbro' itself. The question of resources of Sierra Leone proper becomes therefore one of yearly increasing importance. With reference to this, we have never ceased to deplore the little attention that has been paid to agriculture, and the seeming absence of all research into the latent wealth of its territory. We were therefore greatly pleased to hear of the efforts making by Mr. Lardner to induce the cultivation of cocoa, coffee, ...", 'last_edit_date': '1879-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Alleged Atrocities in the Congo Free State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A recent number of the Sierra Leone *Weekly News* stated that the men from Sierra Leone and others who have ventured into the service of the Congo Free State are suffering terribly at the hands of their employers, who illuse them, break their engagements, intercept their communications with Sierra Leone, and, in a word, use them as slaves. It published the following letter from a correspondent at Stanley Falls, at the upper waters of the Congo: "Your countrymen of Sierra Leone are induced to come hither as workmen, and afterwards are compelled to serve as soldiers; they are contracted with for a salary to be paid in English money, and they are compelled to take their pay in inferior Belgian goods. Their food consists of fish dried many moons ago, and rice only. They are beaten with the 'chikote,' dried hippo hide, for the slightest reason or for no reason; the sick languish in wretched native huts, through which the rain and sun stream, and are denied either blankets or beds by the State. If they complain they are punished, and if they write to their friends or complain to the Governor of Sierra Leone the letters are opened and stopped by the officials. Men whose term of service has expired are kept in distant parts of the river. The natives are cruelly treated, their homes are burned, their property confiscated, and their wives and children reduced to bondage by the State. The State not only allows the slave trade to go on, it is itself engaged in the wholesale and retail traffic in human beings.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-01-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_01_1891#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Colony of Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': '| Year | United Kingdom | Colonies | Foreign | Total |
|------|----------------|----------|---------|-------|
| 1887 | £247,764       | £1,933   | £58,351 | £308,038 |
| 1888 | 190,529        | 1,211    | 58,407  | 250,147 |
| 1889 | 210,800        | 1,110    | 65,871  | 277,781 |
| 1890 | 295,012        | 1,627    | 93,269  | 389,908 |
| 1891 | 345,031        | 2,145    | 106,202 | 453,378 |

Of the imports in 1891 that entered for home consumption was £298,137, merchandise warehoused amounted to £146,553, and £8,688 worth of goods was transhipped. The increase in the value of importations in 1891 over those of 1890 was £63,470. The principal articles imported were—cotton goods, £139,954; spirits, £27,991; haberdashery, £23,679; tobacco, £22,253. The value of imports from the United Kingdom was thirty-four times that from France and ten times that from Germany.

**Exports.**

| Year | United Kingdom | Colonies | Foreign | Total |
|------|----------------|----------|---------|-------|
| 1887 | £120,188       | £15,695  | £197,634| £333,517 |
| 1888 | 166,569        | 17,651   | 154,823 | 339,043 |
| 1889 | 131,077        | 23,992   | 164,650 | 319,719 |
| 1890 | 147,436        | 21,043   | 180,840 | 349,319 |
| 1891 | 218,294        | 32,177   | 227,185 | 477,656 |

The value of produce exported was £329,751, and of European goods £137,905. The increase in the exports of 1891 over those of 1890 was £128,837, which was more than the total exports to the United Kingdom in 1887. Articles produced or manufactured in and exported from the Colony in 1891 were valued at £6,177, against £5,394 in the previous year. The chief exports were palm kernels £157,457, rubber £77,738, kola nuts £43,004, specie £36,231, palm oil £14,370, gum copal, £9,241, rice £8,291, and hides £7,112. The exports to the United Kingdom in 1891 was four times that to France, five times that to Germany, and twenty-five times that to the United States of America. These figures afford evidence that the trade of the Colony is expanding, a satisfactory feature in a community in which about one-sixth of the resident inhabitants is engaged in trading. Probably the large importations of recent years are not altogether the outcome of increased local consumption, as nearly one-half the imports find their way into the interior countries, and should more properly be classified as transit trade, the few ports in the Colony being mere commercial depots, where are landed the merchandise brought by vessels from different countries, whose manufactures find a market in this part of West Africa. Therefore the stability of the trade of Sierra Leone rests on the pacification of the producing areas which border upon it.

Freetown has become noted as a coaling station, and as it possesses an admirable harbour, a good provision market, and plenty of pure drinking water, it is much frequented by ships, as such supplies cannot be so readily obtained elsewhere on the coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1893#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SIERRA LEONE', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have received a copy of the report on the census of Sierra Leone and its dependencies. The duty of superintending the taking of the census in this Colony falls, it would appear, upon the Colonial Secretary, who seems to have done the work with much care and thoroughness. The total population is put down at 60,546, and of these only 134 are classed as "Whites." With the one exception of Belgium, every European nation, not to speak of the United States and the West Indies, is represented, the English, however, being in a large majority. The African nationalities which go to make up the native population are equally varied. Notwithstanding the fact that there are 140 ministers of religion in the Colony, and double that number of lay preachers, close upon 25 per cent. of the inhabitants are classed as "Pagans," and 5,000 of the balance as Mahomedans. Of the total population 23 per cent. are put down as traders and hawkers. Mr. Griffith asks, "What good can come of a country where one-fourth of the people are dependent for their livelihood upon what they sell to the remaining three quarters?" and he urges that "some measures should be adopted to force these people to discontinue an occupation so manifestly prejudicial to their own advancement as well as to the country."

generally, and oblige them to engage in labours of production." Whatever may be thought of this somewhat startling suggestion, it is evident from the return before us that Sierra Leone is dependent for whatever prosperity it may enjoy to the transient traders and strangers who bring in the articles which the surrounding country furnishes—gold, rubber, beeswax, gum, copal, &c. The native inhabitants are too indolent to labour continuously, and Sierra Leone has little to offer the European but fever.—*Echo.*', 'last_edit_date': '1881-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1881#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sierra Leone and Its People', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A stroll through the town is very interesting. There are no wheeled vehicles whatever in the place, and the roadways are covered with grass. Excepting in one or two of the principal streets, the houses by the sides of the road stand in gardens full of trees, whose branches stretch over the pathway and afford protection against the rays of the sun. Most people walk, but a few are carried about in a hammock swung from a piece of wood which is borne on the shoulders of four sturdy natives, much in the same way as a palanquin is carried in India. The bearers proceed at a rapid pace, with an easy gliding motion which renders this form of locomotion very comfortable and enjoyable in a climate like that of Sierra Leone, where the thermometer rarely goes much below eighty. Although vehicular traffic is absent, there is no lack of life in the streets of Freetown. The main thoroughfares are crowded with people, and there is plenty of animation and bustle. Fat, jolly-looking negresses, with bright coloured Manchester kerchiefs wound picturesquely round their woolly heads, sit at the street corners presiding over baskets of native produce. Native dandies, attired in what they probably consider the height of fashion, lounge about the principal shops, eyeing the passers-by. There is a cheerful air about all, and every one appears to take life easily. Negroes are proverbially merry-hearted, but I did not know how merry was their disposition until I had been to Sierra Leone, and had an opportunity of seeing them in their own homes. They laugh and joke incessantly, and it is a rare thing to see a sour or unhappy face amongst them. English is the principal language spoken, and most of the shops are for the sale of English goods. One long street is full of shops devoted to the sale of Manchester prints and Birmingham hardware. Amongst the latter I noticed a number of flimsy-looking rifles, which, I imagine, would do more injury to the persons who fired them than to those they were fired at, and a quantity of cheap swords, equally effective in appearance. These articles, I suppose, have a value here, as there is a great demand for them in the interior, and they constitute an important medium of exchange, without which commercial transactions could not be carried through. The names upon the shops are English, and also the notices, which sometimes are of a quaint character; but the retail trade is entirely in the hands of the natives. The export trade consists chiefly of coconuts, benniseed, ginger, ground nuts, and other natural products, and the imports of ale and porter, wine and spirits, and manufactured goods of various kinds.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1888#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sierra Leone and Its People', 'section_title': '', 'content': "I had looked forward to my trip to Sierra Leone with much interest, because I was anxious to see this interesting colony, and judge for myself the character of negro civilization. I was not disappointed in my anticipation of an entertaining and instructive visit; but I must confess that I was surprised to find that Sierra Leone possesses the claim it does to natural beauty. I had heard and read so much of its unhealthiness that I had pictured to myself a low-lying swampy coast, fringed with mangrove bushes, and with the other accompaniments of a malarial climate. This imaginary sketch bore not the slightest resemblance to the truth. In the place of a flat, low-lying district I found a mountainous tract of country, formed by two rivers which nearly intersect it. The general appearance of this Sierra is picturesque in the extreme. The sky line is broken by the irregular outline of a number of conical peaks, covered to their summits with lofty forests, which give to the distant scenery a rich and romantic appearance. Freetown is situated on the shore of a beautiful bay, hemmed in by a grand amphitheatre of hills, covered with vegetation. The distance between the town and the base of the mountains varies from three-quarters of a mile to a mile and a half, the intervening space being broken by numerous grass-clad undulations.

Hills ascend almost in regular gradation until they reach the highest peak, and as they are well wooded, the *coup d'œil* is striking and beautiful. A fairer situation for a town can scarcely be imagined, and if the sad experience of the past did not teach us the contrary, it would be pronounced healthy. There is no room to doubt, however, that Sierra Leone is extremely unhealthy, and epidemics of fever occur from time to time which sweep off large numbers of the population. This fever is peculiarly deadly to Europeans, and at the time when there was a European garrison the mortality was immense, whole families being occasionally carried off during one visitation. Happily, few Europeans are now sent to this deadly climate, and the number is yearly decreasing. At the census of 1881 there were only 160 resident whites in the whole of Sierra Leone. The colony is garrisoned by half a West India Regiment, and a considerable naval force is maintained on the coast to protect British interests.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1888#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: The Ashantees' economic dependencies on coastal trade and European goods influenced their alliances and conflicts with neighboring tribes, including the Fantees, who criticized Ashantee trade restrictions while European commercial interests exacerbated regional tensions.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a comprehensive view of the Ashantees' economic dependencies and their influence on regional alliances and conflicts. Both sources highlight the Ashantees' reliance on coastal trade, which was crucial for their economic survival and for obtaining war supplies, such as guns, powder, and lead from European trading posts like the Bremen factory at Quitta. This dependency is further underscored by their need for coastal goods like salt, which maintained relative peace until internal pressures for conflict arose. The General History of Africa notes the Ashante's struggle to control these trading posts and the economic shifts following the abolition of the slave trade, emphasizing their reliance on coastal commerce. Both sources discuss tensions with neighboring tribes, particularly the Fantees, who criticized Ashantee trade restrictions and were frustrated by the Ashantees' refusal to allow free passage through their territory, hindering trade with inland tribes. The textbook details conflicts with other Akan peoples, such as the Akyem and Akuapem, over trade route closures, perceived by the Ashante as rebellion. Both sources agree that European commercial interests exacerbated regional tensions, with the textbook mentioning British government involvement and treaties affecting trade routes, while The African Times criticizes British authorities for enabling Ashantee access to supplies through open ports. Together, these observations support the claim that economic dependencies significantly influenced the Ashantees' alliances and conflicts, while also highlighting the role of European interests in these regional tensions.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that align with the claim regarding the Ashantees' economic dependencies and their influence on alliances and conflicts. The text highlights the Ashante's struggle to control European trading posts on the coast, which were crucial for their economic survival, indicating a dependency on coastal trade. The abolition of the slave trade, a significant export for the Gold Coast, led to economic shifts, further emphasizing the Ashante's reliance on coastal commerce. The Ashante's political domination efforts over other Akan peoples, including the Fante, are noted, with conflicts arising from trade route closures by the Akyem and Akuapem, perceived by the Ashante as rebellion. This supports the claim of tensions with neighboring tribes over trade restrictions. Additionally, the text mentions European commercial interests exacerbating regional tensions, as seen in the British government's involvement and treaties affecting trade routes and political control. However, the text does not explicitly mention the Fante criticizing Ashantee trade restrictions, which is a difference from the claim. Overall, the textbook supports the claim's assertion of economic dependencies influencing Ashantee alliances and conflicts, while providing a broader context of European involvement in regional tensions.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that align with the claim regarding the Ashantees' economic dependencies and their influence on regional alliances and conflicts. The articles highlight the Ashantees' reliance on coastal trade, particularly for war supplies, as evidenced by the mention of the Bremen factory at Quitta supplying the Ashantees with guns, powder, and lead. This dependency on coastal trade is further emphasized by the Ashantees' need for salt and other goods from the coast, which kept them relatively peaceful until their war captains pushed for conflict. The articles also discuss the tensions between the Ashantees and the Fantees, with the latter criticizing Ashantee trade restrictions and expressing frustration over the Ashantees' refusal to allow free passage through their territory, which hindered trade with inland tribes. Additionally, European commercial interests are noted to exacerbate regional tensions, as seen in the criticism of British authorities for allowing the Ashantees to obtain supplies through open ports and the historical context of European settlers' involvement in local conflicts. These details support the claim by illustrating how economic dependencies and trade dynamics influenced the Ashantees' alliances and conflicts with neighboring tribes, including the Fantees, while also highlighting the role of European interests in these tensions.
