[{'id': 309, 'article_title': 'Okeodan and Addo', 'full_section_title': 'Okeodan and Addo', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-24', 'issue_date': '23_01_1864', 'content': 'The recent establishment of protectorates over Okeodan and Addo by the Government of this colony, has, no doubt, received the approbation of the Government at home, as a measure of so great importance to the future prosperity of Lagos merits. That this step will prove the salvation of Lagos, in a commercial point of view, there can be no doubt. Porto Novo having been allowed to slip from our grasp into the hands of the French, had already caused immense damage to the trade of this place, and the extent of that injury would have been increased a hundredfold, had the French been allowed to add Okeodan and Addo to their possessions. Merchants here did not fail speedily to appreciate the value of the acquisition made by this Government; and if those at home interested in the welfare of Lagos will glance at the map, and reflect for a moment on the state of our relations with Porto Novo and Abeokuta, they cannot fail at once to perceive the great danger that we have escaped by securing to ourselves the possession of Okeodan and Addo, together with the river of the latter name, instead of allowing the French to occupy them. Were any proof needed of the value of those places to us, and of the important influence which their possession will exercise on the future of Lagos, the great dissatisfaction felt and experienced both by the French and the Egbas would furnish it.

The French, who expected to reap so much benefit from the possession of Porto Novo, which they intended should form their starting-point from which to establish an extensive trade with the interior—Abeokuta of course included—and also the nucleus of a large colony, whose limits might be *indefinitely enlarged*, find their projects nipped in the very bud; they see themselves deprived of what they looked upon as their easiest, most direct, and most available means of access to Abeokuta and the interior; and one of the largest markets of the neighbourhood closed to them. The French had already cast longing eyes upon Okeodan; and that they would have taken possession of it, had not this Government been beforehand with them, is undeniable; for they did not conceal that intention. If the annexation of these places could be of any value to the French, their possession is doubtless of equal importance to us; in fact, I may say of very much greater importance to us. A policy of exclusion and monopoly may in general be erroneous, and contrary to English ideas; but with such neighbours as the French to deal with, we must meet them with their own weapons. We know how they act at Senegal, Goree, Grand Bassam, and Gaboon, some of which places are entirely closed to foreign commerce; while at the others it is placed on such a footing as to be almost a nullity.'}, {'id': 2966, 'article_title': 'The Proposed Exchange of Settlements on the West Coast', 'full_section_title': 'The Proposed Exchange of Settlements on the West Coast', 'last_edit_date': '09-04-1875', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1875#article-19', 'issue_date': '01_10_1875', 'content': 'As to the Gaboon, having a competent knowledge of all the native tribes inhabiting that region, and speaking several of their languages or dialects, I am able to state with confidence that no complications with them need be feared, in consequence of their allegiance being transferred to us from the French, as they are timid and unwarlike, and totally devoid of any such organization or government as exists in Asyanti or Dahomé; moreover, being ardently fond of trade, and knowing that the presence of the French has, if anything, tended more to impede than to accelerate the development of the resources of their country, and has undoubtedly tended, in a very considerable degree, to keep British capital and enterprise out of the field, they would welcome the advent of the English with enthusiasm and delight. I have more than once been requested by the chiefs and people now under French rule to write on their behalf to the English Government to take possession of their country, in order to prevent the French from doing so, as they foresaw inevitably would be the case in the ordinary course of events, and as has now come to pass.

The Gaboon settlement or territory, with its dependencies, extends from about 50 min. north latitude to 2 deg. south latitude, and includes not only the Gaboon proper, but also Cape Lopez and the rivers Mexias, Fernan Vas, and Ogowé; the latter, although so little known to European geographers, being the great artery of, and most direct highway into, Equatorial Africa. I have myself explored its course for a distance of nearly 300 miles from its mouth, and at my furthest point the natives are completely ignorant of its source or origin, which may probably be looked for in one of the vast central lakes, if, indeed, it be not the long-sought outlet of Tanganyika, which Lieutenant Cameron is supposed to have lately discovered, and is now exploring to the sea. As far as is yet known, its course lies directly under the Equator, and this fine river runs through a region rich in ivory, india-rubber, ebony, and other products of great value, the Gaboon ivory being well known as the finest in the world; whilst the climate is very good for West Africa, and infinitely better than that of the Gambia, Sierra Leone, the Gold Coast, or Lagos. The estuary of the Gaboon is the safest and most commodious harbour on the whole West Coast, easily accessible to ships of the largest class, and wherein thousands of vessels could ride at anchor at the same time. The trade of Gaboon, as also that of Grand Bassam, is already chiefly in the hands of British traders, whilst that of the Gambia is principally in the hands of French merchants or, to speak more correctly, the produce of the latter river goes almost entirely to France, where it is utilized, but has never been so in England.'}, {'id': 4630, 'article_title': 'THE FRENCH IN WEST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE FRENCH IN WEST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1883#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_06_1883', 'content': '

In West Africa. Since our last, as our readers will perceive, the French have established themselves at Black Point, and in other territory in the neighbourhood of the River Congo; they have resumed a Protectorate over Porto Novo in the neighbourhood of Lagos; they have "called in" at Bonny and proposed to enter into treaties (as a preliminary no doubt to a protectorate) with our friend King Peppel. We ask again, What does all this mean? With the Madagascar and Tonquin business on their hands, why this display of small energy on the West Coast of Africa? Can it be that the appetite for the River Gambia has of late increased in strength, and that it is wished to have as many insignificant points as possible to yield in exchange for that magnificent possession, for a most valuable ore it would undoubtedly be in the hands of those who already possess the "Senegal," and are at present the great purchasers of its chief produce—"ground nuts"—from which the oil is expressed at Marseilles, where it becomes "fine Lucca," "best Olive"? But why, we shall be asked, why do you, you who have been calling incessantly upon your own Government to annex the sea-coast from Quittah to Whydah, and to take possession of Porto Novo, and to assume some sort of governing power over the Oil Rivers, why do you complain of French aggression and occupation? In the first place, the circumstances and conditions of Great Britain and France are essentially different; and, in the second, Great Britain differs in its occupations and annexations of foreign barbarous countries, from all other civilized powers. Since the erring and disastrous attempt to tax the people of her then North American colonies, for the benefit of the mother country, Great Britain has never sought to derive revenue for the Imperial exchequer from any of her beyond sea possessions. Until she adopted and put into universal practice in her colonies and possessions (such as had not legislatures of their own) of the principles of free trade, every acquisition of territory in West Africa, or Fiji, or New Guinea, or elsewhere, is an occupation by her for the benefit and advantage of the manufacturers and commercial people of every other state and power. She holds and administers for the general benefit of the people whom she and her subjects are seeking to civilize, and of the world at large. Not from any one of her Colonies or possessions does she draw one farthing of revenue into and for the benefit of the Imperial exchequer. But France, if she takes possession of territory, establishes therein her exclusive system. She takes possession for the benefit of French manufacturing industry, and shipping, and commerce, to the exclusion of all other. Let her open the ports of her Colonies and possessions to the British flag and to British commerce, as Great Britain opens hers to the French flag and to French commerce, and no one would hail with more pleasure than we should do her "occupation," however extensive, of the uncivilized portions of the habitable world. But even then she should do what is worthy of a great nation, and not make little, unworthy, pettifogging attacks upon the tranquillity of semi-civilized people. We had intended in this number of our journal to have entered at large upon this subject, in consequence of her recent action at Black Point, Porto Novo, and Bonny. But "the unexpected," which so often frustrates the carrying out of human intentions, prevents our doing so; and we are compelled to content ourselves with blaming anew the British Government for its culpable indifference to the welfare of Lagos, in turning a deaf ear to all the entreaties of which the friends of Lagos have been prodigal, that possession should be taken of Porto Novo, and the barbarous cruelties of its abominable rulers be put an end to by the enforcement of British Law. We feel this very much. We were partly influential in obtaining the occupation and annexation of Lagos; and we always urged that its Government should be made to embrace Porto Novo. We were opposed in this by the old influence that made of Whydah a depôt for free African labourers for the French plantations, as a substitute for the suppressed African Slave Trade. We had hoped that influence had abandoned the Lagos Waters, and was now operating only on the East of Africa and in Madagascar. But we must defer further remarks until our next issue.'}, {'id': 4715, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN SETTLEMENTS', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN SETTLEMENTS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_11_1883', 'content': 'Under the title of "Europe in Africa," the *Indépendence Belge* gives a lengthy article describing the various settlements made by each of the Great European States in different parts of the Black Continent. The writer criticises somewhat severely, though in a friendly tone, the policy pursued by France towards its colonial possessions in general, and those in Africa in particular. This, with the frequent changes in policy natural to a Government which is always being changed, has "prevented them from attaining the prosperity at which they might otherwise have arrived." As for England, her policy is described as prevailing not only in the ten colonies which she owns in the continent, but almost everywhere throughout the central and equatorial parts of it. The Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch, and German possessions are then mentioned, and a claim is put in on behalf of Belgium, not, indeed to actual territorial possession, but to a number of commercial settlements owning some local property. It is, as the Belgians assert, their legitimate boast that, on the initiative of King Leopold II, they opened the Congo to the navigation of the world. It is, therefore, with this part of Africa that they have the most to do. They have established a joint-stock company, called the "Belgian Company of African Commerce," which was incorporated in March, 1882, with a capital of 10,000l. Of this sum about 2,000l. was spent in the purchase of the vessel Akassa, which is, no doubt, destined to do wonders on the Congo river. It is intended to increase the company till it has a capital of 600,000 francs, and ultimately two or even five millions of francs. At present it seems that the subscribers to it are chiefly English. But it is necessary to avoid confusing the company with the two others also having French names, that is, the International African Association and the Comité des Etudes du Haut Congo.'}, {'id': 4724, 'article_title': 'THE FRENCH IN WEST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE FRENCH IN WEST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-20', 'issue_date': '01_11_1883', 'content': 'If the old "Quem vult perdere," which applied equally to nations as to individuals, had not been so hackneyed, we should undoubtedly have chosen it as a fitting introduction to what we feel bound to write as regards the late, and present external action of the French Government, which seems to us to have placed France upon the slippery plank at the bottom of which lies disaster, if not ruin. It would be impossible, we think, for even the most unreasoning admirer of France, its people, and its Government, to find cause for eulogy in the late external action of the Paris cabinet. With Annam and Tonquin we have nothing to do, though we may have formed our opinions on the subject. As regards Madagascar, we consider the French action, prompted by the Réunion planters, as so certain to lead, if successful, to a new revival of the African slave trade, either open or under the pretence of apprenticeship, or free labour contracts, that, as such, and as a wanton aggression on a community of the African race that has been for some time steadily progressing on the road to civilization, we do not hesitate to give it our most emphatic condemnation. The Government of Liberia, like that of Madagascar, refuses to allow white men to obtain a settlement on any portion of its land by purchase; and although this has greatly interfered with the development of the resources of the country, by shutting out European capital and energy, we can find quite enough in the history of past relations of Europeans with the people of Africa to excuse this policy of isolation. Behind every European acquiring, by purchase, landed possessions in such a country, there looms the national government of that European in the distance, as almost certain to become a factor in any dispute that might arise between him and the authorities. With equal justice, therefore, might France make demands upon Liberia, as upon Madagascar, on the ground of refusal to allow French subjects to become freeholders. What most concerns us, however, as regards the present external action of the French Government, is that portion of it which embraces west and south-west Africa in its disturbing course. We have before alluded to and condemned (and it will bear repetition) the most unfriendly action of France in taking the wretched King Tofa, of Porto Novo, under its protection. We repeat, situate as Porto Novo is with regard to Lagos, together with the non-existence of any real French interest there, the acceptance of a Protectorate by France was about as offensively unfriendly an action as can well be conceived. The French mercantile house that counselled it, has performed about as questionable service to France as was performed by the Portuguese slave trader who led the French Government into a similar measure some twenty years ago. No good can come of it to France, and much evil may. We and all other advocates of the rights of humanity, must now hold her responsible for all the horrors it may please her atrocious protege, King Tofa, to commit. We have a right to demand, in the interests of humanity and civilization, that the French Protectorate of Porto Novo shall be characterized and justified by the absolute repression of those fearful customs in which it has pleased King Tofa and his predecessors to indulge. Such repression has characterized the action of Great Britain in West Africa, and the way in which she has thus exercised her power for freeing the poor wretched victims of tyranny and superstition constitute, in our mind, her only just claim to rule there. Her keeping peace among the natives, and suppressing all slavery and slave trade, so far as within her power; affording protection to trade and commerce, and laying the foundation of civilization on which the natives may hereafter build—these, we say, and to afford protection for philanthropic and missionary enterprise, are her raison d'etre, on the West Coast. There is no doubt—there can be no doubt—that she might do this work better than she does, if more enlightened councils prevailed in Downing Street; still, what she has done, has been greatly instrumental for good. To feel this fully we have only to imagine what the West Coast of Africa would have been without persistent British interference and guardianship there. And it must always be borne in mind that the imperial exchequer does not receive one farthing from her settlements and possessions, and the protected trade there; while under her liberal free trade system, the ships, subjects, and goods of every other civilized power, European or American, have the same advantages as her own. In a word, she keeps the greater portion of West Africa open to trade and commerce for the benefit of the whole world. Now, the French Colonial system is the very reverse of this. Her protective and prohibitive regulations are in full force at Goree and Senegal; and, by intelligence lately received, we can have no doubt that France is anxious to confer similar benefits on other portions of the West Coast. The French admiral who took Porto Novo under French protection, looked in upon other places on his way down the coast. He made overtures to the King of Bonny, which the king and chief, who have received education in England, were too wise to listen to. And now we learn further that he has proposed to establish a French factory at Old Calabar, and that King Duke Ephraim IX., whose coronation under the auspices of the British consul and the Rev. W. Anderson, we some time since gave an account of, has held a grand council and petitioned the French Government to induce French traders to settle there. Those who do not know anything of the West Coast would suppose from this that French traders were hitherto denied trade with Old Calabar; which, under British consular auspices, has been open for trade to all the world from the period at which Great Britain put a final end to the slave trade there. The intended process is clear. A French factory under Government auspices, perhaps managed by Messrs. Regis, of Marseilles, Lagos, and Porto Novo, who have manipulated the Porto Novo protectorate—a dispute with the natives—French Government demands redress—protection—occupation—a French exclusive trading station, to the exclusion of our Liverpool and German merchants, who now do the great oil trade there.'}, {'id': 4879, 'article_title': 'GERMAN COLONIZATION IN AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'GERMAN COLONIZATION IN AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': '07-01-1884', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1884#article-22', 'issue_date': '01_07_1884', 'content': 'have any real right to Angra Pequeña, there is no reason why we should not assert it; but at most, it does not extend beyond one or two of the islands in the bay. It would be an unwise dog-in-the-manger policy to manufacture difficulties as to the German occupation. If Germany wishes to acquire colonies in Africa or elsewhere, it is, we think, our interest to encourage her in her enterprise. Germany, next to Great Britain and France, is the greatest trading nation in Europe, and her trade in recent years has been extending with marvellous rapidity. In this respect she is no doubt a competitor with us; but her competition is robust and healthy, and can do us no real harm. So far as we can see, nothing but good could result from having her as a neighbour in South Africa; her traders and colonists would set themselves energetically to develop the resources of a continent that needs nothing more than earnest workers. The one chief objection to French colonization is that it paralyses the unrestricted development of every region to which it spreads, and hence the desirability of preventing France obtaining an exclusive hold over such an important artery of trade as the Congo. If we can judge from the example of Angra Pequeña, the Germans are more likely to follow the English method of colonization than the French. With England the flag has generally followed where the trader led and established himself, whereas with France the flag is, as a rule, forced on regions where her traders have never been.'}, {'id': 5221, 'article_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'full_section_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'last_edit_date': '10-01-1885', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_10_1885', 'content': 'After the 1870 war the French, then more intent on healing their wounds at home than on extending their colonies, were desirous of exchanging the Gaboon for the Gambia. Any one who has seen the two places must wonder why we did not accept their offer. The French were then desirous of consolidating their possessions, and for long after our refusal to treat for the exchange the work of exploration by De Brazza starved.

This exploration has led to the addition to the colony of the Gaboon of the countries between it and the Congo, which may soon offer an important field for trade, and probably contain a trade route to the equatorial and northern portion of the Congo, which will compete with that of Mr. Stanley. Our commercial relations with France since the abrogation of the Cobden Treaty have been such that we have been unable to safeguard the interests of our merchants in French possessions beyond the seas, but perhaps nowhere except in the Gaboon have English ships been forced to haul down the English ensign and hoist the tricolour before being allowed to trade in certain territorial waters! The French in the Gaboon have acted on a principle of exclusion, and though a portion of the territory is bound by the Free-trade rules, we may feel certain that the English merchant, though he may legally stand on an equal footing with the French trader, will find that his position is very different, and that many obstacles are put in the way of his competing on equal terms with his rivals. The Congo is now the scene of one of the greatest experiments that has ever been tried in international law. The establishment of trade and the opening of communications cannot be brought about in a few months, and if some of the utopian descriptions we have heard of the thousands and millions of yards of calico which the teeming multitudes of Central Africa will require are to be taken as the basis of calculation in estimating the future trade of these districts, those who accept will be doomed to disappointment.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': "This consideration having been stated, it may be well to turn to the other class, the conduct of other nations in West Africa. Some thirteen years ago, France obtained possession of the Gaboon. Since then she has extended her claims to the Masabe River, eighty miles north of the Congo. Duties are levied for the maintenance of her establishment, which the traders had not coveted, and is harassing and destructive of commerce. Only on the points of land actually occupied has she any authority whatever. The natives are hostile, and wherever French authority can be exercised, the chiefs have been reduced to helpless poverty. Does a trader wish to establish commercial relations with a coast tribe on French territory 100 miles from Gaboon? He has to pay the same duties as in Gaboon; but if any dispute arise with the natives he gets no protection. Those parts have flourished most where the natives' ideas were studied, and the traders' actions regulated accordingly, where the delusion has not taken root that trade can flourish while the native villages are burning, and chains put on the customers. In the Gaboon and Ojowé rivers, all craft are required to fly the French flag, except ocean-going vessels. Hence have resulted attacks on English vessels by the natives under the impression that they belonged to the French Government! The American Protestant Mission were forbidden to teach the children English; French only would be tolerated. In Loango the chiefs were ordered to contribute a certain number of men, to be shipped to Gaboon and drilled as soldiers. The young men failed to present themselves, and so the French authorities refuse to allow youths to leave the country, though work elsewhere is plentiful. So great is the fear of the natives by the French Government in Gaboon, that traders are not allowed to possess a rifle or a revolver, lest they should sell them to the natives!", 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the course of some excellent articles which have appeared lately in the *Manchester Guardian*, dealing with the present and future trade prospects of Africa, we have one chapter devoted to the consideration of the drawbacks upon genuine commerce by the enforcement of such quasi-regal rights as those exercised by Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, and the rest of that host of petty kinglings, in the districts of the West Coast. The article in question says:—

One of the ways in which the development of trade must be carried out is by pushing factories up beyond the tribes who now serve as middlemen between the European trader and the native producer. Some difficulty will no doubt be encountered in passing through the unhealthy and malarious districts in which these middlemen live, but the improved knowledge we are obtaining of how to combat climatic diseases will render such an enterprise more easy than it would have been twenty years ago. Indeed, if we contrast the early reports of the Niger with its present exploitation, we may believe that the climate of no tropical country will permanently prevent its being opened up to commerce. This is a ray of hope for our African traders, and it is to be hoped that our Government will enable them to avail themselves of it speedily, and not allow them to be forestalled by the merchants of other nations. As if the inaction of our Government had not been sufficiently disastrous to the trade of the African merchants of Liverpool and Manchester, the home legislation of the last few years has also done much to hamper their enterprise. One industry alone, which, though it may be considered a small one, came in the aggregate to a considerable amount, has been completely driven out of the country. The trade in matches to the West Coast used to be supplied by Manchester. Now, the children who used to be employed in their manufacture are sent to school hungry, while German matches are sent in German ships to those who used to buy the English ones, and the only profit to English people is that of the middleman, and even that is being rapidly taken from them.

The German and French textile manufactures are also running us close, and we have to watch carefully the change of fashions and ideas among the natives. Many cheap articles made in France, with a ready sale on the coast, could easily be made in England. Some of the native manufactures could easily be imitated, such as the Niger cloths and the silk and cotton cloths made by the Santees and Ashantees of unravelled European stuffs. Beyond the Oil rivers to the south we have the French colony of the Gaboon, which has now become one of the largest tracts of Africa controlled by an European nation. In the old portion of the colony trade is not so flourishing as it used to be, English enterprise having been driven away by the action of protection and differential duties.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Deputation to Lord Knutsford', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"As regards the colony of Gambia, it was but natural that British traders would object to give their colony and trade to France for what the French possessed between Pongas river and the Gaboon, as the French had only the Assinie and Porto Novo territory, both of little value. Besides, they expected our own people would keep the hinterland of the Gambia and not let the French hem them in. Again, if the exchange had been made, it would not have prevented the French getting behind us at Sierra Leone, the inland territory not being between the places named.

"Then there is the Tabou territory on the Kroo coast. The real ruler of this place is an Englishman who has lived there for twenty years, and holds deeds of ownership of the land. This gentleman called at the Colonial Office years ago with the documents in question, and besought the authorities to take over the country. They refused, and when the matter was again brought up by the recent deputation they were told that the territory had been taken over by France.

"Something of the same kind took place as regards the island of Matacong. At present it is owned by an Englishman, leased by an Englishman, and the owner was told the other day by Lord Knutsford that it was French territory.

"You cite Liberia in your article as a place where a profitable trade may yet be done. Well, this is a poor solace. It is not creditable to a Government that its subjects should have to give up trading in its settlements and go into the colony of a neighbouring Government to make a living.

"There is also the question of the Gold Coast settlement. We have not the assurance that the hinterland there has been secured to us. On the contrary, what may we not fear from the mission of M. Binger? Look what France is doing in West Africa. Railways at Konakry and St. Louis, spending £250,000 on a pier at Kotonu, near Lagos; all this apart from her numerous expeditions.

"After all, the sum total of the whole question is this. We have a coast colony, and to feed that colony we should have the inland trade. The territory whence emanates this trade is suddenly taken away from our influence by a country whose interest is to divert it to its own colonies. We cannot get the inland territory under our own influence again, and our coast colony may become a seaport without a trade. What steps can we take to nullify the effect of the change and bring back the trade to the colony? Hitherto the Government has been looked up to for guidance, protection, and direction, but, in view of the interests which have been recently sacrificed, the African trade is determined to speak out unmistakably for itself in future, whatever Government may be in power.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-01-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'French Influence on the Congo', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The author of "Le Congo Français" has no faith whatever in the Conference. Nothing can come of it. The only solution is an amicable division of the Congo between the Powers chiefly interested. But whatever may happen, we are not for a moment to be encouraged to believe that France will hear of Free Trade. Protection under one form or another is not only a necessary condition of colonial commerce and colonization in Africa, but it is absolutely necessary if we wish to supply this commerce with the products of our own industry; and the less our industry at home is encouraged and protected the more necessary will it be to protect and encourage it in Africa, if we are to maintain, what we seek above all things in colonization, openings for our industry. This is a very delicate way of putting it, that colonial extension in Africa is to substitute protection in trade among the natives for the concessions which France is compelled to allow at home.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1885#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.668, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE BRITISH POSITION ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In continuation of a series of articles upon the British Colonies, which have been appearing lately in the Times, our contemporary contains the following communication upon the present situation in the West African Colonies:—

British trading interests in West Africa have taken alarm at the position and influence which have been acquired by France, and dissatisfaction has been expressed with Lord Knutsford's reply to the deputation of merchants that waited upon him. The members of the deputation seem to have been imperfectly acquainted with the later developments of French activity in the regions under discussion, and not to have realized the force of the successive treaties by which the political spheres of the two countries have been gradually enclosed within geographical limits. Yet the negotiations between the two Governments which led up to the treaty of last year have been from time to time made public in all essential points. That treaty was intended to form the last link of a chain of agreements which should simplify the relations of the two Powers in that part of Africa, and it is now too late to urge the extension of our political influence into a sphere which has been assigned to France. It is impossible, in territories where the frontier is still vague, for one civilised Government to refuse to acknowledge treaties submitted to it by another on the ground that native signatories of the treaty desire to repudiate it. If such a principle were admitted the only result would be a speedy return to the primitive reign of force. Peaceful agreements with native chiefs would have no meaning, and the civilisation of barbarous countries must be preceded by military occupation. Nor should it be forgotten that if the present position of France in relation to English settlements upon the West Coast of Africa is displeasing to English merchants, they have themselves to thank for the fact that any French settlements now exist.
3

...ween the River Pongas and the Gaboon. Had the merchants of the Gambia and the Chambers of Commerce of this country been willing to acquiesce in the cession of the Gambia to France in 1876, all French territory lying between that colony and the Gaboon would have passed into English hands.", 'last_edit_date': '1892-01-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1892#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Intrigues of the French in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A special general meeting of the members of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce was held on July 11, Mr. G. Hutchinson presiding. The especial business of the meeting was a discussion on "The French at Abeokuta."

The Chairman, in opening the proceedings, pointed out that if the French obtained possession of the river Ogan, an important highway into the interior of Africa, they would be in a position to cut down and interfere with the trade and prospects of Lagos. The French had induced several of the native chiefs to sign an agreement for a French protectorate, and they were now endeavouring to induce the King to do the same by a promise of £3,000. It was of the utmost importance, therefore, to British trade that some steps should be taken to prevent the French from getting this treaty ratified, and to prevent any European Power who, like the French and Germans, had taken small strips of land on the borders of Lagos, from interfering with the commerce and duties of the colony.

Mr. Barker (Secretary) read correspondence from natives and agents at Lagos on the subject. It appeared that Abeokuta is a large and populous place in the kingdom of Agbas, and the seat of the Government emporium of trade from the interior. Since 1843 the English had been in the place, and had taught the natives many useful employments. The English merchants and missionaries established the present trade in palm oil and kernels to counteract the Transatlantic slave trade. The place had lately been visited by a French officer disguised as a trader, and he had concluded arrangements with several native chiefs to divert the trade to Porto Novo, which was under the protection of France, and to close the roads to Lagos. If the revenue of the latter place, which was really only a sandy island, fell off, the Government would be compelled to abandon it.

The Chairman said that it appeared to him that the object of the French was to get behind the English all the way along the coast. He thought it would be a good thing either to pass a resolution authorizing Mr. Barker to write to the Government on the subject, or to arrange for a deputation to go to London.

Mr. C. J. Morris said that the French were developing their trade very rapidly on the coast. In place of employing a few sailing ships, as they did a few years ago, they had now steamers carrying some hundreds of tons. Things had altered very greatly within the last few years. There was a very large amount of trade now being developed to French coasts which', 'last_edit_date': '1888-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE WITH THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. J. F. Hutton said that for years past the Manchester Chamber of Commerce had been in correspondence with the Colonial Office in reference to the West Coast of Africa, and had constantly called attention to the neglect of the authorities to attend to the interests of our trade, and to the responsibilities that ought to be undertaken in connexion with it. This trade especially concerned Manchester and the district around, because the bulk of the goods that went to the West Coast were cotton goods. For that reason, the Manchester Chamber of Commerce felt greatly interested in this question, and they asked the Government to consider whether they could not accept a greater amount of responsibility, not only as regarded the merchants, but also as regarded the natives in the interior. This country held possession of a mere fringe of the coast; but the goods that passed up the river were taxed, and merchants got no protection for their trade in return. The policy of the Colonial Office deterred merchants from going into the interior, and disheartened them. They had been urged, and in fact warned, not to go into the interior. The result was that our trade had fallen off considerably. He considered that the cause of this decline was, in a great measure, the absence of that order and responsibility that ought to exist on the coast of Africa. Complaints had been made of internal wars. These wars were continually arising among the tribes, and in some cases merchants had been ruined. A substantial duty was levied on goods passing along the Gambia, and the protection accorded in return was most inadequate. The case of Gambia was, perhaps, the worst of the class. It had been troubled by wars and robberies to such an extent that trade was almost ruined, and there was scarcely a merchant left of any position. The trade of the district was gradually passing into the hands of the French, from the want of activity and determination on the part of the British authorities. The British traders were being taxed without getting any adequate protection in return. The merchants had no representative on the Council. It was true there were...', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This subject is (says the *Manchester Guardian*, in a series of excellent articles upon the present state of the West Coast of Africa, now under publication) a very wide one, the trade of Africa being carried on under such different conditions, by such different races, and the goods dealt in being so various, that it would seem difficult to bring all under one discussion; but, unfortunately, all the trade of Africa has one great point of similarity, and that is that all is depressed, and much is passing into the hands of foreign competitors. A Royal Commission has been appointed to inquire into the causes of depression in trade. The causes of the depression in African trade are not far to seek, and the remedies must be applied by the Government, and not by the merchants. The apathetic policy which has been pursued, the systematic ignoring of those who have knowledge and experience, and the entrusting of important interests to incompetent hands, have had the effects which were to be expected, and unless some decisive action is taken soon, we may expect our African trade to go from bad to worse, and be all transferred from London, Liverpool, and Bristol to Hamburg, Havre, and Marseilles.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Yet the Government is not alone to blame. Our merchants have frequently preferred to listen to the wild harangues of men whose exaggeration was patent to all, instead of paying attention to the estimates of those whose accuracy could not be questioned. Some have rushed into the African trade without knowledge or capital, and by ignorance and rashness have not only lost their own money, but have caused serious loss to firms who were working on a sound basis, but in consequence of the competition of mushroom adventurers, had to trade at a rate of exchange which barely paid expenses, and even to retain their connexion with those who took European manufactures in return for raw produce, at an actual loss. These remarks, of course, more especially apply to the trade with West Africa, but over the whole Continent, wherever the British merchant has a footing, he has had to contend with similar difficulties, and to put up with foreign competition carried on in a manner that scarcely savours of fair trade. Foreign competitors, wherever English influence is paramount, have the same privileges as themselves, but directly British protectorate or colony is quitted (except in the Oil Rivers and the Free Trade district of the Congo State) they have to compete with hostile tariffs and duties. In the early days of commerce the West Coast was a happy hunting ground for the merchant who did not much care whether his cargo consisted of gold dust, ivory, or slaves for the plantations in the Western Hemisphere. Many of the ships which visited the coast seemed to consider all that sailed under a foreign flag as fair prize, and even failed to recognize the friendship due to a fellow-countryman. Chartered companies were formed by different nations, which did their best to prevent their unlicensed competitors from encroaching on their privileges; and when war broke out between their respective countries, were quite ready to join in the conflict. These chartered companies made treaties with the natives, and built forts and stations which became emporia of trade. On the Gold Coast these forts succeeded each other in rapid succession. Hollanders, Brandenburghers, Danes, Portuguese, French, and English, all possessed strongholds, some of which are in use at the present day. The solidity of the masonry, the size and design of these fortresses, show the importance which the traders of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries attached to this West African trade. Slavery was rampant, and it is almost certain that without slave labour they would never have been constructed. A large portion of the trade was doubtless in slaves, but still that alone could never have accounted for the prosperity and wealth of the merchants who traded with Western Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'West African Trade and the Government', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Mr. J. F. Hutton, President of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce, in his address at the annual meeting of the Chamber on Feb. 1, said that a matter which had engaged the attention of the directors was our trade with West Africa, particularly in the neighbourhood of the rivers Niger and Binue. They had to complain very much of the apathy manifested by the resident officials of Her Majesty's Government, who taxed the goods, but declined to afford any protection or assistance to British merchants. Those officials seemed to have an idea that they were sent out to rule and not to assist as much as possible in the development of British trade. Owing to the state of affairs which had been allowed to arise in the localities indicated, the trade in this country had suffered a very marked decline, for whereas in 1884 we sent 106,000,000 yards of cotton goods, representing a value of £1,320,000, we only sent last year 73,000,000 yards, or a money value of £851,000. He submitted that the Government ought to take prompt measures to protect the lives and property of British subjects in West Africa, and so assist in extending a very valuable market for English manufactures. They had just heard that last May, on the invitation of the German Government, Her Majesty's Government gave to Germany an assurance that a Congo International Conference should be pledged to the British Protectorate in the Niger, that only moderate duties should be levied, and that those should only be levied for the purpose of paying the expenses necessary to carry out the obligations of the Protectorate. At the same time it was understood that there should be no monopolies there, and those concessions were made without giving those who were really owners of property in the territories any voice in the country whatever. Two of the special objects of the merchants in obtaining these concessions from the natives and in obtaining the treaties of sovereignty and territory were that we should do the very utmost we could to stop the importation of spirits into the districts. That trade had increased very considerably during the last few years, and it was one of the curses which European countries were introducing into uncivilized countries, and would tend to retard the progress of our trade and the progress of civilization in the interior of Africa. He thought it was a discredit almost to the Powers of Europe that when great and earnest endeavours were made to limit the import of spirits into these places, there was an almost unanimous opinion expressed against it except by England. Another object which these merchants had in making these treaties was that there should also be some limit put upon the importation of arms and gunpowder, which was another source of evil, and constantly causing wars and raids on our trade.", 'last_edit_date': '1886-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1886#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FRENCH IN SOUTH-WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Proceedings of an extraordinary kind on the part of the French in South-west Africa are reported. It seems that for some time past life and property up the Gaboon River have been placed in danger through the outrages of the natives. These outrages have been brought to the notice of the French authorities at Gaboon, but it seems they have shown great apathy in dealing with the subject; indeed, it is alleged that the Commandant has informed the traders that their property and they themselves would not be molested if they dealt fairly with the natives. In proof of this, the Commandant himself went up the river in a boat unarmed. He had not gone far, however, before he was fired at by the natives from the shore. Fortunately, he escaped unhurt, though one bullet passed through the sleeve of his coat. Subsequently, a French gunboat was sent up the river to inquire into the matter. On the approach of the vessel some natives came off to her with fruit, which they wished to sell. It is stated that the crew then attempted to arrest the natives, who numbered about forty. Becoming alarmed, most of the natives jumped over the ship's side into the water, and it is alleged that whilst striking out for the shore most of them were shot down by the crew of the gunboat. Two men who were arrested on the deck of the vessel were afterwards hanged from the yard-arm. The gunboat then returned to Gaboon, and the circumstance was reported. The Commandant, however, is stated to have disapproved of thus summarily dealing with the natives, and looked upon the matter as an outrage on French subjects. He has therefore, it is stated, placed the commander of the vessel under arrest. It is further stated that the French authorities had told the traders they must protect their own interests, but the prohibition of arms into Gaboon prevents them having the means of even their own defence. The British Consul of Loanda, Mr. Cohen, was at Gaboon when the despatch left, making inquiries into the alleged undue treatment of British merchants at Gaboon. From Sette Cama news was received that the French had annexed Ngove, and the English traders and natives of Sette Cama were afraid that the French would also take their town. Both Ngove and Sette Cama are independent places, and the trade is carried on exclusively by British merchants. Ngove is the next port further south from Gaboon, and Sette Cama adjoins Ngove still further south. All along Cape St. Catherine has been looked upon as the recognized boundary of the French possession of Gaboon. A petition, it is said, has been forwarded to Mr. Cohen by the inhabitants of Sette Cama, informing him of what has taken place, and expressing their anxiety for their own town. They have also asked the Consul to visit them, in order that the French may not take Sette Cama.", 'last_edit_date': '1884-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1884#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'French Aggression on the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is useless to shut our eyes to the fact that hitherto we have systematically shirked any responsibility in regard to native affairs on the Gambia; whereas it is equally palpable that in Senegal the French have shown great activity both in encouraging and in giving practical support to native allies, and in repressing undesirable neighbours.

We have attempted to rely on the broken reed of "moral suasion," as embodied in one-sided treaties carefully constructed to avoid the promise of anything but advice, the result being that we are completely isolated, while our neighbours have enlarged their sphere and bid fair to transform North-west Africa into a vast French colony. No attempt has been made to develop the resources of the Gambia; the river banks have always been infested with marauders, who have lived by plundering the traders and industrious settlers who come down to plant their farms. The merchants have never had any protection beyond the "moral" effect of less than 100 native police kept at Bathurst, of whom not more than twenty would be available for any emergency in the river, even if they would be of any use when they got there.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-04-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_04_1888#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'River Gaboon.—New French Claims', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Trade is wretchedly dull here, and on every part of the adjacent coast; this arises in a great measure from wars among the different tribes, which, having broken out almost simultaneously at different points, produce is very scarce and excessively dear, and provisions can scarcely be purchased at any price. Thus, as matters have apparently reached their worst, we may be permitted to hope that they will soon mend.—I am, Sir, yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1868-02-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1868#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Intrigues of the French in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'previously used to go by the customary mail routes to Liverpool. The English were to blame in not extending their position more into the interior. They ought not to rest satisfied with the fringe of country which they possessed at present. If they sat down and did nothing, and were simply content with the palm oil and kernel trade, he was afraid that in a few years' time the African trade would pass out of the district. He concluded by moving the following resolution: "That the African Trade Section of the Chamber write to the Colonial Secretary, asking him to receive a deputation from the merchants and shipowners of Liverpool on the subject of the proposed French protectorate at Abeokuta."

Mr. RADCLIFFE seconded.

After some discussion, it was resolved that the Manchester and Glasgow Chambers of Commerce be asked to join the deputation.

Our readers will find a full account of the reception of this deputation by Lord Knutsford in another column (p. 117).', 'last_edit_date': '1888-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial Africa was marked by complex and contentious land politics, with disputes over land ownership, property rights, and trade.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles both provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that colonial Africa was marked by complex and contentious land politics, with disputes over land ownership, property rights, and trade. The textbook details the alienation of fertile land in Kenya and Southern Rhodesia for European settlers, leading to significant political and economic repercussions, and highlights the resistance in British West Africa, where indigenous societies successfully opposed British attempts to control land, preserving communal ownership. It also discusses the commercialization of land, which led to illegal sales and litigation, causing poverty and social unrest, and describes the imposition of European bureaucratic structures that disrupted pre-existing African political systems, leading to disputes over territorial integrity and sovereignty. Furthermore, it notes the unequal value of commodities exchanged in trade, reflecting the fragile position of African regions within the international trading system. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight various instances of land and trade disputes, such as tensions between British and French interests in West Africa, the annexation of territories by European powers, and conflicts over trade routes and resources. They discuss disputes over the hinterland of the Gambia, the annexation of the Tabou territory by France, and the complex trade dynamics in the Cameroons and Opobo regions. Additionally, the articles mention the challenges faced by native chiefs in negotiating treaties and the imposition of European legal and trade systems, which often disregarded indigenous land rights and governance structures. While the articles do not explicitly address the broader socio-political implications of these disputes, both sources collectively illustrate the contentious nature of land politics and trade during the colonial period in Africa.

For example, the articles discuss the disputes over the hinterland of the Gambia, the annexation of the Tabou territory by France, and the complex trade dynamics in the Cameroons and Opobo regions. Additionally, the articles mention the challenges faced by native chiefs in negotiating treaties and the imposition of European legal and trade systems, which often disregarded indigenous land rights and governance structures. These details align with the claim by illustrating the contentious nature of land politics and trade during the colonial period in Africa. However, the articles do not explicitly address the broader implications of these disputes on the socio-political landscape of Africa, which could be considered a difference from the claim's broader context.
