[{'id': 489, 'article_title': "Petition against Governor Pine's Rum Licence, and his Reply", 'full_section_title': "Petition against Governor Pine's Rum Licence, and his Reply", 'last_edit_date': '12-23-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1864#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_12_1864', 'content': "To his Excellency Richard Pine, Governor and Commander-in-Chief of Her Majesty's Forts on the Gold Coast.*

The humble petition of the undersigned Chiefs, Headmen, and other inhabitants of Cape Coast Protectorate, sheweth,—

That your petitioners, not being British subjects, but merely under British protection, ought not to be taxed without their being first consulted.

That the British Government has always acknowledged their right to be consulted, when any important measure is to be brought forward and passed into law.

That in the late ordinance relating to rum licences they were never consulted, nor had they any intimation of its existence until they were informed that it had passed into law.

That the three native councillors chosen by your Excellency are not their representatives, as the first intimation they had of their existence was after their appointment had been confirmed by Her Majesty the Queen (Victoria) of Great Britain.

That they consider their voice in your council not in the least binding on them.

That if, through ignorance, they have passively submitted to this mode of legislation, they do not consider they are bound to bear the yoke any longer, after their eyes are open to the oppression that a few can rivet on them, by virtue of an office which (they) your petitioners have no say in.

That they are aware that other countries allow the people on whom taxation falls the heaviest to choose their representatives, and are, therefore, bound to abide by laws made by them in a pure constitutional manner.

That they are surprised to find one London house alone, through their agents or correspondents here (whom they never elected to represent the people of the Protectorate, but perhaps nominated by your Excellency yourself), should represent this vast Protectorate, and take seats in your councils, because their combined interest must, in a great measure, actuate them, directly or indirectly, in their deliberations to (their) your petitioners' prejudice.

That the late acknowledged and prolonged mismanagement of the Ashantee war has greatly crippled their small resources, and they find that it is impossible for them to submit to any additional taxation in their present degraded position, in the eyes of their enemies (the Ashantees), which degradation was not brought on through their incapacity, but through those who were sent to lead them.

That, under these circumstances, your petitioners cannot but protest against your Excellency's right of passing the ordinance relating to the dealing in wines and spirituous liquors, and other ordinances generally, without first consulting (them) your petitioners.

That your Excellency will be pleased to reconsider the ordinance case in question.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray."}, {'id': 494, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '11-14-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1864#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_12_1864', 'content': 'He went to the Colonial Secretary’s office on the day he obtained his certificate, but he could see no one to receive his money, and thinking that his certificate would shelter him until the Colonial Secretary could spare time to leave his commissariat duties to receive his rum licence fee, he went on selling. For this (although all the circumstances were proved) he was fined also 10s., or one month’s imprisonment, the stipendiary magistrate kindly informing him that *he would not make it hard labour*. The poor man paid the fine, and, I believe, petitioned the Governor to have it refunded, which was done. The Governor, with all his faults and errors, is above such dirty practices.

Is it a wonder that with such legislation and such justice the people should be ready to rebel?

Within the last three or four months the British rule has become a most despotic one. The Government never condescends to reason with the people. Laws are made without their knowledge or consent, and ignorant people are entrapped and sent to prison by unscrupulous officials, to be there the companions of murderers and murderesses.

It is an acknowledged fact that had the Governor properly convened the chiefs, &c., and reasoned with them, he might have done wonders; but he has fallen into a great error by depending too much on a certain class of men, who, instead of doing him any good, have brought him into general contempt and hatred. He

imagined that the influence of his friends was unbounded, whereas there is not one chief, headman, or captain in the Protectorate that will even do them reverence. The Africans want men who will not think it too much trouble to reason with them. They are *not* deaf to reason. No African is deaf to reason. It is surprising how argument founded on truth will prevail in their assemblies. It would be difficult to find an instance in which right, if fairly and patiently discussed with these people, has not prevailed against the hotheadedness of force and wrong. If, therefore, they do refuse obedience, that result must be traced to that want of discretion and ignorance of the character of the Gold Coast people which has characterised the late proceedings.

Since commencing this, I am informed that the people are so determined to oppose Governor Pine and his Rum Licence Ordinance, that they have commenced collecting subscriptions throughout the whole Protectorate, in order to send commissioners to England to represent their grievances. They are really in earnest, as large sums have already been paid in for that especial purpose.'}, {'id': 681, 'article_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-0', 'issue_date': '23_09_1865', 'content': '### SIERRA LEONE.

We find difficulty in adequately expressing our regret and indignation at the persistence of Mr. Queen's-Advocate and Acting Chief-Justice Huggins, in endeavoring to force upon the colony "An ordinance providing for security for costs (to be given by plaintiffs) in actions ex delicto." When we first heard

of the attempt, some months ago, we gave our opinion pretty freely, although moderately, on the subject, believing that Mr. Huggins would abandon a course for which no justification whatever could be found, and which, if adopted, would operate as a most grievous denial of justice to those classes of the community in Sierra Leone who have especial need of the protection now afforded under the operation of British law in the colony. We rejoice to see that a general public meeting, which seems to have been attended by all the influential native merchants and traders, was held on the 21st of July, for the purpose of publicly discussing this proposed Ordinance, which was unanimously condemned by the meeting. Mr. Lake said, with great force and justice, "We are required to give security—that is the whole principle of the bill; any man aggrieved, ill-treated, beaten, kicked, is required to give security for costs before he can enter an action against the person who ill-treated him—that is the principle of the bill."

The following Petition was unanimously approved and signed immediately by about 120 persons:—

*To his Excellency Colonel J. W. Chamberlayne, Acting Governor and Commander-in-Chief in and over the Colony of Sierra Leone, and the Honourable Legislative Council of the same.*

"The humble Petition of the undersigned Inhabitants of Freetown, Merchants, Traders, and others, respectfully showeth—

"That your petitioners beg leave to approach your Excellency and the Members of the Legislative Council of Sierra Leone, in Assembly, for the purpose of most respectfully but most firmly protesting against the passing of 'an Ordinance providing for security for costs in actions ex delicto,' the title and principle of which Ordinance are the same as in a prior Ordinance, against the passing of which almost every one of your petitioners protested to the Governor and Legislative Council on a recent occasion. The amended Ordinance now referred to by your petitioners is the same in principle, as they have already stated, as before it was amended; and having been before opposed to its principle, on what they considered and still consider good grounds, they, therefore, beg most respectfully strongly to protest against its being law; for they honestly believe that its whole scope and tendency is the protection of the rich and powerful in their oppressions of the poor and weak, and that should it become law, it will be a source whence the most horrible crimes that disgrace the calendar of a civilized country will flow in this colony continuously.'}, {'id': 1009, 'article_title': 'SIERRA LEONE PROTEST AGAINST THE ORDINANCE ABOLISHING TRIAL BY JURY IN CIVIL CASES.', 'full_section_title': 'SIERRA LEONE PROTEST AGAINST THE ORDINANCE ABOLISHING TRIAL BY JURY IN CIVIL CASES.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1867#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_01_1867', 'content': 'Fourthly—That, as British subjects, we are entitled by the British Constitution to know what are the measures introduced into, or before the Legislature of the colony, vitally affecting our rights and interests and the rights and interests of the community; and it is the right of the inhabitants of this colony, Her Majesty’s loving subjects, to be afforded time to make such representations as they desire, under all circumstances, before such measures have been passed, or have been finally disposed of by the Legislature.

Fifthly—That in consequence of the non-notification of there being such an ordinance to be dealt with by the Legislature, the hurried and unconstitutional manner in which it was passed, and the time between its passing and the departure of the mail conveying it for confirmation, the general community has been absolutely debarred from giving publicity to their decided sentiments against the 11th clause of the Ordinance *especially*, and from petitioning against the abolishment of trial by jury in civil cases, for which this clause provides, and stating their reasons for doing so—a circumstance which, considered, in itself, apart from the other condemnable circumstances connected with the passing of this Ordinance, could not, we respectfully submit, but cause you to recommend the non-confirmation of this Ordinance, and Her Most Gracious Majesty at once to approve of your recommendation, until a reasonable time shall have been afforded us, as British subjects, to lay our complaints and objections respecting it before the Imperial Government.

For the foregoing reasons, my lord, we now unanimously and absolutely protest against the confirmation of this ordinance until we, among numerous others of Her Majesty’s loyal subjects in this colony, shall have had sufficient time to make known, in a legitimate manner, our sentiments concerning it to Her Majesty’s Ministers, and to point out the intolerable wrong, the gross injustice, which would be done to the inhabitants here, were such an ordinance—such an alteration in fact of the constitution of the colony, to receive Her Majesty’s sanction; and we very confidently rely upon your lordship duly to lay this our protest before Her Gracious Majesty, or those of her Ministers whom it may concern, and to give it all the support to which your high sense of justice and impartiality tells you it is entitled.—We have the honour to be, and to subscribe ourselves, your lordship’s very obedient humble servants,

WILLIAM LEWIS,
Merchant, Vice-President of the Chamber of Commerce, &c., &c.,
CHRISTOPHER TAYLOR,
Merchant, and Member of the Chamber of Commerce,
I. B. PRATT, ditto, ditto,

with fifty other members of the Chamber of Commerce, merchants, traders, &c.'}, {'id': 1037, 'article_title': 'SIERRA LEONE NEWS', 'full_section_title': 'SIERRA LEONE NEWS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1867#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_02_1867', 'content': 'The all-engrossing subject of political importance for the past month, has been the now notorious Ordinance for abolishing trial by jury in civil actions which was forwarded by the Executive two mails ago for the Royal sanction. This is the Ordinance of 1866, No. 4, which was accompanied to England by the Protest of the natives against its confirmation. The petition which it was stated in the Protest would be sent, setting forth the grounds of the inhabitants for praying for the non-confirmation of the Ordinance, will be sent by the Governor to the Secretary of State, to whom it is addressed, by the present mail. The petition was presented to-day (January 12) to his Excellency, when he took occasion to inform the gentlemen who presented it that No. 4 was the offspring of the late Secretary of State, Mr. Cardwell, and Mr. Chichester Fortescue, immediately after the Select Committee on the West Coast of Africa had closed their labours in 1866, and was adopted by the Earl of Carnarvon. The abominable odour which attaches to his Excellency on account of this Ordinance is then undeserved by him; and besides, as his Excellency says that it was not done out of any party spirit by those gentlemen but simply because the same policy will be carried out with respects to the other settlements on the West Coast, we hope the public in their next step, if necessary, against this Ordinance, will bear in mind this fact.

The public health is good.—The African Interpreter.

The petition alluded to above has come over by the last mail. It has been signed at public meetings throughout the colony, and has 800 signatures, every principal native merchant, trader, &c., in the colony having signed.'}, {'id': 1240, 'article_title': 'The New Governor-in-Chief', 'full_section_title': 'The New Governor-in-Chief', 'last_edit_date': '12-07-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1867#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_12_1867', 'content': "Mrs. Hoffman, the wife of the late lamented Rev. C. C. Hoffman, is now in England, from which she will proceed to America on account of her health being impaired. She is medically advised not to return to Africa. Miss Julia Gregg has succeeded Mrs. Hoffman in charge of the Orphan Asylum.

The Half Cavalla tribes, the Rock Town and Fish Town tribes are preparing to war against the Cape Palmas, the River Cavalla, and the Grarway tribes. This war is occasioned on account of the mysterious death of General Brown, of the Half Cavalla tribes, who disappeared since the beginning of this year; it is believed he was murdered by the River Cavalla tribes, who are enemies to the Half Cavalla. It is rumoured the war will begin in December, after they have gathered in their new rice.

The Golconda, on her last voyage out, brought seventy-six emigrants for Cape Palmas, amongst whom was Mr. Knox's family, ten in number, the largest family that came out and the most respectable. Mr. Knox brought with him his wife and daughter, his mother and step-father, besides nephews and nieces, but it is lamentable to know that this interesting and promising family have nearly all passed away to their eternal home in less than three months, leaving behind them the daughter and some of the children to stem the troubles of this world in a strange land. Mr. Knox came out to Africa quite prepared for agricultural pursuits, bringing with him cotton and other seeds, and had begun clearing land to commence planting, when he took ill. His wife died eleven days before him.

A newspaper is started at Monrovia called the African Republic, another at Grand Bassa called the People of Bassa.

Three petitions are being got up in Cape Palmas by the citizens to present to the House of Senates and Representatives. The first is to pray for increased duties on ardent spirits, which may be the means abolishing the selling of ardent spirits in the country. The second, to pray that a large receptacle for the emigrants, with good accommodations, may be built. The third, for a repeal of that law in the constitution preventing white men

from holding properties, and giving equal rights to people of all nations, whatever their colour, rank, or position, so that foreign capitals may come into Liberia, and that she may be brought to the position she ought to have been brought to years ago.

The two houses of legislature will meet next month.

The Honourable and Rev. James Payne has been elected President of Liberia, and the Honourable Joseph T. Gibson, Vice-President. The Honourable J. B. Dennis has been elected senator for Cape Palmas Mayland County, vice the Honourable Charles Henry Harman, who has been appointed Governor. The Honourable James M. Thompson, the Honourable Daniel F. Wilson, the Honourable Ausburn Tubman have been elected representatives for Cape Palmas Mayland County.

**Copy of a Petition to Amend the Constitution of Liberia.**"}, {'id': 2220, 'article_title': 'Letter to Earl Kimberley on the Reported Stoppage of the Abeokuta Roads', 'full_section_title': 'Letter to Earl Kimberley on the Reported Stoppage of the Abeokuta Roads', 'last_edit_date': '04-25-1872', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1872#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_05_1872', 'content': 'My Lord,—I regret to have again to trouble your lordship relative to the affairs of the settlement of Lagos.

By a letter from a mercantile correspondent at Lagos, dated March 27, and received this day per Benin, I am informed as follows:—

"Abeokuta Road.—By report I learn that the Egbas have stopped produce coming down from Abeokuta to Lagos, on account of the Government having stopped guns and powder from going up to them. Indeed, there is a great confusion in the state of things here at present, which I fear will prevent shipments of cotton and Beni-seed for some time to come."

The worst fears of the merchants and traders of Lagos as to ruinous complications being likely to arise from the Administrator's recent measures—which apprehension I laid before your lordship in December last—seem thus to be, unhappily, in course of realisation.

I have the honour again to state to your lordship, on the authority of many correspondents, that whatever may have been alleged by the Administrator to your lordship as a means for obtaining your lordship's sanction of the prohibition of export of arms ordinance, and other injurious measures adopted by him against the authorities and people of countries on the mainland opposite Lagos, there have not been any just or good grounds for such ordinance and measures, which threaten effects most disastrous to the trade and commerce of Lagos, and ruinous to those connected therewith.

In the name, therefore, of the merchants and traders of Lagos, as well as in my own, I earnestly entreat your lordship to take immediate steps for putting an end to a state of things which, if continued, must cause very great loss to the mercantile and trading interests of Lagos, and so embitter the relations of Lagos with the interior countries as to place a new obstacle to the spread of civilization among these people.

I have also the honour to enclose copy of another communication, dated Lagos, March 16, relative to a petition or testimonial from one Taiwo and others, said to have been forwarded to your lordship by the said Administrator of Lagos in support of his late proceedings.

Beseeching your lordship's interference to prevent that ruin which again threatens the traders of Lagos through the acts of Her Majesty's Administrator in that settlement, I have the honour to remain, my Lord, your obedient servant,  
**FERDINAND FITZGERALD,**  
Editor of *African Times.*

To the Right Hon. the Earl of Kimberley, K.G., Colonial-office.

---

*Inclosure in above.*

(Copy of letter dated Lagos, March 16.)'}, {'id': 2457, 'article_title': 'Petition of Cape Coast Traders against the New Tariff', 'full_section_title': 'Petition of Cape Coast Traders against the New Tariff', 'last_edit_date': '04-22-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_05_1873#article-4', 'issue_date': '29_05_1873', 'content': "In conclusion, we would beg to assure your Excellency that great dissatisfaction exists throughout the entire Protectorate at the present constitution of the Legislative Council of these settlements; for at the passing of the new tariff the mercantile community, who were alone affected by it, were entirely unrepresented, and this we consider a very great hardship.

We therefore most earnestly pray that your Excellency will be pleased to reconsider this new tariff, and also our complaint as to the formation of the present Legislative Council of these settlements.—We are, your Excellency's most obedient and faithful servants,

(Signed) Wm. Cleaver, Agent for F. O. A. Swanzy.  
G. Kendall.  
F. C. Grant, Agent for Rideout and Roberts.  
W. W. Selby, Agent for Littott, Spinks, & Co.  
Mary Barnes.  
J. A. Ffyn.  
W. E. Davidson.  
And others.

To his Excellency Colonel Harley, C.B., Administrator-in-Chief, West African Settlements, Cape Coast Castle."}, {'id': 5598, 'article_title': 'Letters to the Editor: The Arrest of King Ja Ja', 'full_section_title': 'Letters to the Editor: The Arrest of King Ja Ja', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1887#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_10_1887', 'content': 'The British Consul was sent for, and Ja Ja, insisted that the five firms should trade as usual pending his arrival; but this they refused to do. When the Consul arrived, without further consideration, Ja Ja was fined thirty puncheons of palm oil (equals £300). Ja Ja then appealed to the Colonial Secretary, and ultimately an order was sent from head-quarters that this fine should be remitted. Just before that order was received Ja Ja was directed to refund goods to the value of £3,000 in oil. He expressed himself as prepared to pay this latter exaction, pending the decision of the Colonial Secretary; but the agents were not satisfied with this, but proceeded to trade direct in his markets. This Ja Ja gave them to understand they could not do, by the treaty of 1873 and the arrangement made at the proclamation of the British Protectorate. Ultimately Ja Ja dispatched his son and three of his chiefs to England to lay the whole matter before the Colonial Secretary; whereupon the traders sent for the British Consul at the Cameroons, who came with a gunboat and commanded Ja Ja to sign the agreement. This he refused to do, pending the decision of the Secretary for the Colonies. The Consul then sent for the senior naval officer, by whose influence Ja Ja was induced to sign, under protest, the agreement. But immediately the result of the interview with the authorities in London was made known Ja Ja was arrested.

I should also say that this act is by no means generally approved, as is shown by the fact of several native traders there having joined with Ja Ja in a petition to Her Majesty.

The statement, also, that Ja Ja had killed 150 persons on account of their disregard of his orders is not borne out by the facts of the case. It was in war, and the prisoners on both sides were killed, according to the native custom; but nothing of this kind has been done since the British protectorate was proclaimed.

I would also remind your readers that Ja Ja is but a heathen; that the people of England must not expect to find in him the results of a civilization and religion under whose influence he has never come.

Trusting you will be able to find space for the insertion of this statement,—Yours obediently,'}, {'id': 5620, 'article_title': 'SOUTH AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'SOUTH AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1887#article-15', 'issue_date': '01_11_1887', 'content': 'A meeting of native delegates from all the various parts of the colony has lately taken place at King Williamstown to consider the question of sending a deputation to England regarding the Registration Act, and to discuss the question of the liquor traffic. The meeting was a large and representative one, no white man taking part in the proceedings. A committee was appointed to watch the registration lists now in course of preparation, with power to bring test cases before the Supreme Court, and interpret the tribal and communal tenure if necessary. Four delegates will then visit England to represent matters. The conference arranged to communicate with the Secretary of State through his Excellency the Governor.

The Editor of *Native Opinion*, in a letter to the *Cape Times* in defence of an appeal to the Imperial Government, argues how can the natives follow the recommendation to fight their battles as colonists in this country when precluded from the hustings, and consequently from a voice in Parliament? He writes:

“It is because we take the Constitution Ordinance to be a matter which concerns the Imperial Government specially that we invoked its intervention. We look upon the Constitution Ordinance as the Cape Magna Charta. When this contract between the Imperial Government and the colony was entered into, the former assumed its proper functions as guardian of the weakest of its children—the natives. With wonderful foresight it firmly insisted that the natives should have a share in the self-government of the colony, and with this view the franchise was lowered so as to embrace the native.

“We contend that it is this contract that has been violated by one of the contracting parties. All we are trying to ascertain is, does the other party to the contract—the Imperial Government, which is also our guardian—acquiesce in what has been done? If it does, and as a consequence natives are excluded from British citizenship, then the confidence of our people in British justice will be rudely shaken, and the vaunted government of the people by the people shunned by the natives as a delusion and a snare.”

The *Cape Times* says: “As far as the Registration Act is concerned, the native delegates must await the course of events, but in the agitation against the destruction of their people by the removal of the restriction on the sale of brandy they have the sympathy of all good colonists on their side. The present honest agitation among the natives themselves against the fatal exercise of liberty deserves the respect and aid of all.”

The export of diamonds for the month of September amounted to 253,391 carats, valued at £330,947.'}, {'id': 6410, 'article_title': 'TRADE IN THE GAMBIA', 'full_section_title': 'TRADE IN THE GAMBIA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_12_1893#article-13', 'issue_date': '04_12_1893', 'content': "Sir,—Trade here is by no means satisfactory, but when you learn the state of things going on, and the one-sided laws laid upon the traders, you will not be surprised. A trade license ordinance has been framed under which British traders must take license to go to trade in another territory. Why should not British laws be enforced in the territories mentioned, so that the Natives may learn to obey them? Alas! progress in the right direction is not the order of the day in this Colony! The traders formed a deputation to meet the Governor, and he granted them an interview. They advised his Excellency to delay the passing of this ordinance in order to give them time to put into writing the terms of their objection. The traders then addressed a memorial to the Governor for the Right Hon. the Secretary of State for the Colonies, to be forwarded by his Excellency at the earliest opportunity. This memorial was signed by fifty or more influential traders of the Colony. Mr. Editor, the door of the territories is left wide open to any other tribes, natives, &c., but not to the British trader of the Colony. The poor traders who ought to enjoy British protection, have it denied to them by the present ordinance. Why? Are we not her Majesty's loyal subjects? And should we not enjoy our freedom as all other Colonies? The traders in the Colony, with exception of a few whites, are protesting against the passing of that ordinance.—I remain, Mr. Editor,  
A POOR TRADER.

*[It is difficult to follow the drift of our Correspondent's complaint, but we insert the letter in the hope that if any grievance exists on the part of the Native traders of the Gambia, the attention of the authorities may be directed to it.—Ed. A.T.]*

---"}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Petition from Accra against the New Duties', 'section_title': '', 'content': "To the Right Honourable the Earl of Kimberley, Her Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies.

The Petition of the undersigned kings, chiefs, headmen, native merchants, European and American merchants, native petty traders, and retail dealers in spirits, and other native inhabitants of Accra and other places in the Eastern districts of the Gold Coast Protectorate,

Humbly showeth,

That your petitioners have for several years past submitted willingly, patiently, and cheerfully to the payment of import due, spirit licences, and other taxes levied on them by the Government of this Settlement.

That from the period of the exchange of territory between Her Majesty's Government and that of His Majesty the King of the Netherlands, which was effected on the 4th day of January, 1868, up to the month of April, 1872, the import dues were as follows, —viz.: On spirits, ales, wines, beer &c., 6d. per gallon; on tobacco and gunpowder, each, 1d. per lb.; on fire-arms of every description, each, 1s.; and on all other goods of every kind an ad valorem duty of three per cent. on invoice price.

That in April, 1872, a new tariff was introduced throughout the Settlement by virtue of which duties became payable as follows —viz.: On spirits and spirituous liquors, 1s. per gallon; on wines, ale, beer, &c., 6d. per gallon; on gunpowder and tobacco, 1d. per lb. each; on fire-arms of all kinds, each, 1s.; and all other articles free.

That during the period from January, 1868, to April, 1872, those of your petitioners who are engaged in commerce paid those duties in addition to the taxes charged for wholesale and retail spirit licences; some also paying other taxes, such as for auctioneers' licences.

That during that period your petitioners were entirely unrepresented in the Legislative Council of this Settlement; neither were they permitted to have any voice in, or control over, the expenditure of the funds which they contributed to the Colonial revenue.

That during that period the only public works constructed for the benefit of the Eastern district out of the proceeds of the taxes were a landing-place at Jamestown, Accra, in 1869; a marketplace in Jamestown in 1870; and a lighthouse in James' Fort in 1871; but not one penny has been expended in the education of the youth of the district, or in any other way for the improvement of the country.

That since the establishment of the new tariff of April, 1872, the Accra district has contributed some 15,000l. or more to the Colonial revenue, but your petitioners have not received the benefit of a single penny thereof in any shape whatsoever.

That your petitioners, the kings, chiefs, and headmen of the district, although now entirely bereft of all authority and all sources of revenue by the action of Her Majesty's local Government, have, nevertheless, received no benefit at all from the taxes collected on such an extensive scale from their people, and to which they themselves contribute.", 'last_edit_date': '1873-05-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_06_1873#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Currency and Other Grievances of African Traders', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Chairman of the African Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce has received a memorial, signed by traders and residents at Bathurst, protesting against the transference of the Gambia mail service from British to French vessels, detailing grievances in regard to the currency of the settlement, and asking the co-operation of the Chamber of Commerce in enlisting public sympathy.

We learn with much regret that the Secretary of State for the Colonies has been pleased to direct that the subsidy at present paid for the monthly mail service between Liverpool and this settlement should be discontinued, as he is informed that the general feeling in the settlement was against its continuance. We cannot suppress our feelings of surprise at the above statement, and at such a seeming disregard respecting a matter which so much concerns our interests, as represented in the memorial, addressed in May last to the Colonial Office, on behalf of the West African settlements, protesting against the measure from the outset. In the face of the facts set forth in this memorial, it is impossible to doubt that the discontinuance of the mail service, hitherto carried on by the British and African Steam Navigation Company, will seriously affect our commercial relationship with the merchants and manufacturers interested in the trade of the Gambia. The establishment of our trading connexion direct with Great Britain is due entirely to the maintenance of the monthly mail communication by the steamers running between Liverpool and the settlement, and but for which it might have been impossible.

We, therefore, regard with serious apprehension the ruin which threatens an enterprise which many of us have embarked in in the earliest days of our lives, and which will cut off from us the fruits which it has been our desire to enjoy in old days. Not only will such a measure cut off our source of supplies, but oblige us to be at the mercy of the French merchants, who already command the trade; and we shall be deprived of the facilities which hitherto have enabled us to maintain competition with our French neighbours in the trade, and will cause tastes and preferences by the natives in the interior of the district, and the wish of the natives for British manufactures will be checked.

The discontinuance of the mail service will also affect the export trade in ground nuts, which has been only recently created, and the results of which have led us to hope that a fair field of competition would be opened against the French market, where the great bulk of this produce has hitherto been consigned. By the service of the mail steamers, cheap food and provisions are within the reach of all classes in the community, and, in the event of this service being discontinued, a state of things altogether unpleasant will be brought about by those in whose hands the advantage lies.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Oppression of the Black Trader at Opobo River', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The same thing that was about to occur at Bonny is reviving at Opobo. Some years ago, the white agents and the merchants in Bonny held a council to plan in what way to expel the black traders from the town of Bonny. They suggested to the King that he should drive away the black traders—that they were spies and tale-bearers, and, by admitting them into the town, they would give occasion for the English Government to take the country from the King. They thought that by these false statements the King would at once expel the black traders from the town; but the King, instead of this, summoned all the chiefs and principal men, and laid the matter before them. They found that the representations made to the King arose from envy, malice, and hatred; and the King said to the agents and merchants that he found no cause for expelling the black traders, adding, if there was any palaver between them and the white men, and the black men from Sierra Leone, they could go to their consul and settle it. Since then all opposition and oppression by the white agents or merchants has been checked, and the black traders are privileged to do business at Bonny Town. The same thing is now occurring at Opobo River. The same firms that are doing business in Bonny River are doing business at Opobo. They have held a council again, planning in what way they may get the black traders from the town of Opobo. You ask, what is the cause of this opposition? Do the black traders get more oil than the agents? Nay, how many casks of oil do you think black traders have shipped in a year? About 50 and sometimes 60 casks. How many casks do the white agents ship in a year? About 900 to 1,000 each house. From what motive, then, is this opposition? Not from envy. There must be some secret going on between the agents that they should call black traders spies and tale-bearers. What do they mean by that? Are they doing something contrary to the English Government, or something against their employers at home? Let the wise men take it in consideration—they will see for themselves; when the water settles they will see what is at the bottom. The black traders do not go to the Coast to be inspectors—they go to trade; but when the white men see any black trader or British subject, they cannot contain themselves, as when a captain of a Portuguese slave-ship happened to see an English man-of-war coming. What is the cause of this? Is it a deep secret known only between the agents? They have forwarded their false representations to the King, instigating him to drive out the black traders, for no tangible reason. The charge alleged to the black traders is that they object to the black traders doing business at the town of Opobo; they must go down to the beach and build houses there to do business, and if they cannot do that, the King must turn them out. They know it to be impossible for the black traders to build houses on the beach, for if they did there would be no capital remaining for the black traders to go on with. The King has disposed of their objection by saying that there is no positive decree against any merchants or traders doing business in the town; that it is a matter of option where a man chooses to carry on his business; that the white agents and merchants had once built a house in the town of Opobo, but for reasons of health they removed to the beach; and if the town of Opobo is healthy for the black traders, why should the white men oppose their being there? The King finds no occasion to drive away the black', 'last_edit_date': '1874-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_11_1874#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Congo Traders and their Grievances', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following is extracted from a letter received from a Liverpool gentleman who has had many years' experience of trading on the Congo: "If the various Governments interested can only be moved to look into the question of duties, it is difficult to see how they will be able to sanction such an enormous amount of squeezing out of the few traders who by fair promises were induced to establish in the Free State territory and the traders established in the Lower Congo long before the Free State was ever dreamed of, and who have not benefited in any way from it. From the poverty-stricken condition of the Free State Government, and for political reasons, I fear the duties will not be arranged in anything like a satisfactory manner for the traders, and if the French and Portuguese Governments follow suit, there is no saying where the thing will end; but of this we are certain, a great blow will be given to English enterprise, and we know that neither French nor Portuguese capitalists will put money in these colonies. Belgian capital is out of the question altogether; the Free State seems to be regarded as a hobby or a speculation of the King. How long will it take to open up the Dark Continent to the boasted advantages of civilisation if the pioneers are to be hampered and hindered by the Governments who ought to help them to the utmost?"

It may be asked why Holland should especially bestir itself in Congo matters more than other nations? The reason is that the Dutch joint-stock company, De Nieuwe Afrikaansche Handels Vennootschap, exports seven-eighths of the total produce of the Congo; its shares are in the hands of numerous holders; it is one of the oldest European establishments in that region, and has a character, an organisation, and a prospect higher than it ever previously possessed.

The duty which Holland is striving to fulfil with respect to her African Trading Company has its counterpart in England. We Englishmen have also compatriots whose history has been similar to that of the Dutch company. Though not possessing such an extensive interest, their establishments are spread over the territory claimed by the Portuguese and the French. These Powers may follow suit if the present encroachments be not resisted, and it behoves our Government to see that our merchants do not suffer through the proposed innovations. But Governments will not, cannot, act unless moved from outside, and the traders of the Congo district thoroughly realise this fact. The export houses have all decided to urge the Powers to ameliorate the present condition of affairs, with a unanimity born of common danger.—R. C. Phillips, in the *Manchester Guardian* (abridged).', 'last_edit_date': '1890-11-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/07_11_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Oppression of the Black Trader at Opobo River', 'section_title': '', 'content': '---

traders; he says, "Opobo is not the only place where the black traders are doing business; there are black traders doing business at Bonny Town, Benin, and Old Calabar Town; the kings in those places do not drive out their black traders, and why should you want me to drive out my black traders? I cannot comply." The King will not drive out the black traders because they have not violated the law of the land. When the white agents found that King Ja Ja would not agree with their demands, they forwarded the case to the British Consul at Bonny, asking him to assist them to expel the black traders from Opobo. The Consul would not do this, but the captains of the steamers declare that he gave a positive order that they—the captains of the British and African and the Royal Mail steamers—should not take on board any oil from the black traders of Opobo. All the oil sent by them on board the steamer Forcados last month was sent back to the town; the captain refused to take it. On inquiry he says he is not allowed to take any oil from the town of Opobo. All the traders' oil is wasting away.

All our hope now is in you, Mr. Editor. Is it possible (we can scarcely believe it) that Consul Hartley should have given such an order? Pray inquire for us. Surely he cannot have done this; but if he has, why? Can he have got a report from home that black traders at Opobo are shipping human beings in casks instead of oil? for if the black traders—British subjects, too—are not guilty of this, I do not see why we should be thus treated. We look to you to get justice done for us.—Yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1874-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_11_1874#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Mr. Hutton on West African Affairs', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Manchester, February 25, 1873.

To the Directors of the Chamber of Commerce, Manchester.

Gentlemen,—The present unsatisfactory state of the trade of the West Coast of Africa induces me to request your immediate and earnest consideration to the condition of the British settle- ments there, and to the manner in which the commercial in- terests of this country on that coast are neglected by Her Majesty's Government.

Wherever slavery has existed Her Majesty's Government has ever been eager and the first to avenge at any expense the cause of the poor negro; the mere suspicion of slavery has always brought to the spot one of Her Majesty's ships of war; but
123

British merchants on the West Coast of Africa are most heavily, arbitrarily, and exorbitantly taxed by Her Majesty's Government to support the officers they send out, and the traders appeal in vain for that protection to their lives and property and for that consideration to their interests to which they have every moral and just claim.

The injustice British traders suffer from this want of protection has most materially weakened their influence over the natives, and in many parts the only evidence of British rule in Western Africa is the presence of the tax-collector.

The British merchants also suffer most grievously from the commercial ignorance and utter incapacity of the officials sent out by the Colonial-office; the improper appointments and the constant and frequent changes made in the Administration are, in fact, the main causes of the present unsatisfactory state of the settlements and of the trade of the West African Coast. When slave trade existed military and naval appointments may have been beneficial; but now, the trade having been extirpated, and a large and valuable commerce having arisen in its place, it has become absolutely necessary to appoint officers who will protect British merchants and foster commercial interests. The trade of the West Coast of Africa has been disregarded by Her Majesty's Government to such an extent that the natives themselves are gradually losing all respect for this country. There is among them also a general and a strong feeling of discontentment, and the undisguised hope that the time has arrived that the settlements should be given back to them to govern as suits themselves.", 'last_edit_date': '1873-02-25', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_04_1873#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'OFFICIAL TRADING AT THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.  
Bathurst, River Gambia, July 1st, 1881.

Sir,—It is about time that some attempt was made by the Colonial Office to put down trading on the part of certain officials here, some of whom, though receiving large salaries, carry on trade themselves, or through people hired for that purpose, thus competing with civilians who earn their living by trade.

Some time ago an American vessel arrived here with an assorted cargo for sale; the Tide Surveyor boarded her in due course, and, as usual, no one could visit the vessel until the above official had concluded his inspection. The Tide Surveyor examined the manifest, and, among other items of cargo, saw a large quantity of shingles. These he knew were in great request in the town, as the rainy season was setting in, and the roofs of the houses of many people required repairing. He asked the supercargo, Captain Ryder, his price for the shingles, was told, and then purchased the lot, 55,000, thus being enabled to rule the market, as no one else had shingles in Bathurst. The vessel was duly entered, and the shingles landed by this Customs official, and he resold about 25,000 to the Engineer Department, and disposed of the balance, 30,000, in small lots, at a good profit, to various people in the town, who had to purchase them at any price, as the roofs of their houses leaked. Now, is it a fair thing that officials, whose salaries amount to hundreds per annum, should be free to compete with and injure the shopkeepers of Bathurst?

It has been a common thing for all kinds of provisions, clothing, also liquors, cigars, &c., to be purchased on board of the mail steamers by officials from the Custom House, brought on shore in the Customs' boat, taken up to the houses of the officials by the Customs' boat's crew, and what was not wanted for the use of the purchasing official, retailed to the people in the town, much under the price such articles could be sold at in the shops at a profit. Business here is very dull; the shops are just turning over the capital, and perhaps paying expenses, the shopkeepers making just a bare living. Is it right that such living should be further reduced by the private trade of officials?

The best remedy would be for the Colonial Office to send out instructions to the Administrator here to make all present and future officials subscribe to a declaration, setting forth that they are not, or will not be engaged in any trade, calling, or occupation, outside the sphere of their official duty, and that they do not, and will not, hire or engage anyone to carry on any such trade, calling or occupation on their sole or for joint behalf.

What with officials of the Courts practising as attorneys, Customs and other officials trading, things here are in a far from satisfactory state.—I am, Sir, Your obedient Servant,", 'last_edit_date': '1881-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1881#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the course of some excellent articles which have appeared lately in the *Manchester Guardian*, dealing with the present and future trade prospects of Africa, we have one chapter devoted to the consideration of the drawbacks upon genuine commerce by the enforcement of such quasi-regal rights as those exercised by Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, and the rest of that host of petty kinglings, in the districts of the West Coast. The article in question says:—

One of the ways in which the development of trade must be carried out is by pushing factories up beyond the tribes who now serve as middlemen between the European trader and the native producer. Some difficulty will no doubt be encountered in passing through the unhealthy and malarious districts in which these middlemen live, but the improved knowledge we are obtaining of how to combat climatic diseases will render such an enterprise more easy than it would have been twenty years ago. Indeed, if we contrast the early reports of the Niger with its present exploitation, we may believe that the climate of no tropical country will permanently prevent its being opened up to commerce. This is a ray of hope for our African traders, and it is to be hoped that our Government will enable them to avail themselves of it speedily, and not allow them to be forestalled by the merchants of other nations. As if the inaction of our Government had not been sufficiently disastrous to the trade of the African merchants of Liverpool and Manchester, the home legislation of the last few years has also done much to hamper their enterprise. One industry alone, which, though it may be considered a small one, came in the aggregate to a considerable amount, has been completely driven out of the country. The trade in matches to the West Coast used to be supplied by Manchester. Now, the children who used to be employed in their manufacture are sent to school hungry, while German matches are sent in German ships to those who used to buy the English ones, and the only profit to English people is that of the middleman, and even that is being rapidly taken from them.

The German and French textile manufactures are also running us close, and we have to watch carefully the change of fashions and ideas among the natives. Many cheap articles made in France, with a ready sale on the coast, could easily be made in England. Some of the native manufactures could easily be imitated, such as the Niger cloths and the silk and cotton cloths made by the Santees and Ashantees of unravelled European stuffs. Beyond the Oil rivers to the south we have the French colony of the Gaboon, which has now become one of the largest tracts of Africa controlled by an European nation. In the old portion of the colony trade is not so flourishing as it used to be, English enterprise having been driven away by the action of protection and differential duties.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Grievous complaints have been made by the several traders doing business on this river of the great want of Government protection. How long are they to remain under subjection to the heathen chiefs and Mohammedan alcaldes, without any one to inquire into, or obtain them redress for, the cruel treatment received by them from those native authorities? The traders on this river are constantly exposed to great danger and loss owing to this want of Government protection. They are compelled by the chiefs and alcaldes to reside in their towns or stockades with their goods and produce. Formerly they built temporary stores and dwelling-houses at the river side or wharf of their several trading ports, by which they had little comparative risk from fire and native wars, the two chief accidents in this river. Of late that system has been done away with in some localities, through Government mismanagement, and the traders have sustained great losses; their goods and produce have in several places been consumed by fires, with the towns where they were compelled to reside, which would not have been the case had they been allowed to reside at the river side. This year the trade has been so dull, that cotton goods scarcely sold, and the very small portion of produce collected has been ultimately destroyed by fire; some thousand pounds worth at Sanding, some hundreds at Zambakotto, Juronku, Dassilammee, and Secker, and several other places—all by fire. Why should the traders be thus exposed, by being compelled to live in native towns, which are always taking fire, when this river, from the mouth to its source, is supposed to be under the management and control of the British Government? Is it not through misgovernment?

The traders having no one to assist them in their dangerous position on this river, and their letters on the subject to the local Government having been without effect, they beg through you the aid of the African-Aid Society, to obtain for them that they may be allowed to separate from the natives in their several trading ports, by building their temporary houses and stores on the river side.

I hope that I shall be understood. The whole of the native chiefs and alcaldes in this river do not thus coerce the traders. But the great question is, why should traders at Carrawan and Swans Coonder, in the late kingdom of Baddiboo, not be allowed to reside out of those towns, seeing that these districts are more or less under the influence of the Government since the late British war against that kingdom? Twenty months ago a letter
**135**', 'last_edit_date': '1864-04-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GAMBIA.—LAW COURTS, JURIES, TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'That the trade is being contracted is an undoubted fact. I know many natives who did a considerable business in the river in past years who are doing little or nothing this year. Their losses have been so heavy by these traders that they fear to trust men with goods to go up the river; and they say it is better to almost remain idle and wait for some favourable change, than to run the risk of further losses that may ruin them.

Then, a large number of the working class of the native community are, consequent on the reduction in the trade, idle, and are living on one meal a day.

A large number of the Liboo traders who were employed as traders in former years could not get engagements this year, so did not come down from Senegal, and being in danger of starvation, had to go and work as labourers on the railway the French are making from St. Louis to Dakhar. These are facts known to many here.

Any man who says that the commercial houses here charge a trader 600l. for 200l. worth of goods at first cost, states not an "indisputable fact," but the reverse. The average price of goods sold for cash in Bathurst is about 60 per cent. on European cost price; out of this have to be paid expenses of importation and landing into store, ship rent, expenses of sale, depreciation and waste, bad debts, interest on money. These goods, when delivered to a trader in the Lower River, are charged in his invoice at 50 per cent. on the Bathurst cash price; but in the past two years that got down to 25 per cent., and even less. In the Upper River the percentage is higher, but variable. The trader gets all his expenses at the port credited to him, such as "customs" to the chiefs, &c., which average 7l. to 10l. per trader per season; then the station expenses for presents to farmers, &c., porterage of produce, landlords' rent, &c., which are about 15 to 20 per cent. on value of produce bought, are all allowed to a trader. Goods sent to him and produce taken from him are freight free. If he pays an extravagant price, or gives extravagant presents, or is extravagant in his expenses, that is his own fault, and he will make a loss. His produce is taken at 2s. the 15 x 15 measure; but if it is taken at 1s. 9d. the 28 lbs. the imperial bushel, then he has a profit of 40 to 50 per cent. on his produce—the difference between a 15 x 15 measure and an imperial bushel of good ground nuts. Credit to the natives is given by traders during the rains, as the natives have not produce always at that time to pay for what they want; but in the ground nut season, traders are distinctly bound by their agreements not to give credit; and if they do, and lose, they are to blame.

"Dealers" are men who get goods at lower rates, and get higher prices for their produce. These men have to pay all their expenses, in consideration of getting better terms than traders who are paid servants.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-02-17', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1882#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Yet the Government is not alone to blame. Our merchants have frequently preferred to listen to the wild harangues of men whose exaggeration was patent to all, instead of paying attention to the estimates of those whose accuracy could not be questioned. Some have rushed into the African trade without knowledge or capital, and by ignorance and rashness have not only lost their own money, but have caused serious loss to firms who were working on a sound basis, but in consequence of the competition of mushroom adventurers, had to trade at a rate of exchange which barely paid expenses, and even to retain their connexion with those who took European manufactures in return for raw produce, at an actual loss. These remarks, of course, more especially apply to the trade with West Africa, but over the whole Continent, wherever the British merchant has a footing, he has had to contend with similar difficulties, and to put up with foreign competition carried on in a manner that scarcely savours of fair trade. Foreign competitors, wherever English influence is paramount, have the same privileges as themselves, but directly British protectorate or colony is quitted (except in the Oil Rivers and the Free Trade district of the Congo State) they have to compete with hostile tariffs and duties. In the early days of commerce the West Coast was a happy hunting ground for the merchant who did not much care whether his cargo consisted of gold dust, ivory, or slaves for the plantations in the Western Hemisphere. Many of the ships which visited the coast seemed to consider all that sailed under a foreign flag as fair prize, and even failed to recognize the friendship due to a fellow-countryman. Chartered companies were formed by different nations, which did their best to prevent their unlicensed competitors from encroaching on their privileges; and when war broke out between their respective countries, were quite ready to join in the conflict. These chartered companies made treaties with the natives, and built forts and stations which became emporia of trade. On the Gold Coast these forts succeeded each other in rapid succession. Hollanders, Brandenburghers, Danes, Portuguese, French, and English, all possessed strongholds, some of which are in use at the present day. The solidity of the masonry, the size and design of these fortresses, show the importance which the traders of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries attached to this West African trade. Slavery was rampant, and it is almost certain that without slave labour they would never have been constructed. A large portion of the trade was doubtless in slaves, but still that alone could never have accounted for the prosperity and wealth of the merchants who traded with Western Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Latest from Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. The average prices in Europe of the more important native products have stood even lower than during the previous twelve months, while the prolonged continuance of low prices in Africa has apparently disheartened the native producer, and tended to diminish the quantity as well as the value of his out-turn. In Europe and America an improvement has, it is true, occurred in the prices of a few leading articles of commerce, but no sign of such revival extending to the products of West Africa has yet been vouchsafed; and, while it is not forbidden to hope for better things in 1888, it would be imprudent of our readers to base their calculations on any material rise in prices, or, indeed, not to make the necessary provisions for a possible—though, let us hope, improbable—further fall. While this condition of business is doubtless felt more or less even by the wealthy European merchants trading to West Africa, the most deplorable results of the depression occur in the colonial centres, such as Sierra Leone and Lagos. Great numbers of clerks and artisans, anxious for engagements as heretofore at various parts of the coast, are unable to obtain employment, or only at reduced rates of wages.

To these communities 1888 will probably bring good tidings. It has been stated, on apparently good authority, that early in the new year the so-called "oil rivers"—now under intermittent Consular jurisdiction—will be formed into a Colony. The experiences of Lagos and the Gold Coast enable us to predict, with tolerable certainty, the results which will follow from this policy. These valuable regions will be rapidly settled and opened up to trade. Hitherto, owing to the prevalence of the barter system, the unsettled condition of the tribes, and the absence of order and justice, only wealthy European houses have been able to make the necessary provisions.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Parcel Post with the Oil Rivers Protectorate', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"It is evident that in a trade which has its foundation on the barter system the value and quantity of the imports must vary directly with the exports. There is of late years a growing tendency on the part of the native, even in the remote interior, to employ silver currency for his transactions in place of direct barter or the cumbrous method of transporting vast quantities of cowrie shells from market to market. Hitherto the carrying powers of a slave and his intrinsic value have been in strict relations, but it is probable the less perishable metallic currency will oust him from the commercial field. In other ways the gradual adoption of specie payments has modified the methods of trade in the Colony, and such firms as have adhered to the old barter system have had to remove to less civilised regions. This is very noticeable in the case of the French firms, who were at one time the leading merchants of Lagos. There are at present few traces of their existence in the Colony, except the large factories which were built by them in the days of their prosperity. The establishment of a branch of the African Banking Corporation Limited, which took place towards the close of the year, will have a very remarkable effect on trade by increasing specie transactions, and even more by encouraging shipments by small traders, to whom money is advanced on the security of insured produce or invoiced European goods. The attention of the natives has been directed lately to the importance of developing minor industries. Among these may be mentioned the cultivation of cocoa and coffee, which has been taken up both by the natives and, in one', 'last_edit_date': '1893-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In 1848, the King of Dahomey requested that a British Governor might be sent to Whydah, an offer which it is needless to say was not made with any expectation that his slaving operations would be thereby impeded; but it is open to question whether, had the arrangement been adopted, the influence which our presence would have brought with it would not have produced a very different state of matters in regard to the slave-trade to that which now exists.

The town of Little Popo applied in 1861, through the Government of Sierra Leone, to be permitted to cede its territory to Great Britain, an offer with which it was not thought advisable to close, and there is little doubt that we might, were it considered expedient, readily obtain such a footing in this neighbourhood as would enable us to impose a very serious check to the slave dealing which now prevails. It is true that the export in this locality is almost, although not entirely, kept under by the vigilance of the squadron, but this is only effected by keeping a number of men-of-war (there were six in December last) anchored within two miles of the coast, at short distances from each other, with armed boats in the intervals; an arrangement entailing the severest and most trying duties on the officers and men employed, and attaining its partial success only at very great cost to the country.

If the present trade of the settlements be compared with that of any other British possessions, it is not certainly of any great moment; but, such as it is, it owes its continuance mainly to the encouragement and protection which their presence affords it. Their exports in 1863 (the latest for which complete returns can be obtained) amounted to within a trifle of 650,000l., whilst their imports for the same period reached 533,000l.

The mode in which the trade is carried on has been already alluded to in the former part of the report, and it will be readily understood that a commerce, which is conducted chiefly by native agents, and to a great extent in countries inhabited by savage and lawless tribes, at considerable distances from the settlements, can only be prosecuted in safety when their influence is felt and their authority respected; indeed, notwithstanding the comparative security afforded to trade, local interruptions of it are but too numerous, and the difficulties which have arisen between the natives and ourselves have, in many instances, had their origin in robberies and assaults committed by them on our traders and their servants, so that the merchants are probably not in error in asserting that the complete annihilation of their trade would in most cases follow the withdrawal of the protection they now enjoy.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Reported Troubles in the Cameroons', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A recent telegram from Liverpool says that news received by the West African steamship Boma from the German colony of the Cameroons, which arrived in the Mersey on Nov. 11, shows that some serious disturbances have occurred there. The Boma left the Cameroons River on Oct. 11, at which date six chiefs had recently been sentenced to five years’ imprisonment, and were then awaiting transportation to the German Togo territory, which adjoins the Gold Coast. Some time ago trade in the Cameroons was so unsatisfactory that the traders, both English and German, formed a “conference,” and agreed to pay only certain prices to the Natives for produce. This agreement was maintained for some time, but appears to have been broken at last by one of the German houses. After this the Natives formed a “conference” against the traders, which one of the Natives broke in the same way by trading with an English house on the old terms. This Native and his people were seized by the other members of the “conference” and very badly treated, besides having everything in their canoes taken from them. Dr. Seitz, the Acting Governor, was administering the colony, and promptly had the offenders arrested. They included all the leading Natives of the place, and they were tried and found guilty of the offence charged against them. Three of them, including a king, were each fined a money payment, and six other chiefs were sentenced to five years’ imprisonment. The Natives of the place were in a state of great excitement. Governor Puttkamer arrived in the Cameroons just as the Boma left, and it was believed by the Natives that he would cancel the sentences on the chiefs. Although one of the reports said that the Natives would rise against the Germans and drive them out of the river, it was not believed by the English that anything of the kind would be attempted, as the Germans a few years ago gave the Natives a lesson of their strength which they are not likely to forget.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-12-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1896#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: British colonial actions and policies in Africa, including military interventions and trade disruptions, led to significant economic instability and competition, adversely affecting both local economies and British commercial interests.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively provide a comprehensive view of the economic instability and competition resulting from British colonial actions and policies in Africa. The textbook highlights the exploitation of African resources and labor, the imposition of monoculture economies, and the neglect of industrialization, all of which contributed to economic instability. It describes how African economies were integrated into the world capitalist system in a manner that primarily benefited the imperial power, leading to the disruption of inter-African trade and a reorientation towards metropolitan countries, further destabilizing local economies. The British colonial administration's preference for British firms and the imposition of tariffs on non-British goods created competition that disadvantaged local African traders. However, the textbook does not explicitly address the adverse effects on British commercial interests. In contrast, The African Times articles provide insights into how British colonial actions also negatively impacted British commercial interests. They detail disruptions in trade routes, such as those caused by the Ijaye war and the burning of Ejirin, which hindered local oil trade. The articles highlight the distrust among interior people towards British occupation and the closing of trade routes by tribes like the Jebu and Egba, illustrating the economic instability caused by British interventions. Furthermore, they discuss the adverse effects of foreign competition, with French and German annexations introducing different trading principles that harmed British commerce. The imposition of duties on British goods, while French and German goods remained duty-free, exacerbated the competition. The neglect of British commercial interests by the colonial administration led to a decline in trade and a loss of influence over the natives. Together, these sources underscore the complex economic challenges resulting from British colonial policies and military actions, affecting both local African economies and British commercial interests.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that align with the claim that British colonial actions and policies in Africa led to economic instability and competition, adversely affecting local economies. The text highlights the exploitation of African resources and labor, the imposition of monoculture economies, and the neglect of industrialization, all of which contributed to economic instability. The colonial economy was structured to benefit the imperial power, with African economies integrated into the world capitalist system in a disadvantageous manner. The text also notes the disruption of inter-African trade and the reorientation of trade towards the metropolitan countries, which further destabilized local economies. Additionally, the British colonial administration's preference for British firms and the imposition of tariffs on non-British goods created competition that disadvantaged local African traders. However, the text does not explicitly mention adverse effects on British commercial interests, focusing instead on the exploitation and economic challenges faced by African economies. This is a notable difference, as the claim suggests that British interests were also negatively impacted, which is not directly supported by the textbook content.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that British colonial actions and policies in Africa led to economic instability and competition, adversely affecting both local economies and British commercial interests. The articles highlight disruptions in trade routes, such as the interruption of trade with Abeokuta due to the Ijaye war and the burning of the market town of Ejirin, which hindered local oil trade. The distrust and suspicion among interior people towards British occupation in Lagos, as well as the closing of trade routes by tribes like the Jebu and Egba, further illustrate the economic instability caused by British interventions. Additionally, the articles mention the adverse effects of foreign competition, with French and German annexations breaking the continuity of British protectorates and introducing different trading principles that harmed British commerce. The imposition of duties on British goods, while French and German goods were duty-free, exacerbated the competition. The articles also discuss the neglect of British commercial interests by the colonial administration, leading to a decline in trade and loss of influence over the natives. These details align with the claim, demonstrating how British colonial policies and military actions contributed to economic challenges in the region.
gha_sources:
[{'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the economic field', 'content': "Finally, whatever economic growth was achieved during the colonial period was done at a phenomenal and unjustifiable cost to the African - what with forced labour, migrant labour (which, says Davidson, 'probably did more to dismantle pre-colonial cultures and economies than most other aspects of the colonial experience put together'),$^{30}$ compulsory cultivation of certain crops, compulsory seizure of land, forced movements of popu› lations with the consequential dislocation of family life, the pass system, the high mortality rate in the mines and on the plantations, the brutality with which African resistance and protest movements generated by these measures were suppressed, etc. Above all, the monetary policies pursued by the colonial powers towards their colonies - tying their currencies to those of the colonial powers, introducing tariffs and keeping all foreign exchange earnings in the metropolitan capitals - while ensuring stable and fully convertible currencies, led to the freezing of colonial assets in the metropolitan capitals instead of their being realized and invested in the colonies. The repatriation of savings and deposits of Africans by the banks and the discrimination practised against Africans in the granting of loans further impeded African development.
