[{'id': 572, 'article_title': 'Parliamentary Intelligence', 'full_section_title': 'Parliamentary Intelligence', 'last_edit_date': '02-21-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1865#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_03_1865', 'content': "

Mr. Cave, in seconding the resolution, said he did not wish to be understood as concurring in all the observations of the right hon. gentleman. If, however, he had urged no other reason in support of his motion than the length of time that had elapsed since inquiry had taken place, he thought he was entitled to carry it. The investigation which took place in 1842 was held with a different object from that now on view, when the idea was all but universally entertained that no amount of money was too great to expend for the civilization of the African. A feeling, however, now prevailed that to tax this country heavily for such a purpose was rather going beyond the proper duty of the House. He quite agreed with the right hon. gentleman that the question of the slave-trade was one of supply and demand. At the same time, an important element which had not been alluded to entered into the question—namely, that of price. The present price of slaves was the only obstacle to the demand for them, being ten times as great as formerly. (Hear, hear.) He believed that if the blockading squadron were removed, if the settlements were suddenly taken away, the price of slaves would fall to such an extent, that the demand would enormously increase, and the supply follow; and that the Government of Spain, which he hoped was contemplating a different policy, would find the temptation to allow a continuance of the trade too strong for them to resist. (Hear, hear.) There could be no doubt that the settlements were in an unsatisfactory state, and he believed they had been conducted upon false principles from the beginning. Under the recommendation of the committee of 1842, crowds of recaptured Africans were maintained in idleness at the public expense, at a time when labourers in this country were only able to obtain precarious, and in many cases insufficient, means of livelihood. He agreed with his right hon. friend, that the suppression of the slave-trade was to be accomplished rather by concentration of means than by spreading them over a large surface. There was no reason to believe that the slave-trade was not going on along the West Coast of Africa, but there were no captures, because the fastest vessels on the coast were the slavers. The greatest speed of Her Majesty's cruisers was eight knots, while the slavers could make perhaps sixteen knots. (Hear, hear.) He could not go so far as to say that these settlements should be done away with; it might have been wrong to place them there in the first instance, and they might have been badly administered, but it would be impossible suddenly to suppress them. If they were suppressed the loss would be very great; other nations would probably take them up, and it would not be wise, he thought, to give to France a greater share of power on the West Coast of Africa. All these settlements had a considerable revenue, and he did not see why with better administration they might not be self-supporting. Sierra Leone had a revenue of 30,000l. a-year, but the expenditure was very great, the salaries alone having risen from 17,000l. in 1860 to 20,000l. in 1862. There was a mixed commission there, it was true, but it was a bad place for a mixed commission; vessels had to beat up to it; and few cases, therefore, had been taken there for adjudication. One of the subjects which the committee would have to investigate was the reason that while the imports and exports from the whole of the Coast had increased from 3,000,000l. to 4,000,000l., the commerce of the British settlements had decreased. It had been asked, what would be the use of the occupation of these stations, if the slave-trade was at an end? But they were useful for the prevention of piracy, and for the protection of British vessels in other parts of the Coast. The committee of 1842, which was founded upon a commission, examined a great many witnesses—Dr. Madden, who was the principal, and a number of naval and military officers who had been out on the Coast in question; and it would be a great pity if this inquiry should be conducted without sufficient witnesses of the best kind, and should fail in consequence of obtaining only speculative evidence. (Hear, hear.) He gladly seconded the motion for the committee."}, {'id': 1195, 'article_title': 'POLITICAL FUTURE OF WEST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'POLITICAL FUTURE OF WEST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1867#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_09_1867', 'content': 'WITH nations as with individuals, the germ of the future is in the womb of the present. It is this which gives to the present its importance and responsibility. If events in the future would be uninfluenced by what is now done or omitted to be done, we should have no right to demand of any Government or Administration that it should do more than provide and care for and attend to the wants and interests of the present; but recognizing this important truth, that days and years and generations are but stepping-stones to other days and years and generations beyond, and that the harvest reaped in the latter will depend in a great measure on the seed sown in the former, we feel bound to examine every act and omission of the British Government as regards West Africa in the light of the future. But this cannot be done without supposing a future, and viewing in perspective its general outlines. When therefore we undertook the work we are at present carrying on for the West Coast of Africa, we not only made a review of the past, and an examination of the actual state of affairs there, but set ourselves to consider what might and ought to be the future of those several countries over which the British flag was then and is now flying. To have merely occupied ourselves with the present, to have been merely chroniclers and critics of the month's events and proceedings, official, social, and material, would have made our task comparatively an easy one. But we should have felt like a mariner at sea without a compass, and steering for a port, latitude and longitude unknown. No permanent good could be thus achieved; the day's necessities and demands, the satisfaction of immediate and personal interests, would be paramount and supreme. And we now fear (and we say it with all respect) is the position and condition of the British Colonial-offices with regard to West Africa; in which Downing-street is but the reflex of the national mind. West Africa has been associated in public opinion with the slave-trade only. Our "forts and settlements" on the Coast have come into national possession, for the most part, through previous slave-trade occupancy, or for slave-trade repression; and so little had our public men ever thought of a future for them, that the great political party out of which the existing administration is formed, advocated ostensively in 1864 and 1865 to get rid of them for us altogether; while the Parliamentary Committee which sat to incubate this brilliant and statesmanlike idea (!) gave such prominence in its examination of witnesses to the question of whether those places on the West Coast were still necessary, or indispensable to the suppression of the slave-trade, as could not fail to give every one the impression that they did not think them nationally worth retaining on any other than anti-slavery trade grounds. It is not strange, then, that we should have had so often to complain of the evident want of some definite idea, some fixed principle, some ulterior policy, some large and comprehensive views with regard to the future of the population on that extensive and important Coast of Western Africa; but to us who regard each act of British rule there as the germ and nucleus of a future African nation, Christian, civilized, and prosperous, whose growth and development and future peace may be jeopardized thereby, it is deeply painful, though not surprising. And out of this deep pain comes one of our heaviest duties, that of striving to bring about such a change of public opinion in Great Britain with regard to Africa as shall lead to the adoption of a wise, noble, and generous policy on the part of the British Government towards our colonies and settlements on the West Coast. We do not for a moment conceal from ourselves the difficulties that are in our way; but we believe in those future African nations; we see how the British Government, without any intention of creating such, has been, and is being, made the reluctant agent in so doing; we recognize in this the action of an Omnipotent directing Power; and we feel the conviction that if we are right in our belief in those future African nations, the course of events, directed by unerring Wisdom overruling man's acts, will ere long work mightily with us against the apathy and indifference with which our public men now regard so important a subject as the future of the still far from depopulated countries lying upon and behind that long coast line of Western Africa—countries unsurpassed by any other on the earth in tropical fertility, and as lying so near to Europe rendered immensely more valuable thereby. When we commenced the African Times we were thought strangely mistaken in our ideas that the gradually increasing education on the Coast might be successfully appealed to; but every year has shown us an increasing interest felt by educated Africans there in those great questions, by the solution of which the more or less rapid advancement of the African countries now under British rule or protection will be determined. And our confidence daily increases, together with the conviction of the increasing necessity for our exertions. The imminent danger of the occupation of the River Melicourie by the French, in consequence of the utter disregard of Governor Blackall, notwithstanding the dreadful blow such an occupation must necessarily give to Sierra Leone as a British colony and future African State, affords a fresh evidence of the need of West Africa being carefully watched by those who do not look upon her countries and her people as doomed to unending barbarism and oppression, but as in course of preparation for, and gradual advancement to, Christian civilization, with the incalculable blessings that follow in its train—to security, freedom, and wealth. It has long been our intention to lay clearly before our readers in Africa and in England that future which we have conceived and believe in as'}, {'id': 3803, 'article_title': 'The French at Matacong', 'full_section_title': 'The French at Matacong', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1879#article-13', 'issue_date': '01_05_1879', 'content': "We do not like the news brought by the Senegal from Sierra Leone relative to the Island of Matacong; and yet we cannot bring our mind to believe that Governor Rowe should have been seized by the insane desire to imitate Lord Lytton and Sir Bartle Frere, and get up a little beginning of hostilities with the French. He will doubtless, we think, have recollected that the French are not exactly like Afghans or Zulus, any more than he is like Sir Bartle Frere or Lord Lytton. Yet it would seem so easy to send a few soldiers, as public rumour suggested, to pull down one flag and hoist another in its place, that we shall feel relieved when another steamer arrives with the intelligence that so insane a suggestion has not been listened to. That the continued British possession of Matacong is of vast importance to Sierra Leone, its trade and revenue, there cannot be the shadow of a doubt. It is therefore with pain we say that we do not feel by any means confident of the future British possession of Matacong. We see that the cession of 1826 is relied upon; but Sir George Grey repudiated that title, and we never took official possession. The French Government treat the matter in a very friendly spirit, as might be expected, stating it to be one for calm discussion between them and that of Great Britain. But we very much distrust the issue of this calm discussion. Neither Government will, we suppose, be inclined to give way. Then will come the proposal for an arbitration, which, of course, we shall feel bound to accept, and—which is also a matter of course, if we may judge by former experience of the results of similar arbitrations—the arbitrator's decision will be against the British claim, and the French will take full possession; acquiring thereby something additional to offer in exchange for the Gambia. For we still feel, as we have ever done, that the entire action of the French Government in the Sierra Leone rivers has had but one real end in view, but one supreme aim, and that is to obtain the River Gambia in exchange. We shall be glad to find that we are wrong, but we greatly fear that our misgivings will be justified by events. If our counsel and remonstrances had been listened to many years ago, this and other French dangers to Sierra Leone would have been nipped in the bud. They have been allowed to blossom and ripen into fruit that will, we fear, prove to be both disagreeable and dangerous to the interests of the metropolitan colony of the West Coast of Africa."}, {'id': 3813, 'article_title': 'The River Gambia as a Trading Route to the Interior of North-west Africa', 'full_section_title': 'The River Gambia as a Trading Route to the Interior of North-west Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1879#article-4', 'issue_date': '01_08_1879', 'content': '"The only present available road from the Upper Gambia to Sego for travellers is the northern one, passing through Wooli and Boudou to Senadaboo, the capital of that country, of which Barcarry Sadou is king. From thence the road goes through Kasson to the capital of that country, Madina, the king of which is brother-in-law to Barcarry Sadou. From this point the road goes to Kuniacarry, the frontier town of Bamburra, and thence to Sego. But as far as English interests are concerned this line is useless, as it passes too close to the French posts on the Senegal, and Barcarry Sadou is but a feudatory of France. Thus the road could any day be stopped to British commerce, even if the enormous Customs duties charged did not prohibit trade with Gambia. Thus the only available route for British trade is that already mentioned—from Yarburtenda, on the south bank of the Gambia, via Jellacotta. Now, Amadu, King of Sego, has, for the past three years, been most anxious to have a visit from an Englishman as the pioneer of the opening of trade with Gambia; and as he has either direct control over, or else tributary relations with, the countries between Bamburra and the head-waters of the Gambia, he can, once arrangements are made, easily open the southern road to Yarburtenda, and protect it afterwards. At present, not only do our Government give us no assistance whatever in pushing the trade in the Upper Gambia, but they throw obstacles in our way. They refuse to protect our trade, yet charge duties on imports and exports; and two years ago, when an English merchant wanted to build a large depot in the upper river, protect it by a stockade, and place men in it to defend it against marauders, the Administrator actually wrote to that merchant, and told him that if he built a stockade and armed his men, he (the Administrator) would notify to the natives that the merchant had no right to be there. This was tantamount to telling the natives they were at liberty to destroy the place.

"By the Treaty of Paris of 1875, Great Britain has sovereignty over the country from the Atlantic to the 10th degree of west longitude, and from Goree in the north to Cuzamanee in the south. Now, the 10th degree is more than half the distance to Sego. Well, there are two courses open to our Government—either to gradually occupy the territory east of M'Carthy Island, their highest post at present, to the 10th degree, and protect trade as the French do on the Senegal; or else draw a line at M'Carthy Island or Yarburtenda, and say, 'We will not protect you beyond this, and as we do not, we will not charge duties on imports into, or exports from, the country above that line, and you can, by every means in your power, push the trade to Sego and Timbuctoo without any interference on our part, and at the end of a certain period we will resume our jurisdiction—say thirty years.''}, {'id': 3861, 'article_title': 'Perils and Dangers to British Trade', 'full_section_title': 'Perils and Dangers to British Trade', 'last_edit_date': '09-08-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_10_1879', 'content': "Sir,—What is the Home Government about? What are your great capitalists, manufacturers, and merchants about? Are all asleep, or utterly reckless of the prosperity of our trade in West Africa? or each waiting for the other to move? In England the outcry is great; commercial depression and overstocked markets are bemoaned; yet none of the above influential people make the least stir to remedy this state of affairs by opening up fresh markets. While, on the other hand, if we turn to France, we see all is activity and energy there, and that, as matters at present portend, she is likely to take England's place in the commercial race in West Africa; and in the long run the volatile Latin race will overshadow and oust the energetic, proud, and great Anglo-Saxon one, and France will get Gambia.

While the English are doing literally nothing—have not advanced a mile into the interior the past thirty years, keeping always to the coast-line—France has pushed up the Senegal to Medina, 750 miles from St. Louis, and occupied that place.

Three expeditions under French auspices leave the Northwest Coast for the interior about next November: (1) one from Senegal, under M. Soleillet, which is to penetrate, via Macina, to Timbuctoo, on the Upper Niger, to open trade relations with that place; this is under the direct patronage of the French Government, and will work in connection with the intended surveying party for the Algiers, Senegal, and Soudan Railway; (2) an expedition leaves the Pongo River about the same time to penetrate to Sego on the Upper Niger; and (3) further south, again, another expedition leaves Sierra Leone for the country east of the Loma Mountains, and will penetrate to the great district embraced by the Kong Mountains on the west and the Niger River on the east. These two latter expeditions are sent out by the most enterprising French African merchants in Marseilles, but who have a close connection with the French Government.

Now let your readers scan a map of Africa, and they will at once see the bearing this new energy in French commerce will have on the interior trade of West Africa. The French trade ports once established on the Niger and in Soudan, French commerce and influence will gradually spread east and south, tap all the central markets, absorb the trade of that vast country, push back English trade year by year, till English productions are driven out of those markets they at present supply. English commerce being confined to the sea-coast towns, will in time die a lingering death, and we shall find France and her trade omnipotent from Senegal in the north to the delta of the Niger in the south, and from the Atlantic in the west to Houssa and Lake Tschad in the east. This is no fancy sketch, but is based on undoubted and, in some cases, accomplished facts."}, {'id': 4244, 'article_title': 'THE MEANS BY WHICH BRITISH TRADE IS DOOMED TO PERISH IN THE "GAMBIA."', 'full_section_title': 'THE MEANS BY WHICH BRITISH TRADE IS DOOMED TO PERISH IN THE "GAMBIA."', 'last_edit_date': '05-15-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1881#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_07_1881', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bathurst, Gambia, June, 1881.

Sir,—Some months ago I wrote the African Times as to some of the plans of the French Government for the occupation, possession, and development of the valley of the Upper Niger and the countries westward of it, as also the Soudan, and the consequent ruinous effects to this colony, that of Sierra Leone, and British home commercial interests. In that letter I said that among other places the French intended to survey and eventually occupy was Farabuna, a town in Bouree, about sixty miles east of the forks of the Gambia river, and close to the gold mines. Well, early in April a French medical official had instructions to start for North-west Africa, and visit the Bambouk, Mandingo, and Bouree countries, the Futa Jallon highlands, and go on to Timbo, as the principal commercial centre for the latter region. Thus you see the French are determined in time to shut us out from the interior, and confine us to the Atlantic seaboard.

The English expedition to Timbo has got there. Dr. Gouldsbury and his men have returned here, but whatever the results have been are only known to the Home Government; but it is remarkable that French newspapers say that had the English expedition attempted to penetrate beyond Timbo they would have been stopped. Does this mean that France claims sovereignty or holds power over all countries east of that town? If so, the sooner we are transferred to France the better for the improvement of trade here.—Your obedient servant,

FREDERIC SPEER.

---

THE MEANS BY WHICH BRITISH TRADE IS DOOMED TO PERISH IN THE "GAMBIA."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bathurst, Gambia, May 15th, 1881.'}, {'id': 4244, 'article_title': 'THE MEANS BY WHICH BRITISH TRADE IS DOOMED TO PERISH IN THE "GAMBIA."', 'full_section_title': 'THE MEANS BY WHICH BRITISH TRADE IS DOOMED TO PERISH IN THE "GAMBIA."', 'last_edit_date': '05-15-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1881#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_07_1881', 'content': "Sir,—For years, along with others connected with this colony, I have verbally and by letters to the Colonial Office, by letters and articles in the newspapers, warned the Government that unless a decided move was made into the interior to the Upper Niger, trade must languish here, and the French would push up from Senegal and cut us out; and that once they reached the Niger before us, it was only a question of time when the British Colonies would become isolated from the interior trade. In July, 1879, I saw Sir Michael Hicks-Beach in London, and told him I was ready to proceed to Sego at once, and had all the capital subscribed for opening and establishing a trade with that place from Gambia, that I could obtain a treaty of commerce with King Amadu, of Sego, giving a monopoly to British Trade. All I asked was for the Government to grant a monopoly to such trade as far as the Gambia was concerned, and allow us the goods imported duty free for, say, ten years from Yarbutenda. This was refused; I was told that I could go there at my own risk. Of course, I was quite aware of that, and no thanks to H.B.M.'s Government; but then, as soon as I had opened the road to Sego, and established a good trade with the head natives of the Gambia at heavy expense, which only a monopoly of several years could repay, the local Government at Gambia would encourage any and every one to crowd up the Upper Gambia, and by undue competition destroy the trade to the Niger as a profitable commercial speculation, just in order to gain for their revenue more customs, duties at the out-port of Bathurst, to be hoarded as a useless surplus, or expended on the staff and imperial pensioners. Many years ago a certain Administrator here, who was under obligations to the agent of a French house, at which time the French houses could not trade up the river beyond the ports of Bathurst and Albrida, His Excellency told that if he got permission from the Government to allow the French houses to trade in any part of the river it would be to his advantage. He used his influence with the Colonial Office, and the request was granted. Nothing more was heard about the debt. Knowing of this case I was determined to be on the safe side. Well, as the Home Government would do nothing the whole scheme fell to the ground, as I was aware, and so were my friends in England, that unless the expedition started at the end of 1879, we should be too late—the French would get there before us; and I warned Sir Michael Hicks-Beach of this. That my warning was only too true the following extract from the Moniteur du Sénégal proves. It is the text of a treaty made lately between Colonel Galleeni, who went to Sego nearly two years ago, and Amadu, king of that empire:—

Article 1st. Gives to France the right to establish trading posts, to the exclusion of all other nations.

Article 2nd. The right to navigate the Upper Niger.

Article 3rd. The Upper Niger to be under the protection of France."}, {'id': 4387, 'article_title': 'Reply to "A Native" and "Speramus Meliora."', 'full_section_title': 'Reply to "A Native" and "Speramus Meliora."', 'last_edit_date': '03-01-1882', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1882#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_03_1882', 'content': "Sego, and everyone in Bathurst would have benefited by the development and increase of trade; but though the plans were matured and the capital ready, the Home Government threw cold water on the scheme, to afterwards revive it in a poor sort of way by the useless expedition to Timbo. 1880 saw Colonel Galleini at Sego, his famous treaty signed. 1881 finds the French building their forts at Bafoulabe and Kita; and 1882 sees the commerce of this place cut off from the Upper Niger beyond recovery.

This is the only Crown Colony that I know of that is retrograding in prosperity; even such places as Heligoland and the Falkland Islands are not at a standstill, but here things are really bad. The remedies are—first, such alteration of the laws as will protect the honest and punish the dishonest; second, a stop to be put to the civil wars in the Badiboo and Jolah countries; third, to encourage the natives to raise some other kinds of produce besides ground nuts, produce that will be more valuable and not so expensive to handle as ground nuts; fourth, to open the road from Jellacotta, on the Upper Gambia, to the gold fields in Neolo, a distance of 70 to 100 miles, to work such mines and protect them from marauders. These mines are about as far as the French will let us go, provided they do not occupy them before us.

In writing about the Gambia and its trade I state facts either from my own personal knowledge or from the knowledge of people on whom I can rely. The majority of traders and other servants I have employed here I have found to be dishonest and indolent; some few I have had who were honest, energetic, and industrious. When I meet with such men I know them, and will submit to any faults they may have, even to occasional drunkenness, sooner than part with them. When men are the contrary, they deserve punishment. All employers agree in this.

As regards the proposed alteration of the law for debt, all the respectable natives now agree as to its benefit, and it is now only opposed by those who at present gain by the inoperative state of the law. Your correspondents seem to have the same views regarding personal property as Charles Stewart Parnell and his Communistic Land Leaguers have as regards real estate and the rents of the same; indeed, some of your correspondents publish their own moral code when they acknowledge to being parties to surreptitiously obtaining a copy of the proposed law out of the Governor's office, or cribbing extracts from the despatches of the Governor and the Acting-Collector of Customs to the Colonial Office."}, {'id': 4671, 'article_title': 'The French Protectorate of Porto Novo', 'full_section_title': 'The French Protectorate of Porto Novo', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1883#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_08_1883', 'content': 'We are not at all surprised to find that the local Lagos press complains bitterly of the French protectorate of Porto Novo. Lagos and Porto Novo, as one of the editors writes, are naturally, from their relative positions, parts of a single State; neither of them is, or can ever be, from physical, economical, and social reasons, complete without the other. This has been long since urged upon the British Government. Sir John Glover, when Governor of Lagos, was deeply penetrated by this truth, and, if our memory serves us aright, made strong representations to Downing Street of the absolute necessity (if Lagos was to fulfil the hopes entertained of her, and realize the objects in view when she was annexed) of the barbarous rule at Porto Novo being put an end to, by the pensioning off of its bloodthirsty ruler, and uniting it with Lagos. Nothing could seem to be more hopeless than any progress of civilization in Porto Novo while it should remain under native rule. King Tofa, the present ruler, has followed in the way of his predecessors, slaughtering no small number of human victims. It will, perhaps, be said that if this be the case, we ought to welcome the French protectorate there. This we cannot do, for at least two good reasons. First, that the place must, ere long, have been united with Lagos; and, secondly, that we do not believe the declaration of a French protectorate will exercise any beneficial influence. As from its position with regard to Lagos, and the channels of access to it from the sea, France cannot possibly turn the protectorate to any profitable account, we do not believe that she will, in any way, interfere with King Tofa's humane government. In the course of the correspondence which has appeared in the London papers about the New Hebrides, &c., we found it gravely stated that the French Government certainly would not do such a thing, because "it would be an unfriendly act." Now, a more unfriendly act than this declaration of a protectorate over Porto Novo we could scarcely conceive. France had no interests there, commercial or other, to protect, and the only safe approach to Porto Novo for merchandise is from within the Bar of Lagos, which is British. Cargo can occasionally be landed on the sea beach, from which it has then to be transported by hand to the town, but as the sea breaks heavily on that beach outside Lagos Bar, the operation is a risky one. So fully was this peculiar circumstance of situation and approach admitted, that with the first news of the declaration of a protectorate came also the rumour that the French Government would make a canal from the sea beach to the town—about as absurd an idea as could possibly be conceived; and although some strange projects seem to have got of late into French administrative minds, such a one as this is at least beyond the bounds of probability. However reputedly rich France may be, yet, with a population that has ceased to increase, with a revenue that for the present has ceased to be elastic, and with a very high and yearly increasing ordinary annual expenditure, she is not likely to throw away some millions in so unfruitful an enterprise as the attempt to cut such a canal would be. We cannot help, therefore, expressing anew our unfeigned regret that the French Government should have authorized or approved of such a measure as the assuming a protectorate over Porto Novo, which cannot bring to her anything but loss of honour, or expense without equivalent benefit. In its cry of distress The Lagos Times makes a remark which has just now, and will continue to have, a much wider application than to this matter of which it treats. The Editor says: "Little as England, on her own account, cares for such an acquisition [as Porto Novo], she should not so much have disregarded our interest in the matter, which is real, while it would be difficult to ascertain the extent of French interest in it; without driving out the Germans, which she would scarcely venture to do, or imposing unjust restrictions on their trade, her own trade [that of France] cannot be improved by the step." We have long foreseen that this diversity of interests between Great Britain and her colonies and settlements abroad must arise. The British Government very reasonably desires to limit the extent of its obligations beyond the seas. The Colonial Office is far from adequate to a proper performance of the work that at present devolves upon it; and as the Imperial revenue does not derive any direct benefit from colonial possessions and settlements, while each added one brings with it some new involvements, the British Government looks with an unfavourable eye upon annexations which are, perhaps, of vital interest to its colonies. We have before us, at the present time, the difference of opinion and sentiment between the Mother Country and the Australian Colonies as regards New Guinea and New Hebrides. The Australian Colonies, now growing so rapidly in wealth and population, are naturally on their outlook as regards their future. They say to the British Government: "Yes, very likely New Guinea and the New Hebrides are of little or no consequence to you, but our interest in their acquisition is a vital one: the Australian countries must have regard to their future, and they do not feel that that future will be what it ought to be unless New Guinea and the New Hebrides are secured from falling into the hands of some other European Power." A letter which we publish in this present number expresses the apprehension of the British and Native traders in the Trans-Volta district of the Gold Coast Colony, that if the British Government will not authorize that of the Gold Coast to annex the small but commercially important residue of the Coast up to the boundaries of Dahomey (which the legitimate native authorities have more than once prayed the local British Government of the Gold Coast to receive into that colony), it will ere long be taken possession of by the French. This would be another most "unfriendly act," it is true; but after the affair of Porto Novo, we ought to be on our guard, particularly as some daring opposers of the legitimate chiefs hoisted the French flag some time ago. It was from prevision that something of this kind might happen that, some twenty years ago, we advised and assisted in obtaining the annexation of the Sherbro' countries, as an appendage to the colony of Sierra Leone; and that we advised the annexation of the River countries near Sierra Leone, where French influences have since prevailed to the injury of the colony. We do think that in such cases as Porto Novo, and, again, as the Popos, the British Government should be more alive to the necessity of protecting the interests of its colonies and settlements abroad.'}, {'id': 5104, 'article_title': 'SHRINKAGE OF EMPIRE.', 'full_section_title': 'SHRINKAGE OF EMPIRE.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_05_1885', 'content': 'A short time ago, while the Congo Conference was sitting, England declared the navigation of the Gambia River, on the West Coast of Africa, open to the commerce of all nations. There was a certain appearance of magnanimity about the act; and magnanimous it might really have been under different circumstances. As a matter of fact, the Government were compelled to do what they did by the squeezing-out process which the French have been so quietly but relentlessly employing against us in that region. This policy was carried on with much determination during the Second Empire, but has been pursued more vigorously than ever since the conclusion of the war with Germany. On the 10th of this month Reuter's agents informed us that a French officer, a Captain Combes, had taken up an excellent position on the Upper Niger; that three posts—Bamakou, Kondou, and Bafoulabé—were provisioned for twelve months, and telegraphic communication established between them. They further added that the launch of the French gunboat now on the Niger was preparing to descend the stream to Timbuctoo with the rising of the waters. At first sight there may appear nothing of importance in all this; but a glance at the map will show that it is a serious step towards the barring out of British trade with that part of the interior of Africa.

As far back as 1849 one of the most energetic and far-seeing of the Governors of the Gambia—the late Sir Richard Graves MacDonnell—writing to Earl Grey on his travels in Bondou, a fertile territory between the Upper Gambia and Senegal, says: "I had frequent interviews with the Almamy, or the Mohammedan Sovereign of Bondou, and was successful in inducing him to enter into an agreement to protect travellers through his country to the Gambia, on receiving certain annual presents from the merchants. I was also equally successful in making a similar agreement with the King of Woolli—both which agreements subsist to this day, and, on the whole, have been as faithfully observed by the two kings as could reasonably be expected. I was fortunate enough to prevent at that period the Almamy's ratifying a treaty with the French, whereby he was to bind himself to 'shut the roads,' as it is called, against the 'coffles,' or country caravans, proceeding from the neighbourhood of the Senegal to the Gambia through his dominions. I actually met in the interior the gentleman sent by the French Government from St. Louis to Bondou for the above purpose, as is mentioned by one of them in the published narrative of their travels." (Vide "Voyage dans l'Afrique Occidentale," par A. Raffenel, p. 484.)'}, {'id': 5192, 'article_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'full_section_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_09_1885', 'content': 'This subject is (says the *Manchester Guardian*, in a series of excellent articles upon the present state of the West Coast of Africa, now under publication) a very wide one, the trade of Africa being carried on under such different conditions, by such different races, and the goods dealt in being so various, that it would seem difficult to bring all under one discussion; but, unfortunately, all the trade of Africa has one great point of similarity, and that is that all is depressed, and much is passing into the hands of foreign competitors. A Royal Commission has been appointed to inquire into the causes of depression in trade. The causes of the depression in African trade are not far to seek, and the remedies must be applied by the Government, and not by the merchants. The apathetic policy which has been pursued, the systematic ignoring of those who have knowledge and experience, and the entrusting of important interests to incompetent hands, have had the effects which were to be expected, and unless some decisive action is taken soon, we may expect our African trade to go from bad to worse, and be all transferred from London, Liverpool, and Bristol to Hamburg, Havre, and Marseilles.'}, {'id': 5452, 'article_title': 'BRITISH TRADE ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'BRITISH TRADE ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_12_1886', 'content': 'Mr. Eli Sowerbutts has received the following letter from a gentleman who has just returned from the West Coast of Africa:—

"On my passage through Liverpool I observed that you were to read a paper on the 'Recent European Acquisitions in Africa.' As I have just returned from the Gold Coast Colony, I have had an opportunity of watching the acquisition of other European Powers, which threaten the destruction of British trade in those parts. I should be obliged if you would call the attention of your Society to this, as at present the Colonial and Foreign Offices are indifferent to all encroachments—so indifferent that they do not care to be informed of the facts. In 1882 a Commission was appointed to define the western frontier; they sent in their report, which has been duly filed and ignored, the result being that the French have occupied countries which were formerly British. The French now hold that part of Apollonia north of the Tando River, marked A A A in the map, where they have established stations for the purpose of smuggling goods into British territory. The King of Apollonia is surprised and indignant at this proof of the value of British protection, as he naturally thought that protection has some other meaning besides the payment of Custom duties. The French have also seized Aowin (on the west bank of the Tando, north of Apollonia), which country joined the British protectorate in 1824 or 1825, in the time of Sir Charles Macarthy. They still show with pride the flag given to them on that occasion. They supplied Sir Charles with a large contingent when he fought and was defeated by the Ashantees. Within the last few months the French have annexed Sehwi (north of Aowin and Wassaw). All this is preliminary to the annexation of Ashanti, which will cut us off from all communication with the interior. The Ashantees have recently frequently begged the British Government to assume the protectorate, but have failed to get the question entertained, owing to the want of knowledge of and appreciation of the value of the country by the Colonial Office officials.'}, {'id': 5724, 'article_title': 'Intrigues of the French in West Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Intrigues of the French in West Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_08_1888', 'content': 'previously used to go by the customary mail routes to Liverpool. The English were to blame in not extending their position more into the interior. They ought not to rest satisfied with the fringe of country which they possessed at present. If they sat down and did nothing, and were simply content with the palm oil and kernel trade, he was afraid that in a few years' time the African trade would pass out of the district. He concluded by moving the following resolution: "That the African Trade Section of the Chamber write to the Colonial Secretary, asking him to receive a deputation from the merchants and shipowners of Liverpool on the subject of the proposed French protectorate at Abeokuta."

Mr. RADCLIFFE seconded.

After some discussion, it was resolved that the Manchester and Glasgow Chambers of Commerce be asked to join the deputation.

Our readers will find a full account of the reception of this deputation by Lord Knutsford in another column (p. 117).'}, {'id': 5728, 'article_title': 'Liverpool and the West African Trade', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool and the West African Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_08_1888', 'content': 'Mr. Hutchinson said he was a member of the Legislative Council at Lagos. They were informed that an agent of the French Government had been to Abeokuta, and had succeeded in making an agreement for a treaty which was to be ratified by means of presents to the amount of £3,000, to be made in September next. They were given to understand that the object of the treaty was to divert from Lagos the large trade from the interior which came down the river Ogun to Porto Novo. This river was the only waterway for heavy traffic from the interior to Lagos, and whoever was master at Abeokuta could do as they pleased with the trade. The French were now firmly established at Porto Novo, and they had also got control of another small port to the westward, and the fact of their having that port had a great influence on the tariff at Lagos. The French having established themselves on our western border, were now supposed to be working down to Abeokuta on the north. The deputation therefore hoped the Colonial Office would take some steps which would enable them to checkmate the French in that quarter, either by treaties or some small subsidies given to those on our immediate frontier, thus making British influence felt and paramount far outside the limits of British jurisdiction. A long residence at Lagos had convinced him that the most educated and intelligent of the natives appreciated the equal-handed justice with which they were treated under British rule, and would rather see their country under British protection than under any other foreign Power. He would also urge that if the French were allowed to establish themselves at Abeokuta they would be able to make it a basis for interfering with the Niger traffic.

Mr. F. Radcliffe said that English traders were placed at a great disadvantage when the French established a colony alongside one of ours, because when trade was bad the French were enabled to come over the border and have the advantage of perfect free trade with our colony, whereas, if we wanted to go into the French colony and trade, all sorts of difficulties were thrown in our way, the goods of English traders were confiscated, and they had no remedy.

Mr. Bond said the Liverpool steamship companies trading with the West Coast represented a capital of over a million sterling. At the present time a imports and exports of Lagos were very considerable, and any action tending to diminish the trade would seriously affect the steamship companies.'}, {'id': 5728, 'article_title': 'Liverpool and the West African Trade', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool and the West African Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_08_1888', 'content': 'Mr. Schwann, on behalf of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce, sympathized with the objects of the deputation. He said Manchester and the district were intimately allied with the port of Liverpool, and it was a matter of great concern to the Lancashire cotton trade that all the markets they had at present should be kept open. He would urge that it was not desirable that the French should be allowed to make arrangements for the continuation of slavery. The commercial communities of England looked with very great confidence to the Colonial Office and the Foreign Office to do as much as they possibly could to foster and protect British trade with foreign countries.'}, {'id': 5731, 'article_title': 'Leader', 'full_section_title': 'Leader', 'last_edit_date': '08-01-1888', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_08_1888', 'content': 'The success of a mission sent to that protectorate of France has already assured a large increase of trade to the French establishments on the Upper Niger. Colonel Gallieni has built a fort at Siguri, the confluence of the Niger and the Tenkisso, in the heart of the Soudanese gold country. It has been placed in direct telegraphic communication with Paris, and a railway towards the coast is in course of construction. All this, it will be admitted, is rapid and substantial progress; and it is not to be supposed that France will now be content to abandon the dream of extending her dominion from the Niger to the Mediterranean. The Sahara has lost much of its terror and its mystery, and by means of a series of artesian wells it may be possible to overcome all difficulties connected with the supply of water, and to construct a line of railway across the desert from the Senegal or the Niger to Algiers. But there are the tribes to be reckoned with, and it is extremely unlikely that peoples who have hitherto fiercely resented all intrusion will all at once become mild-mannered enough to permit the French or anybody else to build a railway right across their preserves. In any attempt of the kind they would see a covert attack upon the slave trade; and their jealousy of all interference in that regard is notorious. For the present, therefore, the project of a railway across the Saharan desert may be dismissed as chimerical. The fact remains, however, that France has of late obtained a very considerable influence in North-western Africa—an influence of which the progress should be carefully watched in this country. There is room in Africa itself for all the Powers; but Great Britain will have to look closely to her position on the West Coast, lest French influence should undermine her influence there.'}, {'id': 5742, 'article_title': 'GERMANY AND ENGLAND IN WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'GERMANY AND ENGLAND IN WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1888#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_09_1888', 'content': 'The Company is first of all a trading concern, bound to make as large dividends as possible; but its trade must be conducted in accordance with regulations laid down by the British Government. It is the business of the Government to discover if any regulations as to navigation, as to export and import duties, as to limits of trade and other restrictions, infringe the provisions of the Berlin Act. Let us not forget what the Company has already done to rescue the region from anarchy. It is, indeed, maintained that Colonial Office rule in our older West African colonies has been throughout disastrous to their interests, and has roused a feeling of chronic irritation among all who have any business interests there, or the welfare and dignity of the Empire at heart. Partly through ignorance of elementary geography, partly through blindness as to foreign intentions, partly through a rooted dislike to exertion and trouble, our Colonial Office has shamefully neglected British interests in West Africa.

This is too strikingly seen in what has been allowed to take place in the region behind Lagos. The entire trade of that colony is threatened with extinction, and it is no wonder that the merchants of Liverpool and London are indignant with our Colonial Office. Two-fifths of that trade is in the hands of the Egbas of Abeokuta, and the remainder in the hands of the Jebus and other tribes, over whom the Egbas have sufficient influence to prevent their trading with whom they please. If our Government do not act promptly we shall be obliged to abandon Lagos for want of a revenue or of any trade to make it worth holding. Yet the Lagos Government were warned, some months ago, of the intentions of a Frenchman who went (actually through Lagos) to Abeokuta; but they ridiculed the idea, and now we have to reckon with the treaties which that Frenchman has made with the Abeokutans, and which, if enforced, will drive Lagos into the sea. It is to be hoped that the Colonial Office will find some way out of this difficulty which will be satisfactory to those British mercantile houses who are so largely interested in West Africa.'}, {'id': 6068, 'article_title': 'FRANCE AND ENGLAND ON THE NIGER.', 'full_section_title': 'FRANCE AND ENGLAND ON THE NIGER.', 'last_edit_date': '02-02-1891', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1891#article-0', 'issue_date': '02_02_1891', 'content': 'I must preface this article by two definitions. For want of a better concise name I shall use the vague term "Central Africa" to describe the more or less malarious portion of that continent lying between (say) the eighteenth parallels of north and south latitude, exclusive of the maritime regions within twenty or thirty miles of the seaboard, which can look to European fleets for protection of life and property. Central Africa, thus defined, is about thirty times the area of France, and fifty times that of the United Kingdom, and probably contains about one-twelfth of the population of the globe. In the second place, and for the same reason, I use the word "England" for "Great Britain and Ireland," and "Englishmen" for the inhabitants of this country. "Britain" and "Britons" are, unfortunately, considered pedantic in prose.

The Anglo-German and Anglo-Portuguese agreements of 1890 have induced a colonial movement in France which, in this age of electricity, may be described as a strong secondary current. Competent authorities tell us that this agitation is no longer confined to colonial enthusiasts, but has penetrated into the mass of the nation; and a number of expeditions have lately been despatched from widely separated points of the African coast to extend French rights into the heart of the continent. The inadequate recognition in England of this movement may perhaps be attributed to a well-founded belief on the part of "Our own Correspondents" that the British public has lately had a surfeit of the Dark Continent.

It may seem illogical that the demarcation by other countries of spheres of influence in East and South Africa should affect the estimates which France had previously formed of the value of the regions bordering on her possessions in the north and west of the Continent; but it is not in France alone that the fever of annexation proves contagious. To this cause, principally, may be attributed the popularity of propositions for the immediate occupation of vast areas of Central Africa. Two minor causes have contributed to this movement. The first has been the downfall of the Boulangists, who had opposed colonial adventures; partly, no doubt, from a belief in the necessity of concentrating the forces of France at home, and, perhaps, partly from a desire to oppose any policy which had been adopted by their bête noire. Now M. Ferry, having recognised the hegemony of Germany in Europe, had, during his tenure of power, sought to direct the energies of France to compensations abroad. The reaction against Boulangism has
**19**'}, {'id': 6383, 'article_title': 'FRANCE AND THE ROYAL NIGER COMPANY.', 'full_section_title': 'FRANCE AND THE ROYAL NIGER COMPANY.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1893#article-1', 'issue_date': '02_10_1893', 'content': 'taken by Lieut. Mizon nor of the movements of the vessels, and the blockade was in full force. They therefore declined to assist M. Hoelle, without otherwise interfering with his full liberty of movement and action. Up to this moment we know not whether M. Mizon intends to obey or disregard the summons of his Government, nor where he is nor what he is doing. We have been informed that since our refusal of a passage to M. Hoelle the French vessels have been moved up to Yola, which I may say in passing, having reference to the town, not to the province, is within the territories of the Company. Our officers found the French flag still flying on the Muri factories after the departure of the vessels. These circumstances justify the refusal of the Company to afford M. Hoelle the assistance we recently and gladly gave to M. Maistre. Until every vestige had disappeared of an expedition which has assumed so hostile an attitude towards the Company, and whose continued presence in the waters of Muri was to the native Princes the symbol of French triumph over British rights, we refuse to give any facilities to the movements of French emissaries. Enough mischief has already been done without running the risk of more.

"In conclusion, I venture to say that, while I have a great admiration for the ability of The Temps and Figaro, and respect for their character as journals, I cannot but be disappointed at their allowing conduct such as Lieut. Mizon's has been shown to be to pass without one word, one hint, of moral disapprobation.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

"ABERDARE,

"Governor of the Royal Niger Company."

On the day after the appearance of this letter, The Times published a leading article upon the subject, of which we append the substance:—'}, {'id': 6403, 'article_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN MAHDI', 'full_section_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN MAHDI', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_12_1893#article-6', 'issue_date': '04_12_1893', 'content': '

The whole Colony has to pay the piper, for we have already lost Heremakono, and shall probably lose much more. Besides having lost prestige with the natives of our own sphere, who welcome the French as the conquerors of their oppressors, the Sofas, it seems that now we have earned the enmity of the Sofas themselves. These people, being totally unacquainted with the subtleties by which the Freetown merchants might explain or excuse their action in supplying them with the means of fighting the French, looked at the transaction from the point of view natural to a native, and concluded that the English would help them with men as well as with weapons, when the time came. They fully expected when the tide of war came to Heremakono that the local Government would back them up, and it is possible that their expectations were based upon promises made to them by irresponsible persons engaged in the trade in arms. Finding that they were not helped by us, and finding also that in consequence of the Brussels Convention they could no longer obtain breechloaders from Freetown, they now cry out that they have been deceived, and they have threatened to destroy Falaba. In the meantime they are ravaging and destroying in Kuranko, the most fertile and promising of the Native States in the British sphere, and have already killed and deported hundreds of the Natives. This, then, is the present situation, and the question is, What are we to do? Shall we protect the Natives of our sphere from the tyranny of the Sofas, or shall we leave our hinterland to take care of itself, as we have hitherto done? There is this to be said in favour of the laisser aller policy, that the three-cornered patch of territory, which is all that remains to us as the result of the Conventions with France of 1889 and 1891, is at the present time completely worthless. It produces nothing, and owing to the Sofas international wars, and the overland slave trade, the population has been so thinned that it will be many years before the country can be made valuable agriculturally. Sierra Leone has hitherto chiefly depended on the trade from beyond the Niger, but now that the French have pushed down to the sources of that river, that trade is completely cut off, and will, of course, be diverted to French ports. We can either withdraw altogether to the peninsula of Sierra Leone, and make it and the coaling station a sort of West African Gibraltar, or we can act with vigour in the territory that remains to us, putting down Native wars and protecting life and property, in the hope that when confidence is restored and population increases, products of some sort may be grown; but it would be a very long time before we received any return for our preliminary outlay. In any case, as the Sofas are now engaged in destroying the best part of the territory still left to us, and the Natives, despairing of help from us, are offering their lands to the French, it behoves us to decide quickly what our future policy shall be, otherwise there will soon be nothing left to conserve.  
—*Pall Mall Gazette.*'}, {'id': 6415, 'article_title': 'FRENCH COLONIAL POLICY IN WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'FRENCH COLONIAL POLICY IN WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1894#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_01_1894', 'content': 'We now come to the last French colony on the West Coast (Gaboon, on the South-west Coast, excluded)—namely, Benin, including the coast towns of Kotonou, Porto Novo, &c., and the newly acquired Protectorate of Dahomey, bounded on the west by German Togoland, and on the east by Lagos and Voruba. Here once more we find all the "hinterland" of Dahomey to the west and north secured to France. The Say-Barroua line marking the limits of French influence, according to the Anglo-French agreements, extends perpendicularly to the eastern frontier of Dahomey.

Such is the position of the French in West and Northern Central Africa, and a glance at a map of the district clearly shows that with a degree of slothfulness utterly inexplicable we have allowed France to step in behind most of our colonies and secure the rich "Hinterlands" in the rear. Gambia, Sierra Leone, and the Gold Coast are now completely isolated, small red spots in a great sea of French territory. It may and will be argued that the French lay claim to these enormous tracts of land in a purely nominal way, that they are not likely to interfere with our trade in these regions, and that if it pleases them to colour them French on their maps, why it is a harmless amusement, which cannot possibly affect us in any way. Unfortunately, we find upon examining the question that these arguments do not hold good. In the first place, the French, unfortunately, do not lay claim to these regions in a purely nominal way; it would seem, on the contrary, that they are secured to them by virtue of regular treaties with ourselves and with the native chiefs, if not with our approval, at least with our tacit consent. Secondly, as to their not interfering with our trade: certainly, they have not done so far to any great extent, but everything tends to show that they are beginning to do so in good earnest. The events which are taking place behind Sierra Leone are ample proof of this. French outposts are slowly advancing along our frontier line, and we are continually learning from the local papers of caravans on their way to Freetown being turned aside and obliged to take the roads leading to the French Coast Settlements. The Mohammedan chief, Samadoo, upon whose trade the colony of Sierra Leone is in a great measure dependent, and who has always been friendly towards England, is now (if we are to believe French reports) completely crushed by the two French columns sent against him in the early part of the present year.'}, {'id': 6415, 'article_title': 'FRENCH COLONIAL POLICY IN WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'FRENCH COLONIAL POLICY IN WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1894#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_01_1894', 'content': 'It would be folly not to consider this state of things as a very bad outlook for the future prosperity of our colony, and it is high time we should realise the full importance of French action and the consequences it may have for us. I have striven to demonstrate, and I hope with some success, the importance there is for us to watch closely the movements of our neighbours in the actual neighbourhood of our own colonies. It is equally necessary to watch them elsewhere in Africa. Men like Maistre, Mizon, Monteil, Binger, Quiquandon, &c., are exploring the Central Soudan empires in all directions: Mizon (of whom we have heard a great deal lately) in Adamawa, Binger in Kong, Bondoukou, &c., Quiquandon at Sikasso, bringing everywhere French merchandise and French ideas and making commercial treaties *en route*. Neither must we overlook De Brazza in French Congo, pushing further and further up the Sangha River towards Adamawa and Lake Tchad.

It is evident to the most impartial observers that the French are displaying the most extraordinary activity in West Africa; their avowed object is to create a great West African empire. They have been temporarily checked by the late Anglo-German Convention, but they have secured as it is enormous tracts of land, and they have crept in behind our colonies, endangering their future prosperity. Surely it is time to wake up and realise what is going on. English interests, English trade, and English capital are largely bound up in West Africa. English enterprise has always been to the fore in that part of the world, as elsewhere. Shall we allow it henceforth to take a secondary place?

As France is doing in West Africa, so has she been doing in the East; as she has done in the East, so will she do in West Africa, if we allow her. What do all the coast papers tell us? They tell us that our West African colonies are gradually losing faith in us. The protests of our subjects—black and white—are disregarded, are treated with indifference and contempt. Shall we, by a shortsighted and fatal policy, let colonies, which have hitherto been prosperous and wealthy, dwindle down into mere settlements, alike useless and burdensome to their mother country?—*A Correspondent who has studied it in "The Pall Mall Gazette."*'}]
