[{'id': 591, 'article_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'full_section_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '03-09-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'issue_date': '24_04_1865', 'content': 'If, however, prices do not soon fall to their original level, there is no doubt but that cotton will be cultivated successfully at the Gambia, though it is to be hoped not to the exclusion of the ground-nut.

The export of hides has not varied much in the ten years previous to 1864, and the value of wax exported remains much what it has been of late years.

The principal articles of import are (Return No. 2, Appendix) cotton goods, rice, and tobacco; a large proportion of the population being Mohammedan, the consumption of spirits is not as great as in the other settlements. In cotton goods, there is but little variation during the last ten years, and the same may be said of tobacco. Rice, owing to the famine caused by the recent wars amongst the natives, has become a large article of consumption, and, as it can be procured at a reasonable rate, it will very likely continue to form a considerable portion of the food of the people, who will devote more land to the cultivation of produce and less to that of corn, &c.

In the Appendix is given a Return (No. 3) of the imports and exports for the last eleven years. The imports of 1863 were the highest ever known, and next in amount to them come those of 1864; it is alleged in the colony, that this does not arise from the importation of a larger quantity of goods in these two years, but from the circumstance that in 1863 there came into operation a law by which all import duties, except upon wine, spirits, and tobacco, were abolished, and an export duty on ground-nuts substituted in lieu thereof. The result of this law has been to remove all motive on the part of the importer for concealing the value of his goods, and the returns made since then represent the true value of the imports of the colony. It is impossible to ascertain how far this statement is correct, but no other explanation of the fact was offered by any one.

The exports for the last eleven years show considerable variation, and in each of the last six years are below the average of the whole period. This is unquestionably due to the wars and disturbances which have prevailed among the natives during this time, and until peace is re-established, and confidence in its continuance restored, any improvement can hardly be looked for.

The capabilities of the country to produce oil nuts and seeds, are limited only by the extent of the population, of whom only a fraction at present employ themselves in cultivation; but a growing disposition to avail themselves of the advantages which it offers is being manifested by the natives, even at a considerable distance from the settlement, and it may be hoped that this feeling will not be without its effect in checking those local disturbances which have of late proved so injurious to the prosperity of the colony.'}, {'id': 4975, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN NOTES', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN NOTES', 'last_edit_date': '12-01-1884', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1884#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_12_1884', 'content': 'A deputation of merchants of Manchester and Liverpool has had an interview with Lord Derby on the state of affairs in British Sherbro' and Sierra Leone. The disturbances that had taken place had seriously affected their trade, and they suggested sending out a special commissioner to obtain some agreement with the natives, and to restore peace. The deputation further urge that Sir Samuel Rowe should be appointed by the Colonial Office, as possessing the confidence of both natives and merchants. Lord Derby promised to have an interview with Sir Samuel, in order to see whether the request of the deputation could be carried out.

A new magazine, entitled the *Deutsche Kolonialzeitung*, which has just made its appearance, may be regarded as one of the results of the "colonization fever" in Germany. It is published fortnightly by the German Colonization Club, at Frankfort-on-Main, in order "to arouse the interest of all classes in Germany in the colonial policy of the country, to further German enterprise in the colonies, to strengthen the relations between Germans in all parts of the globe by intercourse with the Fatherland, and to spread the knowledge of foreign countries and peoples." The October number of the *Deutsche Kolonialzeitung* gives an interesting account of the growth of German colonization during the last five years, and especially during the current year on the West Coast of Africa, and is accompanied by a comprehensive sketch, with maps of "Deutsch Africa."

It appears that the Swazi King is seeking our protection, and the suggestion is thrown out by a contemporary that the Colonial Office should telegraph to Mr. Thompson, late British Vice-Consul at Delagoa Bay, and send him to negotiate. Mr. Thompson knows the Swazies thoroughly, and by good luck he is now in South-east Africa. Why not employ him at once on special service in Swaziland?

The eastern districts of the Cape are indebted to Mr. J. B. Hellier, who brought with him from Cape Town a plant of a recently-introduced cactus from Mauritius, which is like the ordinary prickly pear in appearance, except for the important difference that it has not a single thorn or hair upon it. It is used in Mauritius as a forage plant, and it is expected that it will prove a most valuable boon to colonial farmers, as furnishing food for their stock in the dry season without the hindrance of damaging the mouths of the cattle as the prickly pear does.'}, {'id': 4976, 'article_title': 'German Treaty with the Chiefs of Bageida', 'full_section_title': 'German Treaty with the Chiefs of Bageida', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1884#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_12_1884', 'content': '**173**

---

**AFRICAN NOTES.**

A deputation of merchants of Manchester and Liverpool has had an interview with Lord Derby on the state of affairs in British Sherbro' and Sierra Leone. The disturbances that had taken place had seriously affected their trade, and they suggested sending out a special commissioner to obtain some agreement with the natives, and to restore peace. The deputation further urge that Sir Samuel Rowe should be appointed by the Colonial Office, as possessing the confidence of both natives and merchants. Lord Derby promised to have an interview with Sir Samuel, in order to see whether the request of the deputation could be carried out.

A new magazine, entitled the *Deutsche Kolonialzeitung*, which has just made its appearance, may be regarded as one of the results of the "colonization fever" in Germany. It is published fortnightly by the German Colonization Club, at Frankfort-on-Main, in order "to arouse the interest of all classes in Germany in the colonial policy of the country, to further German enterprise in the colonies, to strengthen the relations between Germans in all parts of the globe by intercourse with the Fatherland, and to spread the knowledge of foreign countries and peoples." The October number of the *Deutsche Kolonialzeitung* gives an interesting account of the growth of German colonization during the last five years, and especially during the current year on the West Coast of Africa, and is accompanied by a comprehensive sketch, with maps of "Deutsch Africa."

It appears that the Swazi King is seeking our protection, and the suggestion is thrown out by a contemporary that the Colonial Office should telegraph to Mr. Thompson, late British Vice-Consul at Delagoa Bay, and send him to negotiate. Mr. Thompson knows the Swazies thoroughly, and by good luck he is now in South-east Africa. Why not employ him at once on special service in Swaziland?

The eastern districts of the Cape are indebted to Mr. J. B. Hellier, who brought with him from Cape Town a plant of a recently-introduced cactus from Mauritius, which is like the ordinary prickly pear in appearance, except for the important difference that it has not a single thorn or hair upon it. It is used in Mauritius as a forage plant, and it is expected that it will prove a most valuable boon to colonial farmers, as furnishing food for their stock in the dry season without the hindrance of damaging the mouths of the cattle as the prickly pear does.'}]

[{'document_title': 'Ruinous Native Wars and Inaction of the Government', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Locally, news is scarce. The latest news from the river is that Biram Ceasey has taken one more port, and is preparing to attack another. That will leave only three ports open for trade in 100 miles of river frontage in the Budiboo country, and those three ports are not safe—may be attacked any time. This war in Budiboo is a sad injury to the trade of Gambia, as it reduces the output of produce at least 8,000 to 9,000 tons, and closes a large market for English manufactures. Very small action on part of the Government would put an end to it, but they refuse on the score of the trouble and expense, and this with a surplus of £23,000 in hand. Now, how much would it cost to keep a sloop-of-war here one month that could land 200 men, a Gatling gun, and one small shell gun? Yet in that time or perhaps less, both Biram Ceasey in Budiboo, and Fody Cubbu in the Jolah country, who are ruining the trade, could be put down. Indeed, the natives themselves say, "If the Government would only interfere, they would be compelled to make peace." In fact war has so wasted these countries that both sides are worn out, and only continue the fight through pride. Surely the cost of a man-of-war for such a time would be well repaid by the preservation yearly to the commerce of this place of such a large amount of produce. As the English Government will not help us, then, now that the French have isolated us from the interior trade, our only chance of safety from ruin is transfer to France.

There is a rumour, via France, that negotiations are going on in Paris to arrange a transfer, and most people here are anxiously awaiting the result, and hoping that France will get this place.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-07-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1881#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.712, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Trade in the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Colonel Stanley is fully alive to the danger and difficulties to which trade is exposed at the Gambia by reason of the constant civil wars and disturbances which take place along the banks of the river, and he is anxious to find some means of protecting it.

It is obviously impossible for Her Majesty's Government to undertake to put down the native wars and punish the marauding chiefs by means of military force, and Colonel Stanley is of opinion that a naval expedition would be likely to fail of success, and to have no lasting effect, as on the appearance of ships of war the chiefs would simply withdraw their forces a short distance into the interior, where they could be safe from any naval attack, and on the retirement of the vessels would return again to the river banks and renew their depredations with increased violence and hostility.

Colonel Stanley is, however, in correspondence with the Admiralty with the view of endeavouring to arrange that Her Majesty's ships on the West African station should pay more frequent visits to the Gambia, in order to show that a sufficient force is at hand if an opportunity of using it with effect should occur.

Colonel Stanley proposes now to send copies of your letters to the Governor of the West African Settlements, and desire him, so soon as he can properly leave Sierra Leone, to proceed to the Gambia and inquire into the matters complained of; to endeavour, if possible, to negotiate with Beram Ciesey, and the other chiefs, for the maintenance of peace and the neutrality of the river banks; and to report generally what steps he would recommend for the protection of trade.

As you are no doubt aware, Sir S. Rowe's extensive knowledge and experience of West African affairs, and his influence with the natives, has already enabled him to do much towards the re-establishment of peace and order, and the development of trade in the countries adjacent to Sierra Leone; and Colonel Stanley has every confidence that his skill and judgment will produce equally beneficial results at the Gambia.—I am, &c.,", 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Trade in the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We have been requested to publish the following correspondence:—

(Copy.)

Chamber of Commerce, Manchester, Oct. 13th, 1885.  
To the Right Hon. Colonel Stanley, M.P., &c., &c., Colonial Office, London.

Sir,—On the 9th September last I had the honour to enclose you a copy of a letter which had been addressed to this Chamber relative to the disastrous condition of affairs in the Gambia—caused, in a great measure, by the robberies of native chiefs upon British property, on a river which, for the past 70 years, has been subject to the sovereignty of Great Britain.

To my communication of the foregoing date, I have not as yet been favoured with any reply.

Gambia merchants tell this board that the losses incurred by them during the last two or three years amount to over 25 per cent. on the capital which they have invested in that trade.

They further state that the season has now arrived when they ought to commence the shipments of supplies of goods suitable for the next year's Gambia trade. But they plead that in the present neglected state of the colony it would not be judicious to make the requisite preparatory arrangements—thus not only inflicting injury on the colony, but also, reflectively, of course, upon the industries of the mother country.

It has been authoritatively asserted that Her Majesty's Government cannot employ force for the establishment of peace or putting down outrages in countries beyond the jurisdiction of the Crown.

But inasmuch as the British Government not only claims, but exercises jurisdiction over the waters of the Gambia, by levying taxes on goods ascending and descending that river, it would seem only a matter of right that Her Majesty's subjects, recollecting that in England taxation and protection go together, should either receive, in this instance, protection from the colonial authorities, or that they should celebrate the demise of their authority and power by the removal of all duties and all official impediments and restrictions on the river.

Appealed to by its members on this question, the Chamber can only in its turn make representations to the Colonial Office. I would, therefore, respectfully call the serious attention of Her Majesty's Government to these complaints, and urge that these grave disabilities, amounting even to wrongs upon British commerce, may without delay be redressed.—I have, &c.,

(Signed) **James F. Hutton, President.**

---

(Copy.)

Downing Street, October 21st, 1885.  
To J. F. Hutton, Esq., President, Manchester Chamber of Commerce.

Sir,—I am directed by Secretary Colonel Stanley to state that he has had under his consideration your letters of the 9th ult. and the 13th inst., on the subject of the injury to British subjects and property, and the loss of trade occasioned by the native wars in the districts bordering on the River Gambia.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Recent Disturbances on the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following communications in reference to the recent disturbances on the River Gambia have appeared in a recent number of the Manchester Guardian:—

Manchester Chamber of Commerce,  
September 9, 1885.

To the Right Hon. Colonel Stanley, M.P., &c., H.M. Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies.

Sir,—I beg to enclose copy of letter which has been addressed to this Chamber by Mr. H. H. Lee, of the River Gambia, relative to the present deplorable condition of trade in that colony, which is caused in great part by the raids of robber chiefs. I also send you copy of a resolution passed this morning at a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Chamber. On the 21st of May last I had the honour of communicating to the Right Hon. the Earl of Derby a copy of a memorial of the merchants of Sierra Leone on a similar state of affairs in that colony, and of which his Lordship acknowledged receipt on the 16th of June. I would most respectfully express the hope that instructions may be at once forwarded to the Administrators of Her Majesty’s settlements on the West Coast of Africa to put an end to these raids on British merchants, and to protect their interests.—I have, &c.,  
(Signed) James F. Hutton, President.

Manchester, August 31, 1885.

To J. F. Hutton, Esq., President Manchester Chamber of Commerce.

Sir,—Bad trade exists not only in England, but also in our colonies in Western Africa, &c.; therefore it is time the voices of merchants were heard regarding the administration of government there. Recently information has been forwarded to your Chamber of Commerce regarding Sierra Leone and the Gold Coast; and I call your attention to the Gambia, whose interests your Chamber so warmly defended a few years back when Government proposed to transfer it to France. Ever since then we have been ignored at home, the trade instead of prospering has been deteriorating, and we have now reached such a disastrous state that ere long every merchant will have to close his establishment, and England will lose another of her own markets for her manufactures, though even a small one. This condition of trade in Gambia is mainly caused by robbery and by marauding chiefs, whose raids are so much on the increase that merchants are being gradually ruined. In spite of this, heavy taxes are being levied on the trade, and absolutely nothing is done to protect us from these robbers.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.72, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Mr. Hutton on West African Affairs', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The West African settlements comprise Sierra Leone, Gambia, the Gold Coast, and Lagos. Sierra Leone has belonged to Great Britain for over eighty years, and is the most considerable of these colonies, and the centre of government of the whole Coast. Gambia, the Gold Coast, and Lagos were in 1866 placed under the Governor of Sierra Leone, much against their wishes and their interests, and it is the government and welfare of these three smaller possessions which have been the most neglected. For nearly 300 years English merchants have been trading in Gambia, which is the nearest colony to the mother country. The annual imports during the last ten years have averaged 127,000l., and the exports 155,000l. The annual revenue is raised by import and export duties, and amounts to 18,000l., out of which sum over 6,000l. is paid in salaries to the Governor and about 25 civil officers appointed by the Colonial-office. The principal grievance of the merchants resident there is that the Imperial Government appoints all the officers, taxes them heavily to pay the official salaries, and affords no protection whatever against the surrounding native tribes. There is a Legislative Council appointed by the Crown, but only one merchant is a member, whose presence is tantamount to being useless when opposed to the opinions of the Government officials. The Gambia merchants complain that in 1870, after attempting to dispose of this colony, the Imperial Government withdrew all the troops, and ever since they have been denuded of all means of defending themselves; and although the Home Government has been appealed to for help, not even a gunboat has visited the colony during the last 16 months, and the colony itself has been compelled lately to arrange for the purchase of a small armed steamer to run up and down the river. Serious disturbances have recently broken out among the natives on British territory, and the natives having threatened an attack upon Bathurst—the seat of the Government—this colony has been compelled to obtain aid from the French Government, and to get their town garrisoned by French troops, and the harbour protected by a French war vessel.

The colonists also complain that they have now no direct mail communication with this country, and that they are compelled to contribute 1,000l. per annum towards the useless maintenance of a small steamer running once a month to Sierra Leone, 500 miles further down the Coast. During the last five years there have been in Gambia five different Governors or acting Governors. The present Governor was appointed in October, 1871, at a salary of 1,300l. per annum; he has held his appointment eighteen months, out of which time only seven months have been spent by him in the colony.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-02-25', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_04_1873#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.699, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The question of the drink traffic and King Ja Ja's troubles, which have been subjects of discussion in the House of Commons lately, ought to attract increased attention to the trade of West Africa.

Our oldest settlement there is at the mouth of the Gambia river; but though the oldest, the total import and export trade amounts to only £380,000 a year. With the exception of the Senegal, the river is the finest on this part of the coast, but it is almost useless for trade purposes, because the country is in so disturbed a condition. Wax, hides, and ground nuts are the principal exports. The ground nuts are sent to Marseilles, where a substitute for olive oil is pressed from them. Rice, cotton, maize, and a kind of millet are also produced, but not in sufficient quantities for export. The charge on ordinary merchandise is 2 per cent. _ad valorem_.

Sierra Leone, with a coast line 200 miles long, has a trade of a different character, the produce of the palm, nuts and oil, hides, gum copal, ground nuts, ginger, and kola nuts being exported. The gum copal and the palm oil are for the most part shipped to Great Britain, and the hides to the United States.

The most promising place of all in this part of the world is Lagos, where the natives are eager to trade. The exports are palm oil and various oil seeds; but although the chances of business are excellent, British rule has failed to develop trade to anything like the extent that was anticipated. The reason is the isolation of the settlements, which were originally slave settlements. Fifty years ago slavery was abolished, and then, instead of making a radical change in the methods of government which the altered conditions required, no action was taken, and the machinery of government was merely adapted to the circumstances. The British Administration has made practically no effort to conciliate the tribes in the interior, or to remove the suspicions which the early history of the colonies had implanted in the minds of the natives. Custom-houses were set up, and, as the natives derive no benefit from the expenditure of the taxes in the colonies, they naturally did not like the new institutions. Then, again, the natives on the coast hate those in the interior, and British administrators invariably sided with the former. The three Ashantee wars were due to this cause. If efforts were made to conciliate the Mandingoes, the Foulahs, and other large tribes in the interior, the trade of these settlements would certainly not consist, as it does at the present time, almost exclusively of the produce of the fringe of land adjoining the sea. The Americans and Germans, particularly the latter, are looking after this trade. As usual, the Germans are picking up the language and the customs of the natives, and it is time our Government bestirred itself to conciliate people who might be valuable customers.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1888#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Intestine wars had broken out amongst the natives in the Mellicourie country, near Sierra Leone, and several European factories had been destroyed and plundered. The authorities at Sierra Leone were adopting measures to punish the marauders and obtain reparation for the losses sustained by British subjects during the disturbance. Trade was very inactive, and in consequence of heavy rains sickness was rather prevalent amongst Europeans. The ships Advance, Day Spring, and Ellerslie were in port.

At Bathurst the health was very good, but the trade was dull. The barque Le Grace, of Marseilles, was in port.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.713, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE WITH THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. J. F. Hutton said that for years past the Manchester Chamber of Commerce had been in correspondence with the Colonial Office in reference to the West Coast of Africa, and had constantly called attention to the neglect of the authorities to attend to the interests of our trade, and to the responsibilities that ought to be undertaken in connexion with it. This trade especially concerned Manchester and the district around, because the bulk of the goods that went to the West Coast were cotton goods. For that reason, the Manchester Chamber of Commerce felt greatly interested in this question, and they asked the Government to consider whether they could not accept a greater amount of responsibility, not only as regarded the merchants, but also as regarded the natives in the interior. This country held possession of a mere fringe of the coast; but the goods that passed up the river were taxed, and merchants got no protection for their trade in return. The policy of the Colonial Office deterred merchants from going into the interior, and disheartened them. They had been urged, and in fact warned, not to go into the interior. The result was that our trade had fallen off considerably. He considered that the cause of this decline was, in a great measure, the absence of that order and responsibility that ought to exist on the coast of Africa. Complaints had been made of internal wars. These wars were continually arising among the tribes, and in some cases merchants had been ruined. A substantial duty was levied on goods passing along the Gambia, and the protection accorded in return was most inadequate. The case of Gambia was, perhaps, the worst of the class. It had been troubled by wars and robberies to such an extent that trade was almost ruined, and there was scarcely a merchant left of any position. The trade of the district was gradually passing into the hands of the French, from the want of activity and determination on the part of the British authorities. The British traders were being taxed without getting any adequate protection in return. The merchants had no representative on the Council. It was true there were...', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.715, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Wars among the Natives of the River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our informant, to whom we have alluded in our notice of the River Gambia, on our second page, writes in substance as follows, relative to those wars among the natives of the Gambia Districts, to which we have more than once alluded, and which have been generally represented as resulting from a Mohammedan propaganda by fire and sword:—

According to his version, the origin of this disturbance is to be found in the mismanagement of the late British war against the kingdom of Badiboo; and, therefore, that what seems now to occupy almost exclusively the heads, hearts, and hands of the Government, is traceable distinctly to their own acts. He seems to consider that the chief Mahabah is performing a duty which the Government neglected to do, and for doing which it envies the man who is really performing very important public services, and preparing the way for the progressive civilization of the country. That man, Mahabah, he says, is not seeking his own interests only, but that of all British subjects. British merchants have been without any real, efficient protection in the river of late years, and Mahabah has made a vast improvement in this respect during the last 24 months. It is true, he proceeds, that, partly owing to the war, and partly to the famine that prevailed during the rainy season, there has been a great deficiency of produce, "but it is far better to prepare the ground before sowing seed, than to sow it in unprepared soil." The Pagsoos, in this river, are a people that do not work, but who go about plundering those who do work; pillaging the merchants and traders, and committing many other and great enormities. They are, in fact, a lazy, predatory, and degraded people. The late war between the British and Badiboo was caused by such deeds as are above alluded to. The British effected really nothing, but Mahabah has made an entire change. These people, before so troublesome, having been brought by him under subjection, are now learning to depend on their own labour for the means of support; so that British merchants, who previously scarcely dared to commission any traders in that part, have now been able to find employment as traders there for those who have been (so arbitrarily, as he contends) dismissed from the Government service.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.716, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have numerous treaties with the natives, beginning from 1826; they relate, in some instances, to cessions of territory, and always contain engagements for the protection of trade, the abolition of slavery, and the preservation of peace. They are not entered into by the natives without great consideration, and as they are rarely, if ever, broken, they are decidedly beneficial to the colony. Moreover, they afford us the plea for proffering our intervention when they show a disposition to quarrel amongst themselves, and in some recent instances our interference has been attended with very good results. The practice which has been long and successfully followed at Sierra Leone, of paying the chiefs small stipends to encourage them in observing these engagements, might advantageously be introduced at the Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.707, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.708, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RAILWAY SCHEMES FOR SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'When there is a promise of a settled and peaceful state of affairs it is disappointing that it should not result in a greater flow of trade. There are various causes assigned for the depression in Sierra Leone. I may mention some of these. Stoppage of the slave traffic: A few years ago it was the practice of traders, called Banjuls, from Bathurst, to betake themselves to the riverine towns of the Protectorate, and purchase slaves brought from up-country, and take them back to Bathurst; and the money brought for this purpose was usually spent in Freetown. Again, traders from the Susu country and Futa Yallon used to drive cattle to Freetown, barter them there for trade guns, powder, and Manchester goods, proceed up country—preferably to those parts where slave raiding and tribal wars were going on—purchase the captives taken, and return with them to their own country. All this trade is now stopped, and I do not suppose any right-minded person can regret it when he considers the iniquities of the slave traffic. During my tour last year in the interior I released several parties of slaves consisting of men, women, and children, either shackled with chains or led along tied to one another with halters round their necks. Another cause of the depression has been attributed to the attitude assumed by the domestic slaves, who are not so subservient as formerly to their masters, who find it difficult to get them to gather the produce and send it to the markets. However, I have found that those masters who treat their slaves kindly do not lose them. Hundreds of slaves come every week to Freetown with trade canoes across from Bullom and the adjacent shores, and I have heard no complaints of their deserting their masters. A third cause assigned is the influx of Natives from the interior and the emigration of labourers. It is estimated that 6,000 labourers have proceeded to the Congo since the commencement of the year. This emigration may affect the producing power, but numbers of these labourers return with their wages, which they spend in the Colony; and those who come to Freetown and obtain work there convert their earnings into goods and return with them to their masters. The cessation of the raids and wars which supplied the slave traders, and the entire prohibition of the traffic, must revolutionise the system of trade, and probably accounts for some of the depression that has prevailed, which has been even more felt in French Guinea, as I am informed, than in the Colony of Sierra Leone.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1895#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.713, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "A Snubbed Colony—Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Well, his lordship sends us an answer through the Administrator here, which being summarized is, "his lordship regrets that in your opinion trade should be in such a depressed state." Now, the words "your opinion" mean it is his lordship's opinion, based on that of the Administrator, that trade is good. And how does he arrive at that? Well, he takes the return of the revenue for the past couple of years and compares that with former years, and it looks well; but then importers and exporters had to pay duties each year whether they lost or not, hoping for the best; but really the past two years have been most disastrous. Four small mercantile houses have been smashed and disappeared; all the other houses have lost heavily, and some are considering about reducing or giving up the trade. The revenue will not increase then. His lordship "will not allow the use of force to stop native wars; counsel and persuasion must be used." Now, as for the latter, even accompanied by presents, the natives only laugh at them, and accept the presents. "As to protection of traders in Gambia River he cannot depart from the policy laid down already. (See Parliamentary Papers.)

"Expedition planned in the interests of Gambia; any disappointment as to its effect not caused by those who planned and conducted it. So Gambia must pay.

"Other parts of your letter are engaging the attention of the Colonial Office." Such was our answer.

Last mail brought me out a copy of the "Report of the Upper Gambia Expedition," better known as the Timbo Expedition, as printed for Parliament. It is got up so as to impress the M.P.'s "that something has been done." I always said it was suddenly conceived, hastily planned, and insufficiently supplied with stores and means of transit. I now find it was hastily and superficially carried out, but that was not the leader's fault, it was "orders." Fancy timing a man to do a journey in an almost unexplored region in Africa to a certain date; a race against time across country. The result has been very little. Space will not permit of more than notice of salient points.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-11-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1882#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.708, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RAILWAY SCHEMES FOR SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The chief cause, in my opinion, of the present depression was the recent reduction in the price of palm kernels and oil, which amounted at first to 25 per cent. This led to many of the Native chiefs, forming a combination, and issuing orders to their people not to sell palm kernels under 5s. a bushel. This resulted in a temporary cessation of the trade, but probably had a more injurious effect still in that it checked the harvesting of the nuts, which thus were lost. I do not think this depression can be attributable to any diminution in the produce of the country. The annual report for 1893 shows there was a net increase of £21,789 in the value of exports during that year; the chief exports being palm kernels, rubber, kola nuts, palm oil, ginger, rice, gum copal, pepper and benniseed. Last year the revenue reached the highest figures it has ever done, which shows that the produce has in no sense diminished; but I should say the chief cause of the low prices, and therefore depression, is that as there are now more traders engaged in commerce than formerly there is a keener competition and a far smaller margin of profit. A botanic station is being started at Freetown, and preparations made to hold an agricultural show next January, which I hope will be an annual one.

Amongst the principal objects is the encouragement of the cultivation of coffee, cocoa, and kola nuts. Already the prospect of the agricultural shows has given a spurt to these industries, and coffee especially is being largely planted. The country rice should be introduced to the markets at home. I understand there is a prejudice against it owing to its brown appearance; this is due to the fact that small portions of the husk are left adhering to the grain; this imperfection is in appearance only—the particles of husk give a very sweet flavour to the rice, and make it rich and nourishing. If once the public could get over their prejudice against it they would buy it readily. The cultivation of the Kola Nut is an industry that should be fostered. There is an increasing demand for it all over the world. In the German army a preparation of the nut forms a reserve ration for active service. I believe this industry will, in the future, yield larger returns than coffee or cocoa. An examination of the causes of trade depression is of importance, for after all the question of the introduction of a railway into a country must be determined by the prospects of its trade.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1895#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.696, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]
